PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Reserves: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Defence Force Reserves: Taxation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That as Mr R. J. L. Hawke has publicly stated:
(1) 'The Defence Force Reserves are the backbone of our nation's defence',
(2) the Defence Force Reserves are a highly economical and viable means of training men and women to serve Australia in times of emergency,
(3) the reserves are composed of volunteers dedicated to Australia.

Furthermore, we the undersigned recognise that members of the reserves are required to maintain levels of efficiency at least equivalent to those of the permanent forces, and that members of reserves spend much of their own time and money towards reserve training obligations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government recognise the role played by the reserves in serving Australia, that reserve pays and allowances are already far below the levels for equivalent work in the general work force, and that therefore the proposed introduction of taxation to the meagre pays earned by members for the Defence Force Reserves is a poor way of saying thank you.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 188 citizens), Lajovic (from 37 citizens), Missen (from 33 citizens), Robertson (from 454 citizens), Sibraa (from 38 citizens), Tate ( from 87 citizens) and Walters (from 517 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention of the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; believing that this implementation would result in:
1. Undue cost to the nation at this time.

2. 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

3. The strong encouragements to mothers to join the work force, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
4. The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 198 citizens) and Lajovic (from 108 citizens) .

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia.
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
i. intolerable behaviour;
ii. desertion for two years;
iii separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 23 citizens).

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (NUCLEAR MATERIALS AND HARDWARE) PROHIBITION BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the exportation of nuclear materials and the importation of nuclear hardware, and for purposes connected therewith.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my second reading speech which explains the urgent need for an absolute ban on the export of uranium and an absolute ban on the importation of nuclear hardware.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This legislation is of fundamental importance to Australia and the World.

It proposes an absolute prohibition on the export of uranium; an absolute prohibition on the import of hardware necessary for a nuclear power station and uranium enrichment plant, and an absolute prohibition on the import of spent nuclear fuel rods.
There are considerable economic arguments against uranium and the nuclear industry, arguments of such force that they indicate nuclear power is of little benefit to overseas nations or Australia.
The economic, environmental and social arguments against uranium and nuclear power will be dealt with by my colleagues in later debate. But a couple of points deserve to be raised now.
Nuclear energy is often portrayed as an alternative to oil dependence and a must for the security of countries such as Japan, who depend on imported oil for the bulk of their energy needs.

This is completely wrong. Nuclear power, which produces only electricity, can never be substituted for oil. Over 90% of oil is used for the transport and petrochemical industries: electricity is just not an energy source for them.

Because of this, even if Japan quadrupled its nuclear power capacity by 1990 ( technically impossible and prohibitively expensive) Japan's dependence on imported oil would decline by only 10%. Nuclear power could never provide them with energy security.
Nuclear power will never provide the Third World with the energy it so desperately needs.

The Third World is short in capital, infrastructure, delivery systems and income. This makes the argument against nuclear power, which depends on all the above conditions, all the stronger in developing countries.
Currently the International Atomic Energy estimates that nuclear energy contributes less than 5% of developing nations electricity, substantially less than energy sources such as firewood.
However, Australia's primary concern must be for the proliferation of nuclear weapons. This concern pales all other arguments into insignificance.
National morality in Australia would never countenance the export of nerve gas or biological weapons for profit-even to allies.
Yet we are prepared to sell uranium for profit.
Nuclear weapons would not be possible without supplies of uranium.
Both super powers have stored 50,000 nuclear warheads for use against people.
There are so many warheads that they exceed the number of missiles or aircraft to deploy them against the enemy.

The U.S. can deliver 12,000 warheads on the Soviets and the Soviets can unload 8,000 warheads on the U.S. with such accuracy as would land them within 100 feet of a target often after travelling thousands of miles.
The total destructive power of this arsenal is equivalent to one million Hiroshima-sized bombs.
One million times the human suffering; one million times the destruction and one million times the military futility that was Hiroshima.
Some of these weapons have a destructive capacity equivalent to 50 megatons of T.N.T. This means they are some twenty times as powerful as all the explosives detonated in World War II.
The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute recognised the problems of proliferation when it stated in 1979:
''The peaceful and military aspects of nuclear energy are intrinsically linked and it is impossible to separate them.''

The spread of so-called civilian nuclear power to non-nuclear states is one of the greatest dangers of proliferation. India was able to explode a nuclear weapon in 1974-with material from a civilian and research reactor provided by the U.S. and Canada.

The arms race continues totally unabated. President Reagan wants another 11,000 nuclear weapons for the U.S. Cruise and Pershing missiles are to be deployed in Europe in December. The Soviets will undoubtedly match each escalation.
With every new weapon the warning time for an outbreak of war is reduced. Hot- line telephones are outmoded. The time will not be there to consult in the face of a crisis.
Already we have come within 3 minutes of an accidental outbreak of nuclear war.
In October 1979 a false warning of missile attack on the U.S. led to the scrambling of nuclear-armed aircraft. If the accident had not been discovered hundreds of millions of people would have died.
Similar accidents were repeated twice in 1980.

Recently we had clear statements from the Minister that the U.S. base at North- West Cape, would be a nuclear target in the event of a nuclear war. Pine Gap, Narrangar, Perth and Canberra must also surely rank high as targets.

The effects of a one-megaton bomb-very small by today's standards-on a city are horrific and beyond comprehension. Jonathan Schell, in his brilliant book 'The Fate of the Earth' wrote of the impact of such a bomb:
'A one-megaton bomb is eighty times the size of the weapon that obliterated Hiroshima.'
Schell notes that a one-megaton bomb would 'gut or flatten' every building within 61 square miles of the explosion, and would heavily damage buildings within a 200 square mile radius.
People would be hurled around along with all the other debris. Hot winds travelling at 400 miles per hour would prevail for more than two miles from the point of the explosion.
A fireball, one mile wide and six miles high would envelope all within the area of the blast.
Anyone caught within nine miles of ground zero would receive third degree burns and would probably die within hours. Those closer to the explosion would be charred or vapourised.
Schell concludes:

'In this vast theatre of physical effects, all the scenes of agony and death that took place at Hiroshima would again take place, but now involving millions of people rather than hundreds of thousands.'
A nuclear war would not be simply another war with bigger bombs. It would be the end of life as we know it.
Even if the war was 'limited' to the northern hemisphere latest scientific opinion believes that eventually the radioactive fallout would contaminate the southern hemisphere.
While ordinary people are being alarmed at the prospect of self-induced extinction political leaders, directly or indirectly, prop up the arms race.
75 per cent of West Germans have indicated in opinion polls that they do not want any more nuclear weapons- Cruise and Pershing missiles-in their backyard.
Their environment already bristles with 6000 nuclear warheads. No wonder they are marching by the millions in the street to show their concern. No wonder they want no more weapons.
Yet, in their infinite wisdom, Governments avidly acquire nuclear weapons at ever increasing rates.
We have to recognise that in making the world more dangerous for the Russians and other potential enemies we are also making it more dangerous for ourselves.
Australia, although small, is a respected democracy.
We are rich in uranium. We have the potential to make a spirited moral stand against the insanity of the arms race, the insanity of nuclear power and the insanity of uranium mining.

If we make a principled stand, backed up with the willingness to forgo some short term monetary gain, we will provide a powerful message to the people of the world about the enormity of the danger that we all face.
Perhaps it is too late. Even if that were the case nothing should ever prevent us from trying to avert a nuclear holocaust. We must give this one last shot.
We have the opportunity, with this Bill, to marshall ordinary people to protest to work towards a safe future for us all.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983 (No. 2)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — When the debate was interrupted last night I was speaking to my amendment No. (6) to leave out clause 13 which seeks to impose sales tax on a range of products which contain sun screen agents. I was pointing out to the Committee the problem currently being caused by melanomas in my own State in particular but in the whole of Australia. The death rate in all States has risen since records were first kept in 1951. In Queensland, where an intensive research program is currently under way, the death rate has doubled in the decade from 1951 to 1960, doubled again from 1961 to 1970 and doubled again from 1971 to 1980. The point is that Australia has the highest incidence of melanoma in the world, followed by New Zealand, Hawaii and South Africa. According to the latest available statistics, a large percentage of melanomas- somewhere of the order of 20 per cent-are on the head, the neck, the scalp, the face, the ears and the lips.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government proposes to exempt from sales tax those agents which screen out solar ultra violet rays it seeks to place sales tax on a variety of other goods which are described as cosmetic preparations. The problem here is a very acute one in that by so doing the Government will establish a disincentive for those people who prepare various cosmetics to have those cosmetics contain screening agents. As a result it will be uneconomic to include protecting agents in preparations such as face creams, face oils, face lotions, body creams, body oils, lipsticks and the like. So rather than bringing about a positive preventive health measure the Government is setting up a disincentive. The argument has been advanced that this measure will affect only cosmetics. Various Government spokesmen have alighted on night cream as an example of this. I do not mind at all if night cream is subject to sales tax. But I would like the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) to tell me what other preparations which are not used during the day will be subject to sales tax.

The situation is very clear. Many women will not use under their make-up-this applies also to men who use various skin preparations-a commercial item sold as a screening agent for ultraviolet rays whereas they could very well use a conditioner or body lotion of one kind or another.

On 5 October I wrote to Senator Walsh who is the Minister representing the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this place and said that I would bring this matter up during the Committee stage of this Bill and seek from him a response in relation to a number of commercial preparations. I took this action because preparations such as conditioner make-up, pure colour blush, pure colour lipstick, lip gloss, radiant compound and foundation compound are advertised in stores as cosmetics. The brochure that is put out at the end of the year by the Commonwealth Department of Health indicates that each of those items is 99 per cent effective in screening out ultraviolet rays. I do not know whether people who live in other States are worried about this issue, but when one considers the statistics in the various States of Australia, I think they ought to be. We have to do something. We have not only to undertake research into this area but also to adopt positive, effective and preventative measures in the area of skin cancers and associated melanomas.

Various State governments, with the assistance of the Commonwealth Government I might add, through the Department of Health, have spent a great deal of money over the years on developing various programs of public education to get people in Australia to be aware of the problems of excessive exposure to the sun. I believe the imposition of sales tax in this area will be a deterrent, a disincentive, to the producers to include those particular screening agents in the development of new cosmetics, or even in some of the cosmetics which are currently available. I suggested to the Government quite some time ago, when this measure was first announced in the Budget, that an alternative method of approaching this could very well be to impose sales tax on ineffective screening agents that are included in any preparation so that we would build in an incentive to the producers not to include various items in their cosmetics. In effect we would be saying to the producers: 'Put into your lipsticks and your other cosmetic preparations effective screening agents'.

One of the items I suggested to the Minister was a lip gloss. I will not read the commercial name of it, but it is readily available and is generally sold in most chemist shops and pharmacies around Australia. The preparation comes in a variety of tastes. It is used particularly by high school kids. It has a relatively low colour, so those who use it do not run foul of the teachers. This is an extremely effective preparation for the kids to wear when they go out in the sun to play basketball, cricket or whatever. I think that what we ought to be doing at the school level is actually encouraging sensible use of various preparations. I could not care less whether they are sold as cosmetics or anything else. As long as they are effective agents for the screening of ultraviolet rays, I think we should give every encouragement that we can and not give discouragement, as is currently envisaged by clause 13 of the Schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with everything that Senator Macklin said with regard to skin cancer. For people such as myself who have very efficient solar collectors it is fairly important to recognise the damage that occurs to our heads, not by rays going right through, but by the skin cancer that can start very early in life. My hair started falling out when I was quite young, when I was about 19 or 20 years of age. Only now am I starting to experience the damage that was most probably caused by exposure to the sun many years ago. This is an important matter. I do not think that Senator Macklin, who spoke previously, mentioned it. The damage to the skin that shows up later in life is often done quite early. People in this country should be encouraged to use sunscreening agents not only during the summer time but virtually all year round. It does not matter whether they live in Tasmania or Queensland. Tasmania gets a lot of very sunny days when the ultraviolet rays get through and impinge on people like me, those who play sports, those who work on farms and those who are out in the sun a great deal of the time.
—But ultraviolet radiation is worse in Tasmania than it is in the north of Australia.

—Senator Jessop said that the ultraviolet radiation is worse in Tasmania than it is in the north. I do not have the figures for the hours but I will get those. I believe that the Government is short-sighted on this matter. I am sure that the Commonwealth Department of Health, which has put out a very good list of the effective sunscreening agents and compounds, would be distressed by the Government's attitude. I feel that the Department of the Treasury should have liaised with the Commonwealth Health Department before this measure was introduced. The Commonwealth should give incentives to encourage makers of these products to include sunscreening agents in their goods because, eventually, it will have to pay the health costs of people who have to receive treatment for sun-related problems. In some cases this treatment is very expensive and extensive. The cost is quite considerable. A lot of damage could be avoided if people recognised that they should use effective-that is very important-sunscreening agents. I think that it should be compulsory for any day cream produced in this country to include some kind of sunscreening agent rather than the Government giving a disincentive to producers by the introduction of this measure. I do not know how much revenue it will collect from this measure; it may be considerable. But I doubt whether it will be more than the long term cost of the health treatment of victims. I believe that ineffective screening agents should be taxed as Senator Macklin said. I sincerely ask the Government to re-examine this matter. When it realises that it has made a mistake it can alter its decision.

—Briefly I support those comments. This is an important matter. It again illustrates the lack of thought by this Government with respect to the introduction of measures such as a sales tax on these fluids and creams about which we are speaking. It is true that ultraviolet radiation varies depending on which part of the world one lives. Tasmania and other parts of Australia on that latitude are subjected more to ultraviolet rays than people in Darwin. People in Darwin are affected more by infra-red radiation . If the proliferation of coal-fired and oil-fired power stations in the world continues it will present a threat to the ozone layer. This is a problem with which the world will have to come to grips very shortly. After all, the ozone layer happens to be the world's environmental shield. It protects the environment of the earth against ultraviolet radiation. I support the Australian Democrats in the concern that ultraviolet radiation is a problem. I ask the Government to re-examine its decision on this matter with the hope that, at some future time, it will reduce or remove the sales tax on those items.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said yesterday the Government cannot accept any of these amendments. I am not levelling this charge at Senator Macklin but originally there was a good deal of misunderstanding and, I suggest, even misrepresentation partly because this was one of many measures which came out on Budget night when journalists are confronted with a heap of paper about a foot high and three or four hours later are expected to write reasonably intelligible and accurate reports on matters in that heap of paper. There are always of course difficulties in that. But originally it was, at its most charitable, misunderstood as a decision to exclude from sales tax exemption all sunscreen agents. It was of course no such thing. It was a decision to exclude from the exemption from sales tax those cosmetics which contained a sunscreen agent. The reason for that is that if the pre-existing exemptions were allowed to continue there would be massive scope for almost the whole spectrum of cosmetics to include a sunscreen agent.
—But it is a good thing, Minister, surely, that that should happen .

—The honourable senator might say that it is a good thing, but one can still buy sunscreen agents free of sales tax. If the exemption were to be allowed to continue in its present form, it would be able to open up a very substantial loophole for the evasion of sales tax on what are purely cosmetic products through the relatively cheap additions to them of the sunscreen agent, and then claiming to the sales tax branch of the Australian Taxation Office that they contain a sunscreen agent and therefore are exempt from sales tax. Indeed I do not think it would be drawing a very long bow to say that once the potential to evade sales tax on cosmetics in general became fully appreciated virtually all revenue currently gained from cosmetics would be lost. I know some people argue that it is inappropriate to levy sales tax on pure cosmetics. That, however, is a different question. I have attempted very quickly to find out what the total revenue from the sales tax on cosmetics is, but I think common sense tells us that expenditure per capita on cosmetics is quite high and that the total revenue from sales tax on cosmetics must run into tens of millions of dollars anyway. I would expect something like $50m or $60m, although that cannot be taken as a definitive figure. That is the sort of revenue which was at risk if the pre-existing exemption was allowed to persist indefinitely.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing I stress that sunscreen agents which are marketed as sunscreen agents can still be obtained free of sales tax. Subject to it being agreed to by the Committee of the Whole-I do not think there is any serious suggestion that it will not be agreed to-the Government has closed a loophole via which purely cosmetic preparations were able to evade or avoid the high rate of sales tax which is applied to general cosmetic preparations. If somebody wants to take up the question of whether cosmetics ought to be taxed at all or taxed at that rate , that is a separate question and one that has not been the subject of this debate in any case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister to respond to a question I asked him in a letter in which I set out seven products which are undoubtedly cosmetics and sold as such and which are included in the Department of Health category under the heading 'lip, nose and face products'. Those seven items that I mentioned to him by way of letter on 5 October are classified as offering 99 per cent protection. The point we are trying to make is not that there is evasion here but that it is an excellent idea if we push to the producers of cosmetics that they do include in their cosmetic effective sunscreening agents.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister raised the matter of cost. I admit the cost. I suggested the alternative method of actually penalising those which are not effective. They include not only cosmetics but also non-effective agents that are sold as sunscreening agents. I do not mind taking those off the market or making them much more expensive because they are causing problems. Items are being sold to people which are not doing them any good. If one considers the cost at one end, one has also to consider the cost at the other end. The cost in Australia of treating melanomas and cancers is very high, and it grows every year. I quoted from the latest authoritative study, 'Changing Epidemiology of Malignant Melanomas', which contains figures showing that the death rate has doubled every 10 years; and the problem extends further than the death rate. We must address this problem and not simply put it to one side.

The Opposition does not support this amendment, therefore it will fail. I hope that the Government will look at this issue to see whether a much more rational way of taxing these products can be devised so that we can actually promote to the producers of various cosmetics in Australia that they stay with the 99 per cent effectiveness they have built in already. I am quite sure that if this amendment were passed the producers of cosmetics would take that ingredient out of their cosmetics. There would be no reason to have it in there. They would take it out and we would lose one of the most effective widespread screening agents in Australia, because far more people buy cosmetics than buy sunscreen agents. There is no way in the world that a person putting on a variety of these cosmetics will put underneath them a sunscreening agent sold as such. They will put a foundation underneath which may be 99 per cent effective. In this country, with the highest melanoma rate in the world, that would be useful in preventive medicine terms. Therefore, I ask the Government to look again at this issue to see whether some more rational way might be devised by which we could still get the producers of the various cosmetics to put a sunscreening agent in them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Macklin did ask some specific questions about products which he declined to name, so I will not name them either. Otherwise I would seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Commissioner on this subject. Senator Macklin inquired about seven products. The definition given by the Commissioner of Taxation in a letter of 6 October was that five of those products would no longer be exempt from the 32 1/2 per cent tax. The question with respect to the other two products is still undecided. That is, of course, a matter for the Commissioner's interpretation, as are many other matters regarding the administration of the Taxation Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin's second suggestion was that cosmetic manufacturers should be induced in some way to include a sunscreen agent in their products. They have been so induced in the past, it must be acknowledged, by the exemption from sales tax of preparations which include a sunscreen agent. That is the positive side of the argument. The negative side of the argument is that an inducement to include such an agent is also an inducement to evade taxation on cosmetics generally. I will quote this much from the Commissioner's letter:
. . . broadly speaking, lipstick products (all shades) which are put up and sold principally for purposes other than as a sunscreen are not accepted as being exempt under item 38A.
Their purpose is use as a cosmetic and any use as a sunscreen is considered to be minimal.
Those are the broad guidelines which the Commissioner intends to follow when making determinations about individual products on this matter.

It is something which the Government can and, I would expect, will be willing to consider in the future. But the potential gains to revenue through the wider use of this loophole are very significant. I stress again that sunscreen agents which are sold as sunscreen agents have been and will continue to be exempt from sales tax. (Quorum formed)
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I want to raise an item which I think is quite important and that is the matter of fire fighting equipment for people in fire-prone areas. I am thinking particularly of South Australia and Victoria, following the devastation by the bushfires earlier in the year. There seems to be some confusion associated with the question whether these items are exempt or should be exempt from sales tax. As I understand it, the confusion arises because of some statements that were made earlier this year . I quote an example of this. The headline of one article is 'Fires Bring Tax Aid for Some Power Equipment'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Residents of fire-prone areas who rely solely on electric pumps for their water supply, may now benefit from tax exemption in the purchase of auxiliary generators. Former Minister of Agriculture, Mr Brian Chatterton, made successful representations to the Federal Government-

TALK.START.PARA: —What clause are you addressing?

—I am talking about clause 50 of the Schedule. I am pointing to what I regard as an anomaly. I want to draw the Government's attention to it simply because I have here a letter from Mr Brian Chatterton to the Minister for Finance, the Hon. John Dawkins. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear John,

During the February 1983 bushfires in the Adelaide Hills the mains water pressure in many areas dropped to a low level which made sprinkler fire protection systems inoperative. Many residents are now installing pump and motor units to overcome the dual failure of water pressure and electric supply.

While the use of these units as mobile fire fighting units has now been defined as sales tax exempt there is some confusion over their use in fixed sprinkler protection systems as it is claimed, where the sprinklers cover parts of the garden as well as the house, that they are primarily for watering. I would point out that the watering function of these dual purpose systems is carried out on mains water pressure and the back up motor and pump is only for fire fighting when the pressure fails.
I would seek a clarification of the rules concerning sales tax exemption on motor and pump units as a matter of urgency as I have had an inquiry from--
a company-
who are undertaking a sales campaign in the Adelaide Hills and would like a firm basis for price quotation. This campaign is planned for the next few months--
the letter is dated 3 August-

so the equipment is ready for the next fire season. It is obvious that it is of considerable benefit to the community as a whole if residents invest in further fire protection devices. The experience of the February fires was that fixed sprinkler systems were extremely effective provided water pressure was maintained.

It is a very important matter and we should look at it as there is some confusion. The other day in Adelaide I heard from a person who provides this sort of equipment that apparently in Victoria there is an opinion that these items are exempt from sales tax. I point that out to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) in the spirit of sweet reason and hope that he can provide me with clarification of that, either now, if possible, or at some future time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am obliged to respond to Senator Jessop. I am not able to give a definitive response at this stage but I will take it up with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and see what information can be supplied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 8, Schedule, clause 17, paragraph (a), proposed paragraph 82 (1) (c), leave out '', fibreglass liners''.
(10) Page 9, Schedule, clause 19, paragraph (b), proposed paragraph 83 (2) (f), leave out '', fibreglass liners''.
(12) Page 9, Schedule, clause 19, paragraph (d), proposed paragraph 83 (3) (c), leave out '', fibreglass liners''.
(14) Page 9, Schedule, clause 20, paragraph (a), proposed paragraph 84 (1) (a), after ''liners'', insert '', other than fibreglass liners,''.
(17) Page 10, Schedule, clause 21, proposed paragraph 86 (1) (b), after '' liners'', insert '', other than fibreglass liners,''.

I think it should be clearly explained that the Australian Democrats, on behalf of a number of industry groups, have made representations to the Acting Treasurer (Mr Hurford) and we have had a very sympathetic hearing. We felt that we were making a degree of progress in several areas, having received indications that very serious consideration was being given to amending these schedules. Along the line it became quite clear that the Liberal Party Opposition would not support the Australian Democrats amendments. I find it very disappointing, as I am sure a lot of other people must, that in this chamber, the House of review, over and over again we hear from the Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia representatives platitudes and cases put supporting the Australian Democrats amendments yet we are not getting their voting support.

It needs to be recognised that this is still supposed to be the House of review . If we are not going to perform the function of reviewing things such as the anomalies which occur, and which have been drawn to the attention of this place and strongly supported by the Opposition, and send these items back to the House of Representatives where the Government can reconsider them, it is fairly pointless for us to express our feelings, sometimes very strongly, about the anomalies that are coming through and then refuse to vote to support those feelings. (Quorum formed)
In his second reading speech, the Acting Treasurer stated:
Some alterations are designed to remove competitive anomalies, that is, those which give some products a competitive advantage over other products.

The amendments that I have moved are necessary because of the Government moving in the opposite direction. It is creating anomalies rather than remedying anomalies. The amendments proposed by the Government maintain the anomalies within the swimming pool industry that the swimming pool industry representatives asked the Government to overcome. They discussed the problems with the Government. They in turn received very sympathetic consideration but, as a result of this Schedule, the more expensive concrete in-ground pools have escaped the bulk of the sales tax measures whereas the other types of in-ground and above-ground pools have still been fully or at least partly taxed in these revised amendments.

One of the great anomalies of which we have to be aware is that with pre- engineered vinyl-lined in-ground pools-there are eight different types of construction-one type will have a taxable floor with the remainder having exempt floors, six will have taxable walls, with two exempt, and five will have taxable coping, with three exempt. The effect of this will be considerable disparity in the swimming pool industry. One flow-on effect will be a disincentive against the enhancement of technological development of swimming pool construction.

This will happen for two reasons. Raw building materials will remain exempt whereas the technology based improvements, particularly for prefabrication of swimming pool products brought about by research and development in the industry which previously developed products to improve this industry, will now become taxable. The immediate effect of the rate increases announced by the Government will also exacerbate the poor financial position of many in this industry. One of the big problems-I drew attention to this earlier and I repeat it-is that it is doubtful whether sections 70A, 70B and 70D of the Sales Tax Assessment Act ( No. 1) will allow contractors to pass on the sales tax increases, for both technical and commercial reasons. The technical reasons need to be examined more thoroughly. Yesterday I had incorporated in Hansard a response from the Acting Treasurer, quoting the Commissioner for Taxation, which still left a lot of doubt as to whether labour involvement was likely to be caught up in the provision in the sales tax legislation for the new sales tax to be passed on to the consumer.

But that is a technical reason. There is a much stronger commercial reason, particularly in this industry. The pools are sold according to contract and the buyer agrees to the installation of a pool at some time in the future. If that time lapse happens to go over Budget day, the contract agreed to prior to Budget day is suddenly changed and the price is increased, quite dramatically in some cases. It is all very well for us to say: 'That is fair enough. There is provision within the law for the contractor to go back to the consumer and claim the increase'. But that is not the way it happens in the real world. In the real world what happens is that the contractor goes back to the buyer and says: 'I am sorry, but the price has increased. Please will you pay the increased price?' The buyer simply says: 'Look, I am sorry, I cannot afford to'. They either get around to negotiate a price, which means that the contractor has to pick up part of the tab, or the order is cancelled. I have had representations from people in the swimming pool industry which indicate-

TALK.START.PARA: —We all have. We all have the same paper as you are reading from.
—I am not reading from a paper, Senator.
—What you read out before; we have that here.

—No, I am sorry. The honourable senator is right off beam. I am not reading from any paper. The honourable senator will have her opportunity in a few moments, and I would like her to quote from the paper that she says is being read. In fact, the paper to which she refers relates to a comment I made about pre-engineered vinyl pools, to which I referred about seven or eight minutes ago. Perhaps she has not been tuned in for the last seven or eight minutes.
—It has not been worth listening to.

—Perhaps Senator Withers is not very interested in the problems of the people who are contracting to sell pools, and I suspect that he is also not terribly concerned about the problems of pool buyers who have suddenly had their prices increased. But maybe he does have a little bit of concern for the employees who are likely to be put off as a result of the loss of orders which will flow from this increase in the middle of a contract. That is the point I am making. I would expect even Senator Withers to have a bit of sympathy for that situation but perhaps I am judging him unfairly and he does not worry about the potential for unemployment.
—Come on.

—Well, perhaps Senator Withers was not aware-Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will be able to show him; I will now refer to the document to which she referred-that there was an estimated 4,500 uncompleted contracts on Budget day. Some of those were up to five months old and all of them would be subject to this anomaly as a result of this schedule coming in and not taking into account the existing contracts. We need not just to accept the Government's palliative that it has reduced this sales tax item from 20 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent because it recognised that it was creating a monstrous anomaly between concrete pools, fibreglass pools and pre-engineered pools. We also need to take into account the problem that arises when a decision is announced and implemented on the same day.

SPEECH.PARA: One further problem arises from that. I have had indicated to me that there may well be difficulties for those who have completed contracts since Budget day and are still waiting for this legislation to be enacted. They did not know whether they had the right to go ahead on the presumption that, despite all the negotiations along the way between the Australian Democrats and the Treasurer ( Mr Keating), this sales tax measure would go ahead. Let us look at it realistically. They had already made one false assumption if on 24 August they went out and sold pools with a 20 per cent sales tax, because the sales tax was subsequently reduced to 7 1/2 per cent. They were in bother if they took that step. If, subsequently, they have taken the step and assumed that the 7 1/2 per cent increase would be passed by the Senate, and if it is not passed by the Senate-if the Liberal and National Parties have the courage of their convictions and are prepared to vote with the Democrats on this measure-they will be in even more serious difficulty, having overcharged for an item for which the sales tax has not been increased. I ask the Government to consider all those factors and reconsider its position. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: — (Victoria) (11.00)-I want to comment briefly on the remarks that have just been made by Senator Jack Evans. During the debate on the second reading of this legislation I indicated that the Opposition would not be supporting any of the amendments that had just been placed on my desk by the Australian Democrats. I indicated that the Opposition had received many representations about the items that have been raised at great length by the Australian Democrats. Sales tax on cosmetics, air-conditioning ducting, swimming pools, berry fruit juices and a range of items that have been raised throughout the debate were the subject of representations to me in person and to many members of the Opposition. When representations were made to me, contrary to the impression that was given by Senator Jack Evans in some of the remarks that he made yesterday, I indicated to those who made the representations that the way to change sales tax anomalies was to make representations to the Government, to explain the difficulties that were being experienced and to point out where some anomalies remain.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly have some sympathy for those who are dealing with air-conditioning ducting because it seemed to me to be a very great change in direction from the present Government's attitude in relation to building materials. Last year we introduced a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax but this Government has introduced a sales tax at an effective 20 per cent. The sorts of matters that were raised with me were understood by the Opposition to present some difficulties. Those of us who have had to deal with sales tax changes over the years in government know that whatever changes are made to the sales tax schedules-for example, changes to the rates, the removal of certain items from exemption and so on-present difficulties. It presents a change in the way in which commodities are dealt with by those who manufacture them or who trade in them.

Whilst no one wishes to see sales tax schedules detrimentally affect their industry, it must be said that, when a government makes amendments to sales tax legislation, as far as the Opposition is concerned, it is the Government's proposal in the Budget; it is the legislation that has been put forward by the Government. As I indicated on at least two occasions yesterday the amendments presented by the Australian Democrats will not be supported by the Opposition. It does not matter how many times Senator Evans gets up and reads the detailed submissions that have been given to him by various groups. Those submissions will not induce the Opposition to change its attitude with regard to sales tax legislation. I would have thought that the debates which were held when the Australian Democrats first introduced amendments to the previous Government's legislation made perfectly clear our attitude to sales tax legislation introduced by a government. That attitude still remains. For that reason-not because we do not see the anomalies, the disadvantages or the difficulties faced by some industries-we will not be supporting any of the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be widely conceded inside the Government as well as outside the Government that there is some anomaly in exempting from sales tax concrete swimming pools, even those which are tile lined. The problem, however, in correcting that anomally is the difficulty in applying the sales tax to the components of those pools because the components of those pools are common to housing and other building in general. It would be very difficult, if not impossible, to effectively apply a sales tax to concrete tile-lined pools because the tax could almost certainly only be applied to the component materials which are common to building in general. Though that is acknowledged it is difficult to correct. A correction of that anomaly which concerns the most expensive type of pools is not the subject of these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments moved by the Australian Democrats seek to remove the sales tax on fibreglass pools or pools with fibreglass liners, some of which are probably as expensive as the unlined concrete pool. If the principle is being argued that , other things being equal, sales tax ought to be directed more heavily towards luxury type goods, then the Australian Democrats' amendments would remove the sales tax on fibreglass pools and liners but would not seek to exempt from sales tax vinyl or other pool liners which are a more down market version. The Government acknowledges that there is some anomaly. These terms are somewhat generalised in that the most expensive pools are exempt from sales tax; the middle range of pools will be subject to sales tax and the bottom range of pools also will be subject to sales tax. We acknowledge that that is a prima facie anomaly. It is very difficult to correct for the reasons I have already stated. The Australian Democrats' amendments would continue to exempt from sales tax the up market pool, remove the sales tax from the middle market pool but leave in place the sales tax on the down market pool. That, in the view of the Government , far from correcting an anomaly leaves a more serious anomaly than that which already exists. For that reason, amongst others, we cannot accept the amendments .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Committee but I will not let pass the remarks of Senator Jack Evans. Like most Australian Democrats he keeps reinventing the wheel. What he said about anomalies in sales tax has been said in this Parliament for some 50 years. Whenever there is a change in sales tax there are winners and losers. If sales tax goes up there are losers; if sales tax goes down there are winners. I do not know that when sales tax comes down those who have a contract necessarily get the benefit of the reduction in sales tax. I would have thought that those who were aware that they might face problems would be able to write into the contracts which they enter into that the contract price would be subject to variations in sales tax. That is a very simple means by which people in the future could--
—Some people do it.

—Some people do it now. It is a matter of normal commercial prudence. I do not want any lectures from Senator Jack Evans about that subject. The other matter, of course, is that Senator Jack Evans has been waxing, waning, complaining and belly-aching because the Opposition will not join with the Australian Democrats. I suppose the belly-aching comes about because the Australian Democrats in this sort of situation realise that within this chamber they have no power at all on their own. The only time they have got any leverage in this chamber is whenever they get into bed with the Government or get into bed with the Opposition. On their own, they are totally irrelevant, nothing but a barnacle on a ship of state. As long as the Government and the Opposition want to do something in this Parliament the Australian Democrats may as well not be in the place. I think that is what is hurting the Australian Democrats today. They came into this place thinking that some of these interesting amendments would be passed. They thought that the Opposition would be dragged along in their cart and that they would be able to go outside and say to all their supporters: 'Look what heroes we are. We have saved you from this sales tax and we have saved you from that'. The Australian Democrats are very brave at going out and picking up single issues. They are very good at thumping their chests and telling all their supporters how good they are. But they are not too good when the real crunch comes. If we had a real crunch like we had in 1974 or 1975, the Australian Democrats would say: 'We cannot pick that one up because we all signed statutory declarations. That is a hard one, for God's sake, and Democrats do not do anything that is hard'. They come in and nit pick around the Government's Budget but do not have the guts to throw it out.

SPEECH.PARA: I can see the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) on the other side of the chamber. I do not know whether he is laughing at me or laughing at somebody else. I trust he is enjoying the debate. I suppose it is the sort of speech he would have made when he was on this side of the House. I have pointed out what is annoying Senator Jack Evans this morning. He has been whingeing, moaning and whining away for the last hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days.

—Two days, I thank my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. Why has he done so? No doubt, it is because he has said, 'Look, we will be able to drag the Opposition along. We will show you all the muscle the Democrats have in this Parliament. We will show you how important we are. Last year we got into bed with the Australian Labor Party and threw out the Government's sales tax amendments'. This year they have not been able to get into bed with the Opposition and throw them out.

—I wish to take a point of order. A few days ago, Mr Chairman, I had reason to praise your chairmanship. I now question it. I ask: What in the name of God is the relevance to this debate of what the Democrats did in 1974 to one clause in a sales tax Bill? With great respect, you have allowed this to go on far longer than you should have. As soon as the honourable senator sits down I will seek the call to tell a few home truths about the gutless Liberal Party members who sit here in Opposition and oppose everything for the sake of opposing it. Mr Chairman, you have allowed this to go far enough. Senator Withers called on the donnybrook. If he wants a donnybrook, he can have one.

—I have been listening to the debate. The subject of the debate was initiated by Senator Jack Evans who made some remarks about the Liberal Party in opposition and Senator Withers in particular. Senator Withers is responding. I think he should keep his remarks fairly brief.

—I have just about concluded. I say to Senator Chipp that I would not have joined in this debate at all but his sanctimonious colleague sitting behind him has been attempting to lecture the Senate all morning on what the Opposition ought to be doing. It is not for him to come in here and tell us what we ought to do. It is no good Senator Chipp flying in here in a rage because I have got under his skin. It is too bad. He can just cop it.

—I will not sit in this place and be lectured by Senator Jack Evans, with all his sanctimonious humbug, about what the Opposition should be doing. The Opposition will do what it wants to do and it will not be dragged along in this place on the coat tails of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of entering this debate which is about levying sales tax on certain items. It is because Senator Withers chose to make a personal attack on my colleague Senator Jack Evans and, for some extraordinary reason, a general vitriolic and bitchy attack on the Australian Democrats that I feel obliged, as the Leader of the Australian Democrats, to say one or two things in our defence. I do not know of any cause for vitriol on Senator Withers's behalf. Let me give him a few home truths. He said the Democrats are nothing in this place unless they work with the Liberal Party of Australia or the Australian Labor Party.
—I did not.
—Did the honourable senator say that or not?
—Yes, I did say that.

—Why is he saying he did not say it? If the honourable senator says things in this place he should stand up like a man and own up to them. He should not crawl away into a little corner just because he was overheard; he should stand up for himself and for whatever he said. Let us look at the Liberal Party and the Democrats. The Democrats comprise five senators out of the 64 senators in the Senate, there being 30 Labor senators and 28 Liberal and National Party senators. That means that if the Liberal Party decides to oppose legislation, and it has opposed almost every piece of contentious legislation for the sake of opposing it, since the Labor Government won office, even matters it proposed when it was in office-I will deal with those in a moment--
—Hypocritical.

—I have never seen such a bunch of hypocrites in my life, yet Senator Withers cast aspersions on the Australian Democrats. I remember the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill. I remember that when the Liberals were in charge the former Minister came to me, as Leader of the Australian Democrats, and said: 'We must have the ABC Bill urgently. Will you please expedite its passage'. I saw my colleagues and they said: 'Yes, we will.' Then the election took place and as soon as the Labor Party was elected it brought in an ABC Bill, almost in identical terms to that of the Liberal Party, in order to implement the recommendations of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. What did the Liberal Party do? It moved an amendment to the second reading saying: 'We will defer this until actions against the ABC for defamation are settled'. That would not have delayed the Bill for too long, only about six or seven years! The Liberal Party members in this place are mindless hypocrites. What sort of vigorous debate did we hear from the Liberal Party members when Mr Fraser's Government introduced retrospective taxation? What vigorous claims were made that it was justified in a sense? Now that the Labor Party is introducing it, we hear a passionate defence on behalf of the Liberal Party that it is immoral and bad. A withholding tax was proposed by the Liberal Party to stop the cash economy in the building industry. What happened as soon as the Labor Party followed up that proposal? Suggestions were made that the regulations would be disallowed and a threat still hangs over the whole matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that five Democrat senators out of 64 have little power by themselves. I have said that on public platforms time and again, but the Liberal Party virtually opposes everything contentious. Its attitude to the assets test is: 'Let's oppose that'. It opposes any little populist issue that comes along, such as the introduction of a means test on people aged over 70 and lump sum tax on superannuation. It opposes every little piddling issue on which it might get a bit of credit. Of course as soon as a matter is introduced in Parliament the Liberal Party magnifies the importance of the Australian Democrats because if the Liberals oppose everything contentious, the passage or non-passage of such legislation will depend on the say-so of the Democrats. I do not mind accepting that responsibility but it is a dreadful way to run a parliament. It is irresponsible when people elected democratically by the electors come into this place and discharge their duties simply by opposing matters that six months before they espoused with some passion. Let us not hear the kind of whinging speeches that we have just heard from Senator Withers, who feels guilty that we have exposed the hypocrisy of the Liberal Party in not opposing sales tax on sun screens in cosmetics. Let it be known that if the Liberals had voted with the Democrats on this issue tyre retreads would not have attracted sales tax. A statement on record by the former Treasurer of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard, stated totally and unequivocally that the Liberal Party would remove sales tax on retread tyres.

TALK.START.PARA: —They changed the Government at the last election.

—I thank Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for that interjection; it is helpful. They changed the government. As it happens, Mr Dawkins, the present Minister for Finance, put in writing that if the Australian Labor Party won government it would also remove the sales tax on tyre retreads. He has not done it. He has broken his promise. We voted today to remove the sales tax on retreaded tyres, but where did every member of the Liberal Party vote? They voted with the Government. They broke the word of Mr Howard. They allow this Government to break a promise. If Senator Withers wants to come in here on a Wednesday when the proceedings are being broadcast and make some cheap capital before his Western Australian audience by attacking one of my colleagues, let him do so, but let him know that each time he does it he is going to be answered .

—We are considering the Schedule to the Bill. I have allowed this debate to continue because of the remarks made by Senator Evans which were responded to by Senator Withers and further responded to by Senator Chipp. Unless Senator Jessop has something new to say in regard to the Schedule, I do not think it would help the Committee if I allowed further debate on this matter .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. Senator Jessop is deliberately and wilfully canvassing your ruling. I do not mind. If he wants to have a full scale donnybrook on this matter, with your permission, let him carry on in this way. We will accommodate him.

—I wish to speak to the point of order. I thought that a good deal of the discussion in the last 10 minutes was marginally, if at all, relevant to the Bill ostensibly under discussion. SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Page 11, Schedule, clause 34, proposed item 123A, leave out all words after ''item'', insert ''by a registered medical practitioner that certifies that the person's hearing is impaired to such an extent that the person is, or is taken to be, moderately deaf''.

The amendment relates to something which is causing a problem and which is likely to be the cause of some quite serious difficulties for a relatively small number of people, whose voice needs to be heard in this House today. The problem arises because the Schedule exempts from sales tax teletext equipment used by the profoundly deaf. The difficulty lies in defining the profoundly deaf. I have received a letter from the Australian Caption Centre which indicates that the decibel loss is not always the deciding factor as to whether a person requires sub-titles for television access. The letter further indicates that it is vital that the range of teletext options all qualify fully for the exemption and not just, as has been suggested, the teletext component of an integrated set. Those are two major concerns for what is, as I said, a relatively small group of people.

There is a problem in that people who do not necessarily qualify technically as profoundly deaf nevertheless require teletext equipment to enable them to enjoy television within their home. For a variety of reasons the requirements of these people might cause problems which do not exist in the homes of normal hearing persons. The difficulties associated with having to raise television volume inordinately high in the case of partially deaf people is a very real problem in some homes. I would have thought that the Government would be very sympathetic to a situation in which social disruption is caused as the result of a person's loss of hearing. This problem could easily be overcome by the introduction of teletext facilities.

I suggest that instead of using the term 'profoundly deaf' we should use the words, and I quote from my amendment, 'by a registered medical practitioner that certifies that the person's hearing is impaired to such an extent that the person is, or is taken to be, moderately deaf'. 'Moderately deaf' is already defined and the Government already uses that definition in regard to invalid pensions, sickness benefits and so on. The Government also accepts doctors' certificates when determining entitlement to invalid pensions, sickness benefits and aid for the disabled. I would have thought that that practice would be a much simpler path to go than to have to get Government authority for this sales tax exemption. I hope that the Government will consider this anomaly in the Schedule.

It might be of interest to honourable senators to know that the Otolaryngological Society of Australia-OLSA-supports my amendment. The Society has indicated that it sees no satisfactory clinical definition that would adequately cover people who require these aids. We need to have an arrangement with some degree of flexibility that will allow a general practitioner to say that in his or her opinion a person needs this sort of aid to enable him to enjoy television.

This is not a great issue. It is not going to tear the country apart. However, it is an issue which I believe should have the compassionate support of the Government. I now feel rather sad that I have to call upon the Opposition in view of its recent outburst in which I was abused for calling for its support on previous amendments. But once more I do call on the Opposition to indicate in the Committee its compassion for this group of people and its support for an amendment which will not mean a great deal to the Government's coffers. My amendment will not break this Government. It will not increase the deficit by billions of dollars. (Quorum formed)

I am sure that the Opposition will win a lot of friends by its constant calling of quorums this morning. Obviously it is a disruptive tactic to save it embarrassment over the debate on these amendments. But it will not save the Opposition or the Government from embarrassment out there in the real world where some of those people who are deaf-not necessarily profoundly deaf, but deaf enough to need this service-require the assistance of teletext equipment in looking at television, to enable them to enjoy their television programs and enable their families to enjoy those television programs. I conclude by appealing to people on both sides of this chamber to support this amendment and enable this part of the Schedule to be returned to the House of Representatives for further consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Evans referred to compassion. This Government has compassion. I think that even the previous Government probably had some compassion. But ultimately, compassion can be no deeper than the purse. An amendment of the type proposed by the Australian Democrats to enable a general practitioner to give certification for exemption is, in the Government's view, too permissive. The clause as it stands provides that eligible persons may receive the exemption on certification by the Director-General of Health or an officer appointed by him. To make available blanket provisions for general practitioners to certify that people are taken to be profoundly deaf would, in the Government's view, be far too permissive and would open up the possibility for avoiding the sales tax on these items to a much greater extent than the Government believes is, on balance, justified or could, under the circumstances, be afforded.

Title agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Robertson-Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I understood that the Minister sought leave to have these matters dealt with together. We would not want to proceed if there is an objection from the Opposition shadow Attorney-General.
