SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to cover the background to this debate, the Senate is debating nine proposals for referendums to alter the Constitution. Five of those proposals have already been the subject of some debate in this Parliament; namely, the proposal for an interchange of powers, the proposal to give the High Court of Australia advisory jurisdiction, the proposal to remove outmoded and expended provisions, the proposal to provide as grounds for a double dissolution the Senate's rejection of an Appropriation Bill and a proposal by Senator Macklin for electors' initiative. Debate on those five proposals has already commenced. I have indicated that the Opposition supports the interchange of powers proposal, the advisory jurisdiction proposal, the removal of outmoded and expended provisions proposal and Senator Rae's proposal dealing with the grounds for a double dissolution if the Senate rejects a Supply Bill. The Opposition opposes Senator Macklin's proposal for a Bill for electors' initiative. That is the background to the debate we are now recommencing.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the debate commenced in May the Government has introduced two new proposals and has discharged its proposal for a fixed-term parliament. We are no longer debating that proposal. However, in lieu of that we are now debating two new proposals by the Government. The first provides for elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate to be held simultaneously and the second would extend from three to four years the maximum term of the House of Representatives . We are debating also two new proposals by private members, one by Senator Hamer to limit the power of the Governor-General to order a double dissolution within three months of the grounds for a double dissolution occurring, and the other by Senator Macklin to break the nexus in determining the size of the Parliament. That nexus requires that the House of Representatives will be, as near as practicable, twice the size of the Senate.

I turn first to the new proposal of the Government which requires that a referendum be held to provide for simultaneous elections for the House of Representatives and half the Senate. In other words, the proposal is that, instead of the Senate's existing fixed term of six years-there is a proposal that it be extended to eight years-it should be two terms of the House of Representatives. That is the proposal included in the Constitution Alteration ( Simultaneous Elections) Bill. It is called 'simultaneous elections', but, as I said, it is described more accurately as the Senate's term being two terms of the House of Representatives.

The Government's other proposal, and it is not an alternative proposal by any means, is that the provision in the Constitution for a maximum term of three years for the House of Representatives and a fixed term of six years for the Senate should be changed to a maximum term of four years for the House of Representatives and eight years for the Senate. The Bills covering these proposals are drafted in such a way that, if the electors of Australia were to agree to both proposals, the maximum term of the House of Representatives would be four years-of course, it could before shortened for one reason or another-and the term of the Senate would not necessarily be eight years but it would be two terms of the House of Representatives. It could be much shorter than eight years or it could be up to eight years.

The Opposition's view is that these two proposals should be dealt with together . We support both proposals. In other words, we support the desired result that there should be a maximum life of four years for the House of Representatives instead of the present three years, but that the term of a senator should be two terms of the House of Representatives. I say that these two proposals should be dealt with together because we believe that that would be the most satisfactory solution to the problem we have under the existing Constitution in that too many elections are held in Australia and there are too many opportunities for elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate to get out of phase. But of course, as we have said repeatedly, we do not believe in a fixed term being determined for the House of Representatives because, under our system of responsible government, that would be an undue fetter on and an impediment to the proper and ordinary workings of our system whereby the Executive is dependent upon the support and goodwill of the House of Representatives. I do not need to debate that issue again.

The Opposition acknowledges that a real problem has existed in Australia for the last 20 years and, in particular, since an early election was held for the House of Representatives in 1963. As a result of more frequent double dissolutions that have occurred in 1974, 1975 and, more recently, in early 1983, the two Houses have got out of phase. There has been and there now is a potential for them to be well and truly out of phase again because, after a double dissolution, half the Senate, the short term senators, may well have to face the electorate well before the expiration of the existing three-year term of the House of Representatives.

Of course, circumstances other than double dissolutions exist for early elections for the House of Representatives. Instability in the House, the Government having a very small majority, losing a majority or other circumstances may well result in an early election being called for the House of Representatives. So, regardless of the problem that arises after a double dissolution, there is a further possibility of the two Houses getting out of phase. Over the last 30 years or so the average life of the House of Representatives has been something less than two and a half years. I think governments in Australia have been faced with the problem of not being able to properly implement their programs because of the frequency of elections.

The argument in support of those two proposals is, basically, to ensure that there will be fewer elections, and to do so by two steps: Firstly, by extending from three to four years the life of the House of Representatives; and, secondly , by ensuring that each time there is an election for the House of Representatives one half of the Senate also goes to the electors, so that there is no scope for a separate election for half the Senate. Of course, the existing provisions of the Constitution enabling a double dissolution to occur if there is a deadlock between the two Houses is preserved by these proposals. It is completely unaffected by the proposals and certainly should not be affected by them. But the two proposals before the chamber today to improve the situation in relation to double dissolutions-the first being Senator Rae's proposal that if, in fact, the Senate rejects an Appropriation Bill or a Supply Bill there is immediate cause for a double dissolution--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill?

—That is right; that is Senator Rae's Bill. That has been the policy of the Opposition for many years. I suggest that that proposal would greatly improve the existing provisions in the Constitution in regard to double dissolutions. The proposal requires three months to elapse before a further rejection of the same Supply Bill by the Senate provides grounds for a double dissolution. Of course during that period the Government could run out of Supply and a very serious situation could arise.

SPEECH.PARA: Another improvement which the Opposition sees to the existing double dissolution provisions is that proposed by Senator Hamer in the Bill we are now debating. He deals with a problem which exists as a result of the present provisions of the Constitution which enable double dissolution Bills to be stockpiled. So although a ground for a double dissolution exists there is no immediate requirement for the Prime Minister to take advantage of that situation and advise an election. In other words the Bills can be stockpiled until such time as the Prime Minister, at some much later date, advises that a double dissolution should be granted by the Governor-General. It may well be that after that period the particular deadlock is not a major problem between the two Houses. In fact the two Houses may be working together quite amicably. It is Senator Hamer's proposal-one with which the Opposition agrees-that that should not provide a ground for a double dissolution; that in fact the power of the Senate would be weakened if a Prime Minister in those circumstances were able to take advantage of a double dissolution situation even though the deadlock between the Houses had gone stale and presumably was not regarded by the Prime Minister as of sufficient importance at the time to have it resolved by a double dissolution.

I now turn to the proposal by Senator Macklin, the Constitution Alteration ( Parliament) Bill. This proposal is properly described as one to break the nexus between the numbers in the Senate and the numbers in the House of Representatives. Section 24 of the Constitution provides:
The House of Representatives shall be composed of members directly chosen by the people . . . and the number of such members shall be, as nearly as practicable, twice the number of the senators.

It is important to emphasise that this nexus does not limit the total numbers of members and senators. It simply provides that there shall be a proportion or ratio between the numbers in this chamber and the numbers in the House of Representatives. In no way does it limit the Parliament in deciding how many senators and members of the House of Representatives there should be. The proposal is an old one. It was originally put forward by Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies in 1965, but it did not go to the people. That same proposal was put forward again by Prime Minister Harold Holt. It was supported by all the parties in the Parliament at the time except the Democratic Labor Party. It was passed by the Parliament and went to a referendum in 1967, but was defeated. However, deciding what would be an appropriate increase in the size of the Parliament, if that were desired, has always been a problem for the Parliament. We are not at this stage debating whether it is desirable to increase the Parliament, but I think it is fair to acknowledge that the provision in the Constitution is an impediment to a reasonable solution to the question if it is thought at any time desirable to increase the numbers in the House of Representatives without increasing the numbers in the Senate.

There is also another very major problem in increasing the numbers of senators because of the system of proportional representation. There is the likelihood of exacerbating a deadlock situation in the Senate if there are even numbers of senators to be elected at any particular election, and if the size of the Senate were increased by a large number of senators at any time we could well run into other problems under the system of proportional representation. So the proposal Senator Macklin has put forward to break this nexus, as it is called-this ratio or proportion between the size of each House-is a practical one. The only problem is whether it may weaken the power and prestige of the Senate. It may well result in the long term in the Senate remaining at its present size of 64 members with, as a result of population growth, a much enlarged House of Representatives.

The proposal contains a provision of a rather technical kind to put a limit on the minimum number of House of Representatives members in ratio to population. Thus we would not have an excessive number of members of the House of Representatives in breach of the limit that is provided. This would result in the ratio of one member representing, I think, 85,000 people. That is a minimum number. The Parliament could decide that there should be a higher ratio and thereby fewer members, but it could not provide for a lower ratio and thereby more members. The proposal is therefore a useful brake on the powers of the Parliament to increase unduly the number of members. I think that is another useful proposal in this Bill.

The Opposition does not believe that the Senate's power and prestige would be affected if the ratio between the Senate and the House of Representatives were removed. We believe that the Senate now has, by its own efforts, by the exercise of its undoubted very wide powers and its very effective use of the committee system, achieved a status in Australia which is not likely to be affected by the breaking of this nexus. Therefore the Opposition will support this proposal.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I think that what I have said covers the nine proposals that are before us. I have indicated the Opposition's attitude to all of them. In conclusion I simply return to the ones that are of perhaps the greatest significance-that is the proposal for simultaneous elections and the proposal to increase the maximum term of the House of Representatives to four years instead of the present three. Many of the other proposals are useful but they are not of any great moment. The proposals dealing with the interchange of powers, the advisory opinions of the High Court of Australia and the removal of outmoded provisions are I think of some practical use but they would certainly not on their own justify holding a referendum. We believe that Senator Peter Rae 's proposal is very important to make sure that there would be a double dissolution if the Senate exercised its powers at any stage to reject a Supply or an Appropriation Bill. As to the argument that such a proposal would break the nexus, again I simply say that we see it as a useful and practical proposal, but certainly not one which would justify a constitutional amendment on its own. Nevertheless, if there is to be a referendum held because of the importance of determining the life of the Parliament and the question of simultaneous elections, the opportunity should be taken to put to the people a number of these other proposals.

The only proposal which the Opposition is strongly opposed to is the Australian Democrats' other Bill. I have already put down the reasons for our position on the Constitutional Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. It provides for a number of electors to be able to sign a petition for a particular proposal to be put to a referendum, not necessarily a constitutional amendment, but any major proposal. We believe that that is so contrary to our system of parliamentary democracy that it should be opposed and rejected both by the Parliament and the people. Otherwise we think that there are a number of useful proposals in this package of Bills to amend the Constitution. Undoubtedly, the ones that justify the holding and expense of a referendum are those Bills designed to extend the maximum life of the House of Representatives from three to four years and to provide for the terms of senators to equal two terms of the House of Representatives. As I have said, the Opposition will support eight of the nine Bills. We believe they justify a decision of the people at a referendum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Australian Democrats will vote in support of all nine Constitution alteration Bills currently before the Senate. We do so on the basis of the principle that we think that the Australian electors ought to have the opportunity of expressing their views on these matters. However, that should not be taken to mean that in the actual campaign itself we will be supporting all nine items if they went to the people. In practical terms only those Constitution amendment Bills which the Government itself supports will go to the people, regardless of whether the Bills are passed in this House. I will comment generally on each of the items before us today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill are placed here in substitution for the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill which the Government had originally proposed. The Australian Democrats supported very strongly the fixed term parliaments Bill. We believed it would have provided a major reform to the Australian Constitution and enabled us to look forward to a settled period in relation to the election of parliaments well into the future. The simultaneous elections Bill and the parliamentary terms Bill do not go to the heart of the matters that have been of constitutional debate in this country since 1975. They merely tinker with the surrounds to that problem, but in no way come forward with a solution.

The arguments that have been proposed for the simultaneous election Bill are well known. The arguments against it are equally well known. In many ways the item has been rehearsed before. However, when one looks at the discussions on simultaneous elections referenda that we have had before, one cannot but be taken with the extraordinarily emotive arguments both for and against that were provided in the pamphlets distributed to the citizens of Australia. I believe it is a pity that such arguments are put in written material distributed to citizens when far more weighty arguments both for and against exist.

In relation to the simultaneous elections Bill I think there is a problem. That problem surrounds the contentions made about whether we will have fewer or more elections. I believe there are good arguments on both sides of that issue. I do not think it can be adequately proven that we will have either more or less elections if we do away with the notion of a fixed term. Essentially, this Bill leaves untouched the ability of government. But there is one argument that might suggest, in terms of the Senate at least, that we will be taking away what one might call quasi-fixed terms for the Senate. In other words, unless the Government in the House of Representatives, by judicious choice of Bills, actually manages to get the Senate to reject a Bill twice under the constitutional provisions which are available currently for a double dissolution , the Senate will have a fixed term. Essentially, if this Bill is passed by the people it will take away that element of a fixed term that is currently provided by the Constitution. That, I believe, could be seen in many ways to be a retrograde step. I think it is for this reason that the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) last year said very clearly that the Australian Labor Party would not have a bar of simultaneous elections without a fixed term. That is my position now.

I do not believe that by taking up the fixed term on its own we will do anything to enhance the constitutionality of the proceedings of Parliament. I think we would give to Prime Ministers an additional power they do not currently have. I hope that in the debate in the community we might get down to that item in a fairly solid way. I merely indicate at the moment some of the thoughts that the Democrats have and will be putting forward at that time. The four-year terms proposal has been canvassed and been the subject of referenda in the New South Wales where it was overwhelmingly carried. I do not know whether there is such support throughout the community. I think some reasonable arguments are put forward for this. Certainly, when one looks at the progression of parliamentary business in this place and in the other place, one sees that there could be a very good argument for a four-term to enable us to have a more rational movement throughout the period of a government's life.

On the other hand, one could very well argue that four years of bad government is not necessarily anything better than, and indeed might be worse than, three years of bad government. So I think there are problems. I believe that the accountability aspect tells against the four-year term. I think that the proposal put forward by Senator Mason in the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill would be a better way of coping with that problem. I have never felt that elections on a three-year basis were a disadvantage to Australia. I for one hold firmly to the notion that the constant input from the people at regular intervals-I think that three years is adequate-is a good thing. But I acknowledge the problems that governments have in legislative programs. I also acknowledge that they could be solved by adopting a four-year term. They cannot be solved by the current three-year term unless it is fixed. In essence, my response to the simultaneous elections and the four-year term proposals is that they are a very poor substitute for the very rigorous and strong reform which would have come from a fixed term. I believe that they create many problems, and possibly they will create as many problems as they are likely to solve.

As regards the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill, I spoke on those Bills when they were before the Senate in another debate, as I did in relation to Senator Mason's Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative ) Bill.

I turn to the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill, presented by Senator Peter Rae on behalf of the Opposition, and to the suggestion of an immediate simultaneous dissolution of both Houses if the Senate rejects Supply. I believe that this would tip the balance away from the House of Representatives very strongly in favour of the Senate. In seeking constitutional reform, I do not believe that one should seek to upset that balance to such an extent. Personally, I shall be opposing that Bill in the campaign. However, at this particular time, the Australian Democrats will support its passage through the Senate to allow the people to make their decision if the Government passes the Bill through the House of Representatives.

The Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill, presented by Senator Hamer, is a good attempt at coming to grips with the problems we have seen in the last couple of double dissolutions of putting Bills on the shelf to be used at a time convenient to the Prime Minister. The election issue in March was a very good example of that, when the Bills taken up, the sales tax Bills, had been left over not from the previous Budget but from the Budget of the year before, and they had not even been presented by the Government itself in its following Budget. They were sitting on the shelf, and they were the subject of some interesting correspondence between the Governor-General and the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. However, I think that the upshot of that correspondence must be that the situation in Australia is now clear: The Government is indeed entitled, once it has a double dissolution Bill, to put it on the shelf and to use it at any time, at its convenience, provided that it falls within the six months bar prior to an election.

We believe that the idea of having that used within three months goes some way towards putting pressure on the Government to ask whether this is really a serious Bill, a Bill on which the Government really wants to go to the people, a Bill which is so serious as to disrupt the government of this country. I believe that it is a fair thing to say that if the Government has not used it within three months it cannot be all that serious. There would be ways in which the Government could get around this provision. Nevertheless, the manipulation of this provision ought not to be a reason for opposing it. It is a step in the right direction. It is not the ultimate solution, but inasmuch as it is a reform that would benefit in some way the operation between the two Houses, it would have our support.

I do not propose to speak now to the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill which I introduced at the second reading stage, simply because there has not been a chance for other senators to comment on that. My second reading speech is in Hansard. If there is any further debate at the Committee stage, I would be quite happy to discuss any of the issues rasied there.

As regards these Bills in general, we believe that it ought to be possible for the Government to put nine Bills to the people. We do not agree with the comments that have been made by the Attorney-General that by putting any more than a small number, electors will be confused. Frankly, I think that we ought to give the electors credit for the ability to sift through the individual proposals, be they four or nine, and make up their own minds about these issues. Looking back at the history of multiple referenda, one finds that there is no basis for the assertion that people are confused or that they vote en bloc for all of the proposals or against all of them. Historically, that is not so. The Australian electors have been very astute at picking their way through. For example, they have defeated items quite strongly on the same day as they have supported others very strongly. We should beware of those patronising types of arguments that suggest that we ought not to put up all these various issues to the people because they might be confused. Paternalistic statements such as that do not enhance the democratic process. I think that people are quite able to distinguish between nine issues, as they would be able to distinguish between four.

Lastly, I comment on Senator Durack's contribution. As regards the nexus Bill that I introduced, we introduced that because of our approach to the recent parliamentary report which recommended an increase in the numbers in this place and in the House of Representatives. We believe that there is not a case for increasing the numbers in the Senate at this time. Therefore, we believe that breaking the nexus would give us at least the opportunity for some reasonable growth in the House of Representatives when that is demanded by a variety of other matters. I point to the current situation in Victoria. There will have to be a redistribution there before the next election, and one seat in the House of Representatives will be lost to that State. In my own State of Queensland there will also have to be a redistribution because we shall gain one seat. The Democrats believe that it is at times such as that that it would be appropriate to have a small increase in the numbers in the House of Representatives so as to avoid the situation of the loss of a seat to a State.

The population is growing more each year, and there could be a moderate increase in the House of Representatives when so warranted by circumstances such as States getting out of kilter with one another and, therefore, carrying over the constitutional requirements. However, at present we do not believe that there can be an argument sustained that would require that there be an increase in the number of senators and in the numbers in the House of Representatives. We would therefore oppose such an increase at present. We believe that, if the Government is looking at that item, it could look at increasing the numbers in the House of Representatives by two or three, or by whatever is required to overcome the problems of Victoria and Queensland.

On that particular item, there is an issue which weighs fairly heavily with the Australian Democrats because of our support for the proportional representation system. The proposal to increase to an even number the number of senators elected at the same time as each House of Representatives election is held would , as Senator Durack pointed out, provide a far greater chance of the Government and the Opposition in the Senate having equal numbers. The reason for that is that when six senators go to the people, half of those positions can be gained by 43 per cent of the vote. If there is an odd number, to gain a majority any party needs a majority of electors supporting it. So using an even number in a proportional representation system will in fact cork the possibility of bringing the proportional representation method into disrepute. We believe that method has served this country well since it was introduced into the Senate in 1949 and we would be loath to support propositions which were in any way damaging to the continued acceptance of proportional representation in this country or to the spread of it.

The only alternative, then, in terms of an increase is to do what was done in 1949 when State representation went from six senators to 10 senators, which gave an odd number at a half Senate election. To go from the current number of 10 to the next odd half-term number, 14, would require approximately 28 additional members in the House of Representatives. I think that is a ludicrous proposition . So really we are in a very difficult situation in trying to maintain a variety of principles. It seems to us that the next move probably ought to be the breaking of the nexus to enable the Senate to maintain its numbers now and so that some time in the future, when it seems necessary to do so, the Senate itself can increase its representation to 14 from each State.

I would like to mention one other item that has been raised with me and which did not become part of my Bill. I refer to Territory representation in the Senate. I believe that there ought to be a ceiling on the number of representatives allowed into this place from the Territories. I believe an adequate ceiling would be provided by saying that the maximum number any Territory could have is that number currently available for any State. The reason I suggest that as a maximum number is that at some stage in the future we could have a Territory in which the number of electors is larger than the number of electors in one of the original States and it would seem entirely inappropriate to have a constitutional bar to that particular Territory having an equal number of representatives at that stage, if it still remained a Territory and did not become a State.

I also believe that at some stage in the future, when Territories become States , we will need a fairly detailed debate about Senate representation for those new States. I am personally of the belief that any new States that come into being in Australia by the provisions which are currently contained within our Constitution, ought never to be regarded as second class States. I do not believe that we ought to set up in this country a system of States that are considered to be original States and then a system of new States. Therefore, I am of the belief that when new States are created, as hopefully they will be in the future, those States should have equal representation with the original States already represented in this place, and therefore that all States ought to be represented in the States House on an equal basis. To have greater and lesser States would only get us into a problem in the long term, which would require a constitutional stage to rectify, of giving equal rights to each State regardless of its population-as was done, of course, at Federation.

But that is a debate for another time, although certainly that time might not be far away. I notice that Senator Robertson, a senator for the Northern Territory, is in the House. The Northern Territory is moving towards Statehood so that issue is of concern to the Territory even now. I think as it gets closer to full Statehood it will become an issue of more and more concern. I simply reiterate that the Australian Democrats support the principle that these issues ought to go to the people for their deliberation and their deliberative vote. We will vote in support of each of these issues. However in the debate which will take place in the electorate itself we will have a variety of views on these matters and we will be urging not a straight vote down the ticket but that people look at each issue. We will be putting forward views on a number of these issues, urging the people to support some and oppose others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering nine Bills at the moment, the purpose of which is to alter the Constitution. It is reasonable to remind people at this time that when Federation was contemplated and agreed upon, the founding fathers of this country very wisely set up a Constitution which would protect the interests of those States which were sovereign States before Federation. Of course, the whole object of the agreement of the States at that time was that the Senate be established, giving the States equal representation. So any threat to the authority and power of the Senate must be greeted with some concern by the people of Australia. On occasions in the past referenda items have been referred to the people but the majority of them have been rejected for one reason or another. In order to achieve the objective of constitutional alteration, a majority of the electors in the majority of States must agree to the proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I say categorically that I am opposed to the first of these measures-the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill-as I have been on previous occasions. I have consistently held the view that this would be a threat to the authority of the Senate. I have maintained that view on two previous occasions and I intend to do so again on this occasion. I will talk about that a little more in a moment.

In regard to the second measure-the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill-I do agree that the parliamentary term should be extended to four years. I have some concern about extending the term of a senator for eight years , because I think that for a lot of these people on the Government side, eight years is far too long. It might be an idea, if that is approved, to suggest that a senator's term be restricted to two terms, totalling 16 years. We might get a few more refreshing views in this place. So I have no real objection to that measure.

As far as the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill 1983 is concerned, I suppose that this proposition is reasonable, although I suggest that in the unhappy event of Australia being ruled by a socialist Federal government and socialist goverments in every State of the Commonwealth, this could pose a threat because manipulation could be pursued which would not be in the best interests of the Senate. I do not want to pursue that because it is a most unlikely situation that would be disastrous for Australia anyway. But let us just put that in our minds. I say to anybody who is interested that that situation could occur. I have some doubts about that but I am not going to be dogmatic as far as that Bill is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it would be a danger to the Senate. You meant to the country, I think.

—To the country, yes, but it could be a threat to the Senate too because in collaboration a Federal socialist government and State socialist governments could manipulate things in a way that only the socialists could do. Of course, the converse is equally true: If there were a Federal Liberal government and State Liberal-National Party governments there would be no fear as far as the electorate is concerned. The next Bill on the Notice Paper is the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill. I am opposed to that and I will talk about my major objections in more detail in a few moments. The Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill is sensible and I support it. I cannot support the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. I could go along with the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill because Senator Peter Rae has given that a lot of thought and I believe it is a sensible measure. As far as breaking the nexus is concerned, the people faced that proposition in 1967 and rejected it. I am not so sure that I could not agree with that at the moment. I have my reservations about it and I will make up my mind in due time.
—Which one is that?
—The breaking of the nexus. Some people say that it poses another threat to the Senate because the object-
—We will get run over by the people from Sydney and Melbourne.

—I was just going to say that the founding fathers, again in their wisdom, said that the Senate should be approximately half the size of the House of Representatives. I know that these days the Senate is quite capable of dealing with the House of Representatives when we need to but, nevertheless, some people in Australia in the small States might have reservations about that. I have no objection to Senator Hamer's Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking against the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill I suppose I could do no better than to refresh honourable senators' memories on what happened in 1974. Then, of course, the voters in the smaller States- Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania-were strongly against the proposal. I remember that we were in government when the proposal was resubmitted. At that time objections against the proposal were strongly levelled by the State Liberal and National party Premiers, Sir Charles Court, Mr Hamer and Mr Bjelke-Petersen. I recall that at that time the late Sir Thomas Playford, although he had retired from active political life, emerged quietly but forcefully to suggest that the holding of simultaneous elections was an exercise in deception and could jeopardise the authority and the integrity of the Senate to the disadvantage of the smaller States. I can put it no better than did my colleague Senator Withers at that time. This is what he said in 1974 , but I believe he said it with conviction and meant every word he said:
I believe that this Bill is nothing but an exercise in deception in which the Government is deliberately attempting to deceive the people of Australia.
He was referring to the Whitlam Government. He continued:

When this Bill was called on for debate in the House of Representatives it was said that the title of the Bill was a fraud. In fact it was said there also that the title did not reflect in any way the intent of the Bill.
I recall that my former colleague Sir Phillip Lynch also said:
There is no constitutional restraint to the holding of simultaneous elections for both Houses of the Australian Parliament.
When the question was posed 'What is meant by saying it is the wrong way to achieve it?', he said:

Its adoption would impair the proper functioning of the bicameral system of government. Tying the Senate to the House of Representatives in the manner proposed by the Bill would weaken its independence. In short the Constitution ( Simultaneous Elections) Bill is not simply unnecessary but also is cunningly deceptive in its intent.
I think that those words are as true today as they were in 1974 and 1977. For those reasons I oppose the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill .

I suggest also that the Constitutional Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill is not in the best interests of the people of Australia and not in the best interests of this Parliament. There have been a number of debates on this subject. I refer to the debate held at the Australian Constitutional Convention in Perth in July 1978. At page 33 of the record of those debates Mr Knox is reported to have said, among other things:

There may well be many people in this country who think that the seeking of advisory opinions from the High Court would be similar to that procedure which exists in relation to the Privy Council. Of course, those of us who have had some experience know that the situation is quite different. The important question is, what is the status of these opinions. Indeed, as far as the opinions of the High Court would be concerned their status could be very powerful indeed. I would imagine that once these were approved then the work of the High Court would increase enormously, because there would be all sorts of avenues to take advantage of to seek these advisory opinions.
He went on to say:

While the seeking of advisory opinions may seem rather academic to lawyers, to the parliamentarians there should be a different attitude. The legislatures of this country should be allowed to try to make the changes that they think are desirable, even flying in the face of opinions they might have from various sources that they might not be successful. Indeed, it would be a very bad and sad day for the various legislatures if the opinions from the High Court were thrust between them and those who wanted to see changes made in the legislation.
I believe that was a very sensible comment. But earlier this year at the Australian Constitutional Convention in Adelaide Mr Doumany from Queensland made the following points:

First, advisory opinions are of necessity expressed in general terms and not related to specific situations. Our whole judicial tradition is directed towards examining the legality of specific situations. The Judiciary is now, in effect, being asked to act as legislators-a move against the separation of powers inherent in our system.

Secondly, because our judicial system considers matters on a relatively narrow frame, questions of fact do influence the decisions which are made. How then is a court supposed to give authoritative pronouncements on circumstances which will be nothing more than the speculations of the persons going before the court ?

Thirdly, sufficient mechanisms already exist for challenges to the constitutional validity of specific Acts to be made. These legal challenges, however, are only made after the necessary political decisions have been made. It can be argued that this proposal is nothing more than an attempt to use the law to overcome an inability to succeed in political arguments.

Fourthly, from a cynical point of view, the proposal can be regarded as nothing more than an attempt to place greater powers in the hands of the Commonwealth Government by encouraging the High Court to write wide-ranging general advisory opinions. This view is not necessarily all that cynical if one has regard to the proposals in section 77A (1) (d). The suggestion that the Executive Government would have an ability to obtain a High Court ruling on the legality of any proposed treaty prior to even signing the treaty, let alone ratifying it, and let alone legislating on it, fills me with complete horror.

Fifthly, the adoption of this principle would also require the High Court to develop new rules of stare decisis and precedent, or are we to adopt a new rule to see if the High Court gives a general advisory opinion in favour of a particular action, then for ever and a day no challenge can be mounted against Commonwealth activity? This, of course, would be ludicrous for any practical person but, nevertheless, this would seem to be inherent in the proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would save a lot of money and a lot of wasted time, would it not?

—I think that we are abrogating our responsibility if we say that to the High Court. We have enough lawyers in this place with differing views. Sometimes in the course of debate we can elucidate some sense out of them. When the Parliament of Australia is prepared to hand over these matters to the High Court of Australia I think it is a sorry day. I think it is an indictment on people like Senator Georges, for whom I have a great regard. I believe his opinion would be equally as valid and equally as sensible as a decision of the High Court.
—You are still going to get my opinion.
—I always value Senator Georges's opinion although sometimes I disagree with it. Most of the time I disagree with his opinions but nevertheless I respect what he has to say. Mr Doumany continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Sixthly, the proposal also ignores the rights of interested litigants to appear to argue a particular point of view.
I am sure Senator Georges would not like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that? Say that again.
—I will say that again. Mr Doumany stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Sixthly, the proposal also ignores the rights of interested litigants to appear to argue a particular point of view. Who is to say who will be affected by a particular advisory opinion by the High Court? Yet from the proposal, the only persons likely to appear when advisory matters are argued will be Governments, both Commonwealth and State. One can readily anticipate the High Court will be encouraged to make pronouncements upon matters which will be of vital concern to many interested parties, but that these parties will only become aware of their rights being affected after the decision is made. Where, therefore, is there any justice in that proposal?
It goes on. The seventh point he made is as follows:

. . . I note already that the proposal suggests that States should have a right of approaching the High Court for advisory opinions. It would strike me that even if you accept the principle of advisory opinions, the last thing the States would do would be to seek to approach the High Court directly for an opinion for , in doing so, they would be casting grave aspersions on the legal abilities on their Supreme Court, particularly of their Full Courts. From this point of view, the proposal can be looked at as a further attempt to downgrade the judicial standing of State Supreme Courts.

Finally, I make the point as to just exactly what the Commonwealth is trying to achieve with this proposal. The Commonwealth already has available to it the best legal advisers in Australia that money can buy. Apparently, these advisers are no longer considered to be able to render appropriate advice to the Commonwealth about actions which it proposes to undertake. Apparently the judges of the High Court are now also to be converted into Commonwealth legal advisers as well.
He went on to say:

The High Court should remain independent and impartial, carrying out its duties of interpreting Commonwealth Constitution and the laws of the land in a way that will ensure that all parties not only do, but believe they do, obtain justice when they appear before the court.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 1.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the extraordinary and unsatisfactory report submitted to the New South Wales Premier , Mr Wran, by the Police Commissioner, Mr Abbott. In that report it is stated that information on early release of prisoners was obtained by telephone taps by Commonwealth Police during surveillance of 'drug traffickers involved in international drug smuggling who by covert means had asociated themselves with the Minister of the Crown responsible for the early release of prisoners'. I refer to the various passages in the report, which indicate that information on the allegations about early release had to be restricted to avoid compromising sources of information about international illegal drug trafficking. I also refer to the inconclusive nature of the report, as it is described by Commissioner Abbott. I ask the Minister: Does not the apparent close relationship between international drug running and elements of the New South Wales State Administration make the matter of early release of prisoners one of Commonwealth concern and responsibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the text of the report made by Mr Abbott to the New South Wales Government. I am familiar, of course, with the general nature of the matters which Senator Chaney has raised. I have also seen the transcripts of the tapes in question which set the initial hares running. So I am not relying solely on second hand information from police commissioners or anyone else in the answer I now give. Mr Abbott's statement that the evidence in relation to the New South Wales Minister was inconclusive is a judgment that I share on the basis of my reading of the transcript of the tapes in question. On that material , the evidence is unquestionably inconclusive. Certainly it is suggestive of further lines of inquiry, but it is not in itself more than that.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I make in relation to the matters raised by Senator Chaney is that it is a matter for very nice and delicate judgment by law enforcement officers as to how far to pursue investigations into matters where there is a very real risk of prejudicing highly sensitive drug law enforcement operations in circumstances where sources may be put at risk. There was a series of exchanges between Commissioner Grey and Commissioner Abbott on that subject. From the material I have seen, I think that the respective commissioners well understood each other's position. I think it would not be appropriate for the Commonwealth Government or anyone else to second guess the judgment that was manifestly finally reached by Mr Abbott, clearly in consultation with Commissioner Grey, on that aspect of the proceeding.

In regard to the third point raised by Senator Chaney as to whether the circumstances are such as to make the matter one of Commonwealth concern, yes, of course, it is a matter for Commonwealth concern in the general policy sense in relation to the condition of law enforcement in this country, and we make no bones about that. But equally clearly the particular matters of criminal investigation that are involved in this case do not in any way, shape or fashion raise questions of possible breaches of Commonwealth law. I have looked very carefully at this aspect to satisfy myself personally that that is so, and I am satisfied. I repeat, as a result of all that, the statement that I made when this matter first arose that there was nothing more that the Commonwealth could reasonably have done than what it did do-that is, to pass the information over to the appropriate authorities in New South Wales. Taking into account the factors I mentioned then and which I mentioned again this morning, the Commonwealth must as a result be in the position of accepting the results of that New South Wales investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Attorney-General 's agreement that there are matters of concern in the general policy sense and his earlier statement that what was put before the New South Wales Government by the Commonwealth suggests further lines of inquiry, is it not a fact that further lines of inquiry have been followed, leading to the Abbott report? Is it not also a fact that public statements, including those made over a matter of days by Professor Tony Vinson, have suggested that that inquiry was not and could not be adequate? I ask the Attorney-General: In light of that public statement by a responsible citizen of high reputation, is he not concerned that an inadequate inquiry has been mounted in these important matters?

—When I referred to further lines of inquiry being suggested by the primary evidence arising from the telephone taps, I was referring to an inquiry by means of interviews and other communications with individuals of the kind that clearly did take place in the course of the New South Wales Police investigation. That inquiry has been conducted to the satisfaction of the Commissioner of the New South Wales Police, who, I believe, on all the evidence available to me, is a man of unquestioned probity and integrity. Under all the circumstances I believe that little further could be achieved in this matter, given the matters to which Mr Abbott referred in his report in relation to the possible prejudice of drug law enforcement operations and the putting at risk of the position of informers. I believe that nothing could be further pursued by an inquiry of the kind to which Senator Chaney now refers. To the extent that there might be further argument about some other avenues of inquiry appropriately being pursued within New South Wales in relation to related matters, if not this one, then, properly speaking, that is a matter for the New South Wales authorities, as I imagine the principles of federalism that appear to be so dear to the hearts of the Opposition would lead the Leader of the Opposition to accept.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the latest survey of industrial trends conducted by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Westpac Banking Corporation? If so, can the Minister say whether there are significant differences between the States in respect of their general business situations? What information, if any, does the Minister have on expected levels of output and employment in the individual States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the most recent Westpac-Confederation of Australian Industry survey. Perhaps I should explain the way in which the figures are presented. The figures on the relevant page record the percentage of respondents who expect an improvement in various economic indicators, minus those who expect a decline in the economic indicators. So the more pessimistic the outlook, the greater the final minus or, alternatively, the lower the final positive figure. In this survey of the general business situation a plus figure of only 13 per cent of the respondents in Queensland expect an improvement. This is by far the lowest expectation of any mainland State and is much less than half of the national figure of 31 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the other matters to which Senator Maguire referred-employment and output both current and expected-the same pattern applies, with one minor exception. In the current quarter expectations of employment Queensland recorded a minus figure of 54 per cent, against a national figure of minus 29 per cent. Again, Queensland had by far the highest minus figure of all the mainland States . Current business expectations in regard to the level of unemployment in Queensland are far more pessimistic than in any other mainland State. The same position applies to expectations of future employment in that Queensland is by far the most pessimistic. Queensland employers, according to the Westpac- Confederation of Australia Industry survey, are by far the most pessimistic of employers in the mainland States and much more pessimistic than in Australia as a whole, which follows inevitably. It is anticipated by all respondents to the survey other than Queensland that output will increase in all other mainland States by anything from 21 per cent in New South Wales and Victoria to 50 per cent in Western Australia. In Queensland, however, the respondents to the survey , who are mostly business people, expect output to decline by 4 per cent. So, on all these current important economic indicators of general business outlook, the view on employment, both current and expected, and output, both current and expected, and the view of the prospects of the Quensland economy, held by the Queensland business community I stress, because it is the business community which is respondent to this survey, is not only very pessimistic but also far more pessimistic than any other mainland State and, ipso facto, far more pessimistic than the expectations of business regarding those crucial economic indicators in the nation as a whole.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES POLICE REPORT: DRUG SMUGGLING

TALK.START.PARA: —I also direct a question to the Attorney-General both in his own capacity and as the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. I also refer to the report of Commissioner Abbott to the New South Wales Government. I ask the Attorney: Has the investigation into the international drug smuggling ring referred to in the report and described as an important one been completed? If so, have any charges been laid? If it has not been completed and is still continuing, when is it likely to conclude?

—My understanding is that the investigation is certainly not completed. It is an on-going one. I am not in a position to give a precise indication as to when it is expected it will wind up in whole or part. I will seek further information from the Special Minister of State and make it available to the shadow Attorney-General.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked whether any charges have been laid?
