QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS: REPATRIATION BENEFITS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs seen a recent Press release by the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Aboriginal and Island Affairs, Mr Val Bird, in which he claims credit on behalf of his Government-I like his cheek-for this Government's Budget decision to compensate Torres Strait Island ex-servicemen for underpayment during World War II.
—What a cheek.

—It is a cheek because I remember asking questions on this matter on two occasions early in the piece. Has the Queensland Government, Mr Bird or his Department made any representations since the Labor Government came to power in March this year in support of retrospective payments of disability pensions? Does the Minister have any comment on Mr Bird's warning to these ex- servicemen not to waste time seeking advice from the National Aboriginal Conference, or any other body, or, for that matter, anyone?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to Mr Bird's comments and Press statement. For sheer effrontery, hypocrisy, distortion and self-adulation I think it takes the prize of the year. In point of fact, of course, the Queensland Government takes the prize as being the worst government in Australia , particularly as it is represented by Ministers who make such false statements in respect of matters of a Federal nature which the Labor Government has sought to rectify. We have been shown again that members of the Queensland Government can lie to their constituents in such a glib way and in a way which does no credit to their public office.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. It has been alleged that members of the Queensland Government lied to their constituents. That term is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—Under standing order 418 I ask the Minister to withdraw that statement.
—In deference to you, Mr President, I withdraw. However, can I say-
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I ask that the withdrawal be unconditional.
—The Minister has undertaken to withdraw the remark.

—I withdraw the statement. However, can I say that Mr Bird and, in fact, many of his fellow Ministers are very careless in the way in which they handle the truth. Perhaps Senator Chaney may reflect on what I have to say when I read to him what was said in the Press statement which Mr Bird has circulated in the electorate of Cook in which Torres Strait Islanders are enrolled. I would have thought that Senator Chaney would not be interested in defending the actions of a National Party Minister, having regard to the disgraceful conduct of that government in Queensland and of his own political party.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Standing Orders prohibit the debating of questions during Question Time. I would ask you to ask the Minister to confine his answer. If the Minister wishes to make a statement on this matter or any other matter, I would suggest it be made after Question Time.
—There is no point of order.

—Twice this year Senator Georges has raised with me the question of the underpayment to Torres Strait Islanders during World War II. In reply to Senator Georges I want to draw the attention of the Senate to what Mr Bird is reported as saying in a Press statement dated 25 August. That document stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Aboriginal and Island Affairs Minister, Mr Val Bird, today welcomed the news that, at long last, the Queensland Government's claims on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Ex-Servicemen for retrospectivity on repatriation benefits had been recognised.

'As a result of representations by my Department, Torres Strait Light Infantry Battalion Ex-Servicemen had their repatriation benefits increased to the equivalent . . . of all Australian ex-servicemen from July 1, . . . 1963' Mr Bird said.
Mr President, that statement is a lie. Those comments show just how desperate he and his Party are in the current election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would ask the Minister to use a term other than the one he has used bearing in mind standing order 418.

—It is an untruth, Mr President. Of course, the Press statement has been issued by an organisation called the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement, the director of which has been selected by the National Party to contest the State elections. Consequently that person, Mr Killoran, is equally culpable in the distortion and attempt to influence the voting of people in the Torres Strait area. The facts are, of course, that this matter was first raised with me as a result of an article that was written in 1980 and which was brought to my attention a few weeks after I assumed office as Minister by a Mr Hall who was a research student at the Australian National University.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Surely an explanation like this should be and could be made after Question Time.
—There is no point of order. The Minister is responding to a question asked by Senator Georges. However, I would ask the Minister to confine his remarks to the honourable senator's actual question.

—I was asked whether Mr Bird's statement is relevant. I am attempting to answer the question asked by Senator Georges. I took the initiative when this matter was drawn to my attention. In 1942 action was taken by the War Cabinet which denied certain benefits to those who served during World War II. I took the matter to the Cabinet. I had a responsibility, because of the questions raised with me by Senator Georges and other Labor representatives of north Queensland, to have this matter dealt with in the Budget presented to the Parliament in August of this year. The rectification of repatriation benefits was agreed to by the Government. It is interesting that when this article was first written back in 1980, the then Minister for Veterans ' Affairs, Mr Adermann, who is a member of the National Party of Australia, failed to act on this issue. I acted on the basis of remedying a long-standing issue affecting the rights of the Torres Strait Islanders. I find it distasteful and I take umbrage at the fact that a Minister of the Queensland Government should attempt to take credit for that initiative.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Georges asked a second question about the National Aboriginal Conference. In the Press statement issued by Mr Bird he asked the Torres Strait Islanders not to avail themselves of advice from the National Aboriginal Conference. That is quite contrary to the Press statement I issued on 24 August, in which I said I had designated that organisation for the purpose of disseminating information from the Government and collecting information for the Torres Strait Islanders. In point of fact, Minister Bird has created confusion and attempted to take credit for an action that is not within his province but in fact rests with the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to table the document to which he referred.
—I am quite happy to do so. I hope the Opposition will disown it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I refer to an article appearing in this week's National Times which disclosed that the Queensland Ombudsman has found irregularities involving Queensland Government Ministers, in particular Mr Russ Hinze, in development approvals for a rainforest area in the Daintree district of north Queensland, which is considered by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to be one of the most important environmentally in the world. Is it a fact that the Queensland Government reversed the decisions of the local council and the Local Government Court, which had refused rezoning, and directed the Douglas Shire Council to allow residential development of the land? What action, if any, will the Australian Government now take to protect the conservation value of this unique area against what appears to be a clear conspiracy to destroy it for monetary gain?

—I am sure that the honourable senator who asked the question is aware of and has confidence in the record of the Labor Government with regard to the protection of the environment. I do not know anything about the detailed matters he raised. The brief I have from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment does not cover that topic. I will refer the specific matter of the Daintree River area and the allegations in the National Times to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and seek a response for Senator Missen.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, concerns the closing down in Queensland next year of the Acacia Ridge plant of General Motors-Holden's Ltd. I ask: How many jobs will be transferred to South Australia as a result of last Friday's announcement? What will be the future role of the General Motors-Holden's plant at Woodville in South Australia ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The announced closure by General Motors-Holden's Ltd of the Acacia Ridge plant in Brisbane will lead to a net loss of employment there of something in the order of 900, 850 of whom are production staff. The assembly operations of General Motors will be transferred from Acacia Ridge to Dandenong in Victoria and to Elizabeth in South Australia. It is estimated by the company that the net gain in employment at Dandenong and Elizabeth will be in the order of 600, but I do not think there is a precise estimate of where that will occur. I am led to believe that it will be a roughly equal division between the two plants.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that the transfer of employment of which the company informed me and which it announced at the time of the statement about the closure of Acacia Ridge is, I believe, a very genuine estimate, but any figures about estimates of employment in the motor vehicle industry in Australia have to have regard to the continuing process of restructuring and technological change which is taking place within the industry. General Motors-Holden's had a very diverse range of situations in which its production activities were being carried on. It is hoped by the company that this step will lead to greater efficiencies and greater capacity for the company to remain a competitive manufacturer of motor vehicles in Australia.

With regard to the future role of GMH's Woodville plant in South Australia, I can say only that in May of this year the company announced its intention to move many of the operations at Woodville to Elizabeth. The intention was to leave the toolroom and, I think, some design facilities and administrative staff at the Woodville plant, a total of about 500 on the completion of a period of wind-down of the Woodville plant, which would take two or three years. I have no further information regarding that matter, except to say that the future of the Woodville plant is being considered by General Motors in conjunction with the South Australian Government. The principal question which is being addressed is the possibility of an alternative use for the Woodville site of General Motors- Holden's. I cannot take the answer any further than that but, as I have indicated, I do know that it is a subject of close discussion between the relevant government and the company.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I ask: Has the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Executive wound down research into wind energy? In particular, have wind energy researchers in the divisions of Energy Technology, Water and Land Resources, and Mathematics and Statistics been instructed to finish their projects on wind energy, to take up other areas of research, and not to begin any new wind energy projects? Has this CSIRO policy arisen substantially as a result of pressure on the CSIRO by proponents of uranium mining and nuclear power?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided me with the following information, which I believe is appropriate in response to Senator Mason's question: The goal for wind energy research at CSIRO has been to assess the potential of wind energy resources in Australia. Research towards this goal has been carried out by the Organisation's Division of Water and Land Resources and the Division of Mathematics and Statistics. The Division of Water and Land Resources undertook a study to assess the nationwide potential for wind power as a source of energy. This was concerned with the availability of the resource, not with technology for harvesting. The project has been completed and therefore has been terminated in the normal course of events, not as a consequence of any specific instruction.

ANSWER.PARA: The two divisions, in co-operation, recently conducted a survey of wind energy potential in the north-east of Tasmania. The results are being evaluated. CSIRO decided to terminate work on wind energy applications in the Division of Energy Technology. This was in accord with advice by a committee which reviewed the former Division of Mechanical Engineering in 1981 and the Advisory Council's advice that CSIRO resources devoted to wind energy research could be more effectively deployed elsewhere. The scientist in question was accordingly instructed by the chief of the Division not to proceed further with studies in this area. CSIRO policy has not resulted from pressure by proponents of uranium mining and nuclear power. The CSIRO does not conduct nuclear power research.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Are we to take it from the Minister's response that, in a situation where advanced technology and development of that technology for generators in the megawatt range is proceeding successfully and has been for some years in almost every other country, the Australian Government has decided to abandon this area of research? If not, what steps are being taken to follow that research?

—I think Senator Mason can infer from my answer that the CSIRO is not involved in the development of technology, but rather, as my previous answer pointed out, is involved with research into the potential for wind energy. As to whether there are other areas in which the Australian Government is encouraging the technology for wind power, I will have to refer that matter to my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology and seek information for Senator Mason.

—Does the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs recall the re- commendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which recommended the provision of adequate arrangements for refresher courses and access to libraries and seminars for those women academics who resign at some stage of their career because of family responsibilities? Can the Minister inform the Senate as to the progress in this matter? Finally, when will the Minister be in a position to respond to the report on tenure tabled in the Senate in September 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first part of Senator Robert Ray's question referred to the tenure report and recommendations. The Government has taken a number of steps to consult with everybody affected by the tenure report and its recommendations in preparation for an official Government response. It will, of course, be up to individual institutions to implement the recommendations relating to special measures to assist women who have been previously disadvantaged in their employment as academics. At this stage I am aware of several major tertiary institutions which have employed equal opportunity officers. I expect that part of the duties of those equal opportunity officers will be to address themselves to those recommendations of the tenure report. At this stage I have not received any specific advice regarding steps that individual institutions have taken. I expect to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the final part of Senator Ray's question, relating to the timetable for a Government response to the tenure report, I can report to Senator Ray and to the Senate that we have taken a number of steps to prepare that Government position. I have discussed the matter of academic tenure with the higher education round table in meetings in April and September this year. I have also raised the matter for discussion and comment with the Federation of College Academics and the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations at their annual general meetings in August and with the Australian Vice- Chancellors Committee recently. In addition, I have raised the issue of tenure with university and college staff associations during my visits to campuses around the country. The Government's education and youth affairs sub-committee will also be meeting with the relevant unions to discuss a response to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on the tenure matter.

In conclusion, the Government is aware of the great interest in this matter and is aware of the many disadvantages that some sections of the academic community have suffered because of current tenure arrangements. In particular, those disadvantages are suffered by women who, because of direct and indirect discriminatory employment practices in the past, generally speaking have not been able to secure tenured positions. Only a very small proportion of tenured positions are held by women within universities and most of those are at a junior level. So, a proportionately large number of women are currently in untenured positions. Similarly, the opportunities for new post-doctoratal graduates or post-graduates who have entered employment in universities in recent years to obtain tenured employment have been very poor because of the static situation and the arrangement of positions between tenured and non- tenured staff that has prevailed in recent years.

We are very concerned about the need to find opportunities for academics to secure permanent employment on an equitable basis. The matter is a complex one and is being dealt with in the consultative way that I have described to the Senate. I point out also that because of the growth in the tertiary sector which the Government's policies will secure-there has been a considerable growth in the academic budget for this forthcoming year and extra money has been made available by the Government for increased participation-undoubtedly there will be new positions available within institutions. With these measures in hand and with the measures which are likely to be strengthened in forthcoming Budgets, I think the academic community can expect a growth in secure tenured employment for academics. I hope we will be able to make an official response within the next few months to the tenure position which will be encouraging and optimistic for people in academic employment and those seeking to enter academic employment .

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Is the Government's current exchange rate policy designed primarily to fight inflation by controlling the money supply? Can the Minister advise how much consideration has been given to the employment consequences of the policy? What is the Government's best estimate of the increased numbers of unemployed directly resultant therefrom?
—I call the Minister representing the Minister for Finance.

—I thank Senator Archer for the compliment of describing me as the Minister for Finance. I am, of course, as you correctly stated, Mr President, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. The Government's exchange rate policy is determined by a number of considerations, some of which Senator Archer mentioned. It is continually under review and will probably be reviewed again by Cabinet next week. But in regard to the more specific details, I will ask the Minister for Finance, although the matter more appropriately falls within the responsibility of the Treasurer, whether he has anything to add to that answer.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Were the considerations of employment taken into account?
—The considerations which Senator Archer mentioned, amongst others , were, of course, taken into account and will continue to be.

—I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy whether his attention has been drawn to the Tasmanian Auditor-General's report into the Hydro-Electric Commission of Tasmania which was recently published. Does it show, amongst other things, that the Hydro-Electric Commission made a loss of $4.1m in 1982-83 which was the first loss in 10 years, with the major cause of the loss being the increase in interest charges which it imposed on consumers? Did it show also that the Hydro-Electric Commission ignored normal processes in the letting of contracts for the Gordon below Franklin scheme in order to speed up work on the project? Has this assessment by the Auditor-General calling in question the commecial judgment and, indeed, the propriety of the Hydro-Electric Commission affected any negotiations between governments as to compensation, particularly regarding tenderers for construction of the Crotty Village?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the Tasmanian Auditor-General's report or the annual report, I am not sure which it was, of the Tasmanian Hydro- Electric Commission.
—Did you say it has or it has not?
—It has been drawn to my attention, but I have not unfortunately, yet been able to obtain a copy of it. But from the information that has been supplied to me--
—By Senator Tate.
—No, not by Senator Tate.
—It is in the Mercury.

—As Senator Tate said, it has been published in the Hobart Mercury and probably in other newspapers. From my recollection of that report and the other information that I have received on the subject, yes, it is correct that the Hydro-Electric Commission recorded a loss in the last financial year and that that loss is substantially attributable to the very much higher interest rates which the Commission is now obliged to pay. The Commission, in company with some other electricity commissions is rolling over loans raised many years ago at interest rates of 5 to 7 per cent and is replacing them with loans at interest rates of 14 and 15 per cent. That means, of course, a continuing financial problem for the HEC and for some other electricity commissions. There was also an absolute decline in consumption for probably the first time ever by major bulk users.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also informed that the report draws attention to the speeding up of construction and the letting of contracts on the Gordon below Franklin project and also reveals that the final costing of the Pieman scheme has not yet been finalised. Prima facie that conflicts with statements made by Tasmanian Government officials that contracts have been let already for power which will be available from the Pieman scheme and the long standing alleged policy of the HEC that these contracts are not let until costs have finally been determined. So there is some conflict there as well. As to whether it will affect the discussions regarding compensation with the Commonwealth, subject to further investigation as to the accuracy and significance of those findings, it seems to me that, at the very least, to the extent that information and figures supplied to the Commonwealth in the past have now been questioned by the State Auditor- General, it is a matter which must be taken into account by the Commonwealth when pursuing discussions with Tasmanian Government officials.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it true that the Caucus legal and administrative committee last night failed to agree on the Government's national crimes authority legislation and instead referred it to a sub-committee? Given that this sub-committee will not report back until at least next week and the Parliament is not sitting the following week, when does the Attorney-General now believe he will be in a position to bring the legislation before the Senate? Has this further delay once again placed in jeopardy the Prime Minister's undertaking to have an effective national crimes commission operating by early next year?

—I wish that Senator Hill would devote as much attention to cleaning up the internal affairs of his own Party as he is devoting to the affairs of the Labor Government. The truth of the matter is that the first draft -and it was a first draft only-of a national crimes authority Bill was considered and discussed at considerable length by a party committee last night, and that draft is being further considered by a special sub-committee set up for that particular purpose. I am not in a position to make a final judgment as to when a Bill will appear in this Parliament. If I were, I would be the last person to tell Senator Hill.

—My question, which is to the Minister for Resources and Energy, follows on the one I asked yesterday of the Attorney-General concerning the reported allegations of Mr Christo Moll. Is the Minister aware that the reported allegations of Mr Moll assert dealings with prominent figures in the Western Australian Liberal Party of Australia? Is the Minister also aware of any evidence linking Christo Moll with a prominent Western Australian Liberal Party figure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there is some prima facie evidence of such a link. I have before me a copy of a cheque drawn on the-I apologise for my pronounciation -Algemene Bank of the Netherlands numbered 809917 and dated 4 April 1978. The cheque is made out for $HK200,000 and is payable to the National Bank of Australasia Ltd. Incidentally, at the present exchange rate $HK200,000 is about $A30,000. I am not so sure of what it was then. However, that cheque has ' cancelled' written across it. I also have a copy of a cheque numbered 809918- that is the next cheque-which has on it the same details as to amount and is made payable to the National Bank of Australasia. It is overstamped 'The National Bank of Australasia . . . Albermarle Street, London', indicating that the cheque was paid into an account. Both cheques are signed, and although the signature is not particularly legible it is clearly identifiable from previously published signatures as the signature of C. T. Moll, that is Christo Moll, and are drawn on a company called Mogill Ltd.

ANSWER.PARA: Copies of the butts to both the cheques are also before me. Butt No. 809918- that is, the butt of the cheque that apparently was paid into an account-has marked on it: 'Fund ex-Crichton-Browne'. Crichton-Browne is spelt with an 'e'. Butt No. 809917 records, inter alia, 'N. Crichton-Browne'-again with an 'e'-'a/c Mogill'. I table the photocopies of the cheques and butts, Mr President.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs relates to Press reports that the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation will not be submitting a formal response to the report of the Committee of Review into the Impact of Radford College until some time in November. I ask the Minister: In view of her Department's advice to some non- government school groups that no formal extensions would be granted to them past the 30 September deadline, has some special concession been made for the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation and, if so, for what reason? Is this an example of special treatment being given to friends of the Minister?

—No group has been denied the opportunity to put in a late submission. The only request for a late submission that I can recall seeing has been from the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation. I have said in my discussions with people in the community that if they are unable to complete their comments on the report by the end of September they can request the opportunity to present their views later. The reason for this is that we want a genuine community discussion on this report. It has been extremely controversial . I think it is a very interesting report which makes some very sensible suggestions about future planning for the development of all school systems in the Australian Capital Territory. There is certainly no intention on the part of either me or the Government to prevent any legitimate comment on it. However, I think it would be desirable if all groups and individuals interested could resolve their views quickly so that the Government can proceed to taking their views into account and making a response before the end of the year.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Will the Minister accept that, perhaps through inadvertence, certain advice was given to some of the other organisations that an extension of time was unlikely? In view of what the Minister has said, will she assure any other organisations that if they wish it they may have the same extension of time as has been granted for the Teachers Federation?
—As I said, I have received only that one notification from an organisation needing further time, but I am happy to consider sympathetically any other such requests.

—Has the attention of the Acting Minister for Health been drawn to an advertisement, which appeared in many Queensland newspapers on Monday and yesterday, which attacked the introduction of Medicare? Were these advertisements placed by the Queensland Government at the expense of Queensland taxpayers? Were the claims in the advertisement deliberately misleading?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the advertisement which appeared in the Courier- Mail on Monday this week. In fact, I have it before me. The advertisement is an interesting one in that it appeared on Monday-incidentally, it contains a photograph of the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, and the interim Minister for Health, Mr Bertoni-and underneath it are the words: 'Authorised by Mr S. Schubert, Co-ordinator General Premier's Department'. The next day Mr Schubert complained to the Courier-Mail. In fact, he was quite mortified at the thought that he had in fact authorised the advertisement. He said he had not authorised it, he had authorised only the payment for it. That clarifies the first part of Senator Colston's question. It seems that yes, the advertisement was paid for by the taxpayers of Queensland. One cannot blame Mr Schubert. We know what happens in Queensland if public servants do not do what they are told, no matter how right or wrong they think it is to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether the advertisement is accurate, I must say that I find it quite ironic that the Queensland Premier and the Queensland Government use public funds in this way to put out advertisements which are inaccurate about the Medicare scheme, which will in fact benefit the Queensland public in general. I find it particularly ironic because in the last couple of years of the previous Federal Government it almost halved the expenditure available to Queensland for its hospital and health services, yet we saw no advertisements and heard no complaints at all from the Premier of Queensland or from any member of the Queensland Government. I remind honourable senators that the support for Queensland hospitals will increase from the $93m provided by the previous Federal Government to $173m in the first full year of Medicare. The advertisement is also very misleading in its claim that under Medicare Queensland will subsidise other States, or, according to the advertisement, southern States. This can be countered simply by referring to the figures.

The Medicare levy in Queensland will raise some $146m. Queenslanders in return will receive $260m in extra funds and benefits for their health care system. Believe me, they need it. Put simply, the Queensland Premier is using Queenslanders' funds to campaign against Queenslanders receiving additional benefits under the Medicare system. The Premier would prefer, in fact, to see Queenslanders queueing up in a public hospital outpatients' department rather than having the right automatically to go to their own doctors and be covered for that under Medicare. He is using Queenslanders' money to try to discredit a program that will increase the freedom of choice for Queenslanders in relation to health care needs and which will give them access to a whole range of health care benefits that they do not have now: That is, automatic cover for visits to their own doctors; the right to extra funds for their private and public hospitals; the right to extra funds for community health centres; the right to cheaper, affordable private health care cover if they desire it; and, most importantly, the guarantee of survival of Queensland's free public hospital system which, as Senator Colston and other Queensland senators would know, has been run down in recent years.

The fact that the National Party and, one may suppose, the Liberal Party in Queensland have stooped so low to produce advertisements like this at the expense of the Queensland taxpayer for election purposes is an indication of how insecure they feel during the present election campaign and how desperate they are to raise issues for which they can try to get some credit for their own Government. I do not believe that Medicare will be an election issue in Queensland. The Queensland people quite clearly will benefit from Medicare, both in their dealings with private medical practitioners and in enabling their public hospital services to be upgraded. I find it quite deplorable that public funds should be used in this way in a pre-election period.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer to the overt, obvious and pathetic attempts of the Government to use Question Time against the Queensland Government. Is the Minister for Finance aware that Queensland has 16.1 per cent of Australia's population? Is he aware that Queensland had only 6.6 per cent of industrial disputes in the first five months of the Hawke Government? Is he aware that 20.3 per cent of the foreign investment proposals by value in the year to June 1982 were in Queensland? Is he aware that over 20 per cent of actual fixed capital expenditure in the 12 months to March 1983 occurred in Queensland? Is he aware that more than 20 per cent of expected capital expenditure for the 12 months to 30 June 1984 will be in Queensland? I further ask him whether he is aware-this is a matter of which I hope he would be aware-that in the three years ended August 1983 there were 42,200 new jobs created in Queensland, whilst there were losses of jobs totalling 47,800 in New South Wales, 19,200 in Victoria and 12, 300 in South Australia in the same period. I further ask the Minister whether he is aware that in the three years ended June 1983 there was a net inflow of 86, 600 people to Queensland from other States compared with net outflows of 34,589 from New South Wales, 40,900 from Victoria, and 17,420 from South Australia. In other words, I ask the Minister whether he is aware that Australians have voted with their feet, their money and their jobs and gone to Queensland because they believe there is a greater chance for them in that State than in New South Wales , Victoria or South Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question Senator Chaney asked referred to industrial disputes over the five-month period ended-I am not sure-
—It referred to the first five months of the Hawke Government.

—It referred to the first five months of the Hawke Government which, depending on whether we count March, would be the five months ended July. I do not have the figures for those five months. I do, however, happen to have the figures for July of 1983, which show that Queensland lost 492 working days per thousand employees through industrial disputes, which is the highest of any of the States and well above the national average of 289 days lost per month. Therefore, among other things, one can conclude from that that such statistics are highly variable. I am not challenging the veracity of the statistics Senator Chaney has produced. They are probably accurate as far as they go. But in the most recent month for which statistics are available, the situation is quite the reverse of that which Senator Chaney presented for the five months.
—That is because of the Liberal Party disappearing.

—I do not think it disappeared quite that early, but I will come back to that later, Senator Button. I am also aware of the fact that the participation rate-again using the most recent statistics available-in Queensland in the most recent month, August 1983, is lower than it is for South Australia and considerably lower than it is for the nation as a whole. The respective figures are: Queensland, 58.6 per cent; South Australia, 58.8 per cent; and Australia 59.8 per cent. In spite of that very low participation rate, for the 12 months ended August 1983, Queensland's unemployment rate had gone up to 10.1 per cent. As I said in the Senate a couple of days ago, that is an increase of 65 per cent in the unemployment rate in just 12 months and an increase very much in excess of the national average.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the other matters that Senator Chaney raised, it is correct that investment was quite heavy in Queensland until quite recently. It was associated with the development of the State's nationwide resources, a development which, for mainly external factors, granted, is now slowing down very rapidly and arguably grinding to a halt. Queensland was, through the years of 1981 and 1982, the beneficiary of fortunate circumstances beyond its control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good government.

—I will come back to that in a minute. Economic activity in Queensland in that period was also stimulated by real estate and construction booms, principally on the Gold Coast, but also in other areas-booms which, like all booms, have now inevitably collapsed. It also had the benefit until quite recently of a Liberal Party Treasurer, who at least exerted some restraining influence on the eccentric behaviour of the Queensland Premier and his Party and his sponsorship of people like Dr Shrian Oskar, Milan Brych and Stephen Horvath. That moderating influence of the Liberal Party has now been removed.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I seek your indulgence. I ask whether it is in order for Senator Walsh to continually attack the Premier of Queensland, to use his response as a vehicle to denigrate the Premier. I can assure him that the people of Queensland will not tolerate it for one minute.
—Order! There is no point of order. I point out that the Minister is replying to a long and detailed question from the Leader of the Opposition.

—It was a long and detailed question which, among other things, sought facts and opinions regarding the present economic stagnation of Queensland and, if one goes back a couple of years, its relative prosperity for reasons which I have already enumerated. In regard to the Queensland Premier, I shall not pass judgment on him. I think judgment will be passed on him by the people of Queensland because he, through his intransigence or worse, removed from the Queensland Government the moderating and rational influence, so far as it went, of the Queensland Liberal Party and, particularly, the Queensland Treasurer. In other words, I think we can let the Queensland Premier be judged by the company he chooses and the people he has sponsored. As I have said, they include that convicted criminal Milan Brych, the international con man Shrian Oskar--
—Order! I think the Minister is now debating the matter.
—Mr President--
—Order! I call the Leader of the Opposition, to ask a supplementary question.
—No, I rise--
—Order!

—All right, Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have in front of me the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for the labour force in Australia in August 1983. I ask a question of the Minister in the light of what I see as his misrepresentation of the figures as between Adelaide and Brisbane. In answer to my question the Minister stated that the participation rate in Brisbane was lower than that--
—In Queensland. Can the Minister confirm that the participation rate in Brisbane is a rate of 58.8 per cent and that the participation rate in Adelaide is 58.3 per cent?
—Order! I do not know that that is, in fact, a supplementary question. I shall allow it, but I would ask the Minister to bear in mind that it is additional information that is sought.

—I shall be very brief, Mr President. The figures that I have in front of me are identical to those cited by Senator Chaney, that is, that the participation rate-I shall not explain what that term means-in Brisbane is higher than the rate in Adelaide. I should have thought, though, that the Government of Queensland, above all, claimed to be a government for the whole State and not just a government for the city of Brisbane. Looking at the whole State, the situation is reversed. The participation rate for Queensland is 58.6 per cent. The participation rate for South Australia is 58.8 per cent. Yet in spite of that, Queensland's unemployment percentage in the 12 months for which we have the most recently available statistics shows a massive increase of 65 per cent, in spite of a lower participation rate than that of South Australia, and a lower participation rate than that of the nation as a whole.

—On Thursday, 6 October, I answered a question in the Senate from Senator Lewis regarding tertiary student hostels in Victoria. I indicated at that time that I had not seen any representations from the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Fordham, on this subject. I have now seen a letter from the Victorian Minister for Education advising me that the Victorian Government intends to dispose of a number of existing hostels and to convert others for the use of primary and secondary students from the country visiting Melbourne for work experience or excursion activities. In my answer I also indicated that the matter of accommodation for tertiary students is currently under review by the Tertiary Education Commission and that that review would be completed this year. I have now been advised that this review will not be completed until April 1984 and will be released as part of the report of the Tertiary Education Commission for the triennial report 1985-87, volume 1.

—At Question Time today I was asked a question by Senator Peter Baume concerning an extension of time allowed for public comment on the Radford report. I should like to confirm that no organisation has been refused an extension. This is despite the fact that the Canberra Times of today carried a report to the effect that the Catholic Education Office was refused an extension , and that the Canberra Church of England Girls Grammar School was given an extension of only three days. This report is wrong. For the benefit of the Senate, I repeat that no organisation has been refused an extension. I understand that the Canberra Church of England Girls Grammar School will be correcting the report in the Canberra Times. I should also point out that not only has an extension been agreed on for the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation but also an extension has been agreed for the National Council of Independent Schools.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS: REPATRIATION BENEFITS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges asked me a question relating to Torres Strait Islanders at Question Time today. I have been advised by my Department that there has been no contact from the Queensland Minister, Mr Bird, or his Department, or the Queensland Government, with the present Federal Government about this matter since the election in March this year. There is no indication on any current file of any contact or representations from the Queensland Government or Department about retrospective payments. I can now confirm that there has been no such approach for at least the last five years. My Department is currently searching archive files to determine whether any earlier representations were made by the Queensland Government on this matter.

—by leave-Mr President, I understand that at Question Time Senator Walsh, by implication, was suggesting that I had had some connection with a Mr Christo Moll. He implied that I had received a payment, I think, from Mr Moll. Is that the suggestion you are making, Senator Walsh?
—Order! The honourable senator will direct his remarks to the Chair. He is making a personal explanation.

—I am sorry, Mr President. I do not make a habit of listening to what Senator Walsh says, as a rule, so I did not hear all that he said. I simply say that to my knowledge I have never met Mr Christo Moll. If he jumped up from my Weeties tomorrow morning at breakfast, I would not recognise him. I have had no business dealing with him, directly or indirectly. I deny that these cheques are in any way connected with me, directly or indirectly. If Senator Walsh is so clever and has some cheques which imply that my name is written on the cheque butt, I should have thought that he would be able to trace the cheques and find out where they arrived and to whom they were paid. That appears not to be the case so far. I simply restate that I have no business dealings with Mr Moll, directly or indirectly.
—by leave-I drew attention to the fact that certain words were written, among others, on the cheque butts. I did not mention Senator Crichton-Browne.
—You are a grub.
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I did not mention Senator Crichton-Browne. It was in response to a question from Senator Cook regarding statements previously reported, statements from Mr Moll. I simply tabled that document and drew attention to some of the matters, the names that were written on the butt. I did not mention Senator Crichton-Browne.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Jones proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The adverse effects on Commonwealth-State financial programs caused by the political instability and mismanagement of the Queensland Government in total disregard for the people of Queensland.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The adverse effects on Commonwealth-State financial programs caused by the political instability and mismanagement of the Queensland Government in total disregard for the people of Queensland.

I have to say that it should be quite obvious to everyone why the Australian Labor Party is bringing up this matter for debate. During Question Time today it was clearly shown that there were a number of areas in which the Bjelke-Petersen Government had certainly mismanaged the economy within the Queensland area of government. I believe that the Bjelke-Petersen Government could be attacked for underspending, for the money that it has not spent-the money given to it under grants from the Commonwealth Government. This includes money under the water supply scheme, money saved from the wages pause, money granted to it for housing , money granted for industry and for soil conservation, and grants from the Commonwealth Grants Commission. All that money paid across to the Bjelke- Petersen Government has been underspent and, because the Government has not spent the money handed across to it, further unemployment has been created within Queensland. We find a lack of action by the State Government. It has not even tried to spend all the money granted to it by the Commonwealth Government to overcome the unemployment that has occurred in the State. The Commonwealth Government made $15.9m available to the Queensland Government for job creation programs in the six months ending 30 June 1983 from money saved during the wages pause. Out of this only $1m has been spent for its intended purpose. The rest has been invested on the short term money market in a desperate effort to shore up the State's Budget deficit at the expense of the unemployed. This is evident right through the actions of the State Government. As recently as 11 October 1983, when the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was in Queensland, a headline in a newspaper read: 'Joh will not co-operate'. The article originated in Toowoomba, and stated:
Mr Hawke repeatedly emphasised his claim that about $42m allocated to the Queensland Government from the Commonwealth employment program for water supply schemes in country towns had not been spent.

In other words, what the State Government has done is to allow unemployment to continue to grow. It has not spent any of the money allocated to it by the Commonwealth Government to try to overcome the problems of unemployment in that area. Because of the time constraints I shall not read all the unemployment figures in this table, but seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators look at those figures they will understand the points being made in relation to the State Government not spending money on unemployment. Another area in which the Bjelke-Petersen Government has failed to spend the money allocated to it is in regard to allocations from the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The Grants Commission estimates that the Bjelke- Petersen Government underspent by $11.4m in 1980-81, the latest figures available, on service to industries, indicating the level of neglect of this industrial and manufacturing sector that is so important to economic recovery in that State and Australia as a whole. I repeat that $11.4m is estimated by the Grants Commission to have been underspent by the Queensland Government. That Government, out of an appropriation of some $920m on 2 August, had spent $652m by the end of September. The Bjelke-Petersen minority Cabinet that was appointed after that time is rapidly running out of the money needed to pay the wages of 140,000 public servants-police, teachers, railway workers, clerks and other people employed in the Public Service. The Queensland Government has a wages bill of $10m per day. Many, if not most, of the State's vital expenditure programs are being shamelessly deferred in a desperate effort to shore up the State's reserves until the election on 22 October.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Premier does not want the people of Queensland to know is that the taxpayers' money needed to keep Queensland running and to foot the enormous bill for the National Party's election advertising is coming from those expenditure programs and trust funds and special funds that have been set up for the benefit of ordinary people. Recalling a question asked about this at Question Time, it is quite obvious that Government members and public servants are authorising advertisements that are being placed in the newspapers. Some of the areas that are at risk because of the Government's transfer of funds to the election campaign are the Aboriginal Welfare Fund, the Workers Compensation Fund, the Children's Services Special Standing Fund, the Drought Relief Fund, the Gateway Bridge Trust Fund, the Hospital Rebuilding Fund, the National Fitness Fund, the Police Superannuation Fund, and the State Service Superannuation Fund. (Quorum formed) Another two areas at risk are the Queensland Road Safety Council Fund and the Motor Vehicle Insurance Nominal Defendant Fund.

A total of $1.3 billion was appropriated to these and other funds on 2 August without a proper budget and with a complete redirection of spending towards election matters. The budgets of some departments are now hopelessly muddled. The departments have had to spend their money on party political campaigning for the National Party, which will severely restrict their expenditure programs next year. They will have to cut costs and cut corners to make up the shortfall, at a time when they should be trying to provide jobs, because their budgets have been manipulated to keep the Bjelke-Petersen minority Government in power.

In regard to the rural sector, Queensland's agricultural industry contributed $ 2,800m to the economy in 1980-81, or about 25 per cent of the State's gross domestic product. That is a decrease in the proportions of gross domestic product of far more than 25 per cent since 1960-61. Despite the professed concern of the National Party for the interests of the rural sector, it has been shown in successive Commonwealth Grants Commission reports to have provided less than adequate financial and technical assistance to our rural based industries. The neglect of areas such as soil conservation, water resources, agriculture, livestock production, the sugar industry, and the provision of adequate transport services, is precisely shown in these Grants Commission reports. While on the subject of the rural sector, Bjelke-Petersen has been complaining that the Federal Government has not given to him, or to his Government, money for soil conservation on the Darling Downs. The Grants Commission estimates that the Queensland Government has underspent by $1m per annum in the area of soil conservation. Let the Premier explain that away.

Queensland has underspent on rural water supplies and irrigation. Examples of neglect include the Burdekin Dam, which had a high priority in 1957 during the time of the State Labor Government but which has taken the National-Liberal Party Government 26 years to initiate. Of course it took the Hawke Labor Government to finance the building of the wall of the Burdekin Dam. Only now is the Burdekin Dam assured of being built, after the Hawke Labor Government contributes to the total cost of stage 1 of the project, of which $13m is to be spent in the 1983-84 financial year. Rural Queensland needs water supplies which are practical and economical, not pie in the sky Bradford schemes which the former Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, described as economic nonsense. I think Senator Boswell is one of the promoters of the Bradford scheme. The Bradford scheme, if initiated, would cost the Queensland taxpayer $1,400m in current prices and would jeopardise other rural oriented projects.

We can go a little further in looking at primary industry. No relief was offered to the fishing industry in Queensland when it was reeling from the effects of the drought on fish breeding grounds. But it is hardly surprising when one reads the 1982 Commonwealth Grants Commission report which estimates that the Queensland Government underspent on the fishing industry at the rate of $1.4m per year. More than 10 per cent of Queensland's grazing properties and pastoral holdings are estimated to be under foreign control. A similar percentage is believed to apply to urban centres such as the Gold Coast.

I will not look at the list I have of foreign investment because I have said it before and I believe the people of Queensland are well aware of the fact that foreign investment in Queensland is higher than in any other State except Western Australia. A distinction must be made between those foreign investments which are long term, which increase production and create jobs, and those which are purely speculative. Speculative investment drives up rural and urban land values and makes it difficult and more expensive for Queenslanders to compete in the purchase of land and property. A typical example of that is a property in Warwick-a property which was owned by an Australian family for over 100 years- which has been purchased by a Japanese company for $1.3m.

In relation to minerals and the resource boom that we hear the Premier talking about, currently 57 per cent of the resource projects announced by the Queensland Government, are in limbo. According to a document produced by the State Department of Commercial and Industrial Development entitled 'Major Development Projects and Proposals 1982' projects shelved or postponed include the following-and Senator Walsh will be interested in this one-Rundle shale oil, $5.2 billion; Alcan Australia Ltd aluminium smelter, $1.1 billion; Lend Lease coke plant, $1.2 billion; Accor coal liquefaction plant, Millmerran, $2.8 billion and Occidental Minerals Corporation petroleum chemical plant, $2.3 billion. Of the 83 projects listed by the Department of Commercial and Industrial Development, it is estimated that 48 have been indefinitely postponed or cancelled. Forty-eight of those 83 projects proposed and written about in the 'Major Development Projects and Proposals 1982' have either been shelved or postponed.

On 22 October that situation in Queensland will change and we will have in power Keith Wright, a Labor Premier, who will, I believe, be able to bring about the development of some of those projects cancelled or shelved by the Premier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Gerry Jones, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The adverse effects on Commonwealth-State financial programs caused by the political instability and mismanagement of the Queensland Government in total disregard for the people of Queensland.

Naturally I reject outright the allegations contained in that. We have just listened to Senator Jones. I could understand it a little if he were a senator from another State but for a senator supposedly from and representing the State of Queensland in this august chamber to come down here with such allegations about a State which is probably doing more than any other State to advance this country, to meet our balance of payments, to meet exports and all the rest of it , is abhorrent. He made quite a few allegations. These allegations were--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I made the allegations because I believe the people of Queensland should be well aware of what is happening in their State and what action is not being taken by the State Government in that State.
—There is no point of order.

—I am quite sure that they are well aware and they will indicate their awareness on 22 October. It is becoming a bit of a running hare on the matter of the State being likely to run out of Supply. Of course, this chamber is not unused to that sort of argument. But let me assure the public servants of Queensland, be they railway workers or teachers-all those who are named as people to whip up this fear complex-that they will be paid come next pay day. There is money in the till, the election will come along, the Government will be returned and everything will carry on.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jones also mentioned problems with the rural industry. A senator from the Labor Government highlights problems in the rural industry! What happened to the rural industry in this Government's last Budget? He mentioned soil conservation. Might I mention what has happened to the tax deductibility for clearing and swamp drainage? What has happened to fuel excise? What has happened to the rebate on the cost of freight or fuel? All these innovations by the new Labor Government in its recent Budget are certainly not there to help the people in our great rural industry. What about all the help that we were going to get for the sugar industry as promised by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, and by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, when they went to north Queensland prior to the last election? What has that come to? It has come to nothing, except that one has to admit that $10m has gone into the Rural Reconstruction Board for loans. There is nothing about the underwriting of the 1983 crop, let alone the 1982 crop, as was promised.

But the people of north Queensland have not been fooled. To my knowledge that same $10m has been hawked around by Mr Hawke twice at least-he has been there recently so it may have been hawked around a third time-that same $10m which is only going into the RRB and will ultimately be there just for loans anyhow. Such is the deviousness of this Administration.

Senator Jones also mentioned the mining industry or the resource industries in Queensland. During the last recess I was in Weipa. It was there that I was reminded that Weipa was the first great resources program which got Queensland going again after years and years of the Dark Ages until 1957. It obviously needed men of vision, and overseas capital as well as Australian capital. Of course, since then, the history of Queensland has changed markedly because of the resources boom. Even though there is a world downturn at this time we are still opening new mines. Senator Jones never addressed himself to that program. I think Boundary Creek opened recently. Mount Isa Mines Ltd is going ahead with its mine and all the ancillaries at Abbot Point for the shipment of that coal. So even though there is a world economic downturn, the Queensland mining situation is going steadily ahead. Sure, some might be on the backburner, as would be expected. But this is in marked contrast to what has happened in other States.

Queensland was still exporting coal when we saw Wran's armada-everybody knows about it-off the shores of New South Wales where, because of the industrial problems in New South Wales, the whole coal industry in that State just about folded up. There were 30 or 40 ships off Newcastle and Port Kembla-Wran's armada , as it became known. All that time the Queensland resources were going steadily ahead. We are, as usual, playing our part in the great resource industries of Australia and helping our balance of trade.

Senator Jones mentioned the community employment program. It was mentioned just as though Queensland was the only State that was having difficulties with the Commonwealth on coming up with the guidelines of how the CEP should be formulated. I state here and now that we are not the only State; other States have had their particular problems with this Government. The Labor States have had their problems with the Labor Commonwealth Government. For that reason, the CEP has hardly got going in any State. Some of the original money--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I should like to say that there are in fact two projects going ahead-one in Tasmania and one in South Australia.
—There is no point of order, Senator Reynolds.

—Good try, Senator. You will have your turn shortly. As I was saying, the problems that confront Queensland in negotiations with this Labor Federal Government are the same as those which confront the Labor State governments. Programs are starting to go ahead in spite of all those difficulties. I might add that the original money for the CEP came from the wages pause which was initiated by the Fraser-Anthony Government. Every time the CEP is mentioned, the water resources program to provide water for urban areas- water which would not be provided without the CEP-is mentioned also. What happened to the bicentennial water resources program? We have already had debates in this chamber on that subject. It was abandoned completely by the Labor Government when it came into power. Some of that money would have helped industry and urban areas, as well as irrigation areas. Dare I mention the Awoonga Dam on the Boyne River at Gladstone? That will go ahead, of course, with Queensland Government money.
—What do you reckon about the hydrogen car?

—Senator Walsh should get back in his place if he wants to interject. Money for that dam was to have come from the bicentennial water resources program. The people of Gladstone should be made aware that those funds were cut off by the Labor Government. That project will go ahead with Queensland money, to the benefit of that great city and the industries in it. What about the dam on the Dawson River? That included irrigation projects and would supply water to the small country town of Theodore. Let us get rid of this hypocrisy about all the water resources programs that are not going ahead because of confrontation between State and Federal governments over the CEP.

SPEECH.PARA: Then, of course, we have the born-again Burdekin Dam. It was nice to know that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, went to north Queensland in the winter recess and found out where the Burdekin River is. He adopted the dam program as his own. That is tremendous. At least it guarantees that the scheme will go ahead. During the autumn parliamentary session I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, a question about what was happening about funding for the Burdekin Dam. Of course, no answer was forthcoming. But fortuitously for the people of Queensland the Prime Minister has found out where the Burdekin River is. He has been to north Queensland. He has said that the scheme will go ahead. Did he give credit where credit was due? Oh no, he implied that it was his program totally. Everybody knows that it was the previous Government's program, that the arrangement in very simple terms was that the Federal Government would build the dam wall and the Queensland Government would build the roads, provide the ancillary services and the rest of it. I am indebted to Senator Sir John Carrick for asking a question at the Estimates Committee C hearing on 12 September 1983. As recorded at page 71 of the Hansard record, Senator Sir John Carrick asked:
At the time of the allocation of the $6.5m what was the arrangement between the Commonwealth Government of the day and the State Government in terms of the dam? Would you spell it out?
A departmental representative, Mr Manderson, replied:

The previous Government agreed to meet the full cost of the dam, which was estimated at about $85m in mid-1980 prices. The State was to meet the preliminary costs associated with the construction of the dam, mainly road works , then estimated at about $14m. The State Government was also to meet the costs of developing the irrigation works, which were then estimated at about $109m.

At that Estimates Committee hearing a departmental offical indicated that the plans were in place and the dam was to be built. The only problem, of course, was that it looked as though the scheme was in jeopardy when the Labor Government came to office and disbanded the bicentennial water resources program .

As I said, the current Prime Minister went to Queensland, found out where north Queensland is and where the Burdekin Dam is, so it is now assured that the program will go ahead. I am thankful for that. Of course, the Prime Minister has been around Queensland like Santa Clause twice now. I think that the people should know that the money the Prime Minister has been handing out is money that has been allocated in the Budget anyhow. He is hawking the same money once again . The people should not be under any illusion whatsoever as far as that is concerned. I am not quite sure about the allocation of $10m. We seem to have an extra $10m to be spent on roads. The Prime Minister announced that, I think, in Brisbane. When he reached Townsville he announced that a portion of it would be spent there; when he arrived at Cairns he announced that another portion would be spent there. I do not know what amount it all adds up to; it might even add up to $20m. We could have been promised $10m that not even the Treasurer (Mr Keating) knows about. I am not sure from where that money is coming. Maybe it is from some of the fat in the Budget. We found out about a couple of new items at Estimates committees hearings. Maybe there is some extra money so that when an election or a by-election comes up the Prime Minister can go around, play Santa Clause and think that he will win the hearts and the minds of the people.

Mention was made of the Commonwealth Grants Commission by Senator Jones. Of course, in Queensland we have tried to keep-indeed, we have succeeded in keeping -State taxes lower than they are in other States. It is interesting that the Grants Commissioner assessed that if Queensland were taxed at the same rate as the other States are taxed on average, the State would have an additional $153m per annum in revenue. Conversely, the Queensland citizens would have $153m per annum less in their pockets. I think that should be noted. Queensland-even the Grants Commission admits this-is one of the lowest taxed States. Taxes paid in Queensland are certainly far lower than those paid in the major States. If we were taxed at the average rate of the other States the people of Queensland would be out of pocket to the extent of $153m per annum.

Of course, much has been said about Queensland industry. It has been mentioned, although not so far in this debate, that General Motors-Holden's Ltd is closing down its plant at Acacia Ridge. I think one fact should be recognised-it was brought home to me by one of the employees of the GMH plant at Acacia Ridge. The employee said: 'If you look out at the employees' car park you don't see too many GMH products'. Maybe those employees know something I do not know about GMH products. Maybe because they are building the motor vehicles they do not have confidence in them. The fact is that other cars come into this country-cars of different quality, in some cases better quality, and sometimes cheaper. I guess that is what the market situation is all about.

I was able to get hold of some interesting figures which show, country by country, the productivity of vehicle manufacturers and the productivity for each worker per annum in the motor vehicle manufacturing industry. The country at the top of the list, of course, is Japan with 50 vehicles for each worker per annum. In Germany, it is 20; in the United States of America, 15; in the United Kingdom , 10; and in Australia, 9.75. I was not able to obtain figures for Italy or France. We obviously have a productivity problem in Australia. Some of the blame for that problem could be sheeted home-I am not an expert on this industry-to the type of machinery that is used. A lot of other nations have gone to robotics far sooner than Australia has. Within those figures there is a certain indictment on the productivity capability of the Australian work force. People employed in those plants have to look to their own laurels if we are to maintain jobs in Australia in that industry. I do not see why the productivity of Australian workers should be any better or any worse than that of workers overseas. In Australia the workers in some industries seem to adopt the attitude that the world owes them a living. Thus, the problem associated with productivity in the motor vehicle manufacturing industry arises. It is a very sick joke really that if one buys a car that has been manufactured on a Monday or a Friday one generally has a lemon because the quality is certainly not up to the standard of cars manufactured on the other days of the week.

The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) at Question Time pointed out some very significant facts. No matter what we might say or what the other States might say about Queensland, people are voting with their money, they are voting with their feet-they are voting with everything they can-to show what they think about Queensland. In the three years ended August 1983 42,000 jobs were created in Queensland, compared with the loss of 47,800 jobs in New South Wales, 19,200 jobs in Victoria, and 12,300 jobs in South Australia in the same period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Queensland is providing all the jobs for Australia.

—As my colleague says, Queensland is providing the jobs for Australia. That is what it amounts to. Sure, its unemployment level might be up at this stage, but what can we expect when people from the rest of the nation are going to live there? In the three years ended at June 1983 there was a net inflow of 86,661 people to Queensland from the other States, compared to net outflows of 34,589 from New South Wales, 40,913 from Victoria and 17,420 from South Australia. The runs are on the board. People are voting with their money. They are voting with their feet and coming to the State where all the action is.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak now about a table that has been shown to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), who is at the table. It was taken from the last Year Book Australia. It gives 1981-82 figures for exports and imports per State indicating whether the surplus is a plus or minus figure. It then shows the surplus per head of population. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
