SPEECH.PARA: Again, I say that the runs are on the board. I completely reject all the allegations that are constantly brought up by the Government, particularly those which were brought up by Senator Jones in this matter of public importance today . People are coming to Queensland in greater numbers. When one looks at the figures showing Queensland's contribution per head of population to Australia's exports compared with imports one must recognise that many of the people who come to Queensland, apart from those who come because of the political and business climate, do so to retire. That, of course, detracts from those figures. The runs are on the board. I completely reject all that has been said by the Government, particularly the remarks made by Senator Jones. He is obviously looking to move to New South Wales, having made those statements. He cannot want to represent Queensland for much longer. Let him go from Queensland to New South Wales and live under that great and wonderful State Government, with all the allegations, assertions and insinuations of graft which have left a smell around the halls and corridors of power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President-(Quorum formed ) People who have listened to Senator Jones and Senator Collard speaking in the Senate today will probably be excused for thinking that those senators were talking about two entirely different States. The exaggeration either in denigration or adulation I think illustrates fairly clearly the problems we have when addressing any such issue in this country. If one looks at the situation in Queensland in terms of the Government statistics which are available, one finds, for example that unemployment, an issue raised by Senator Jones and addressed by Senator Collard, has followed a fairly erratic course this year in Queensland, peaking at 11.5 per cent in February and dipping to 9.9 per cent in June. For most months of this year it has been above the national average. The total number of people employed in Queensland, has been lower in every month of this year than it was in the corresponding month last year, but this is true of the Australian economy in general.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that estimating the rate of unemployment in Queensland for comparative purposes with other States is compounded by the problem of the high migration rate to Queensland, which tends to push up the State's unemployment figures. However, one ought to be careful when one looks at that factor. If people suggest, for example, that it is good that people migrate to Queensland, they cannot blame others for the problems that are brought by those who come there. I am suggesting that one must take the kicks with the pats. At the moment the Premier of Queensland is saying that it is marvellous that people come to the State and then he says problems are caused by the people who come. One cannot have it both ways. I think more sensible debates might take place if all governments accepted that they have limited control over what goes on in the economy. When things are looking good governments want to take the kudos, but when things look bad they will correspondingly have to take the blame. It might be better to mute the clamour for praise. In that way one would not have to take quite as much of the blame which necessarily results from the cyclical way in which economies rise and fall.

Under the current Government, or that part of it which still lingers on, in Queensland the major employment and resource base is in agriculture, mining and tourism. Agriculture in both Queensland and the rest of Australia has been badly affected both by the world recession and by the drought. Mining has been adversely affected throughout Australia by the world recession and the corresponding downturn in commodities such as coal and copper. I do not believe that we can blame the Queensland Government for the drought or for the world recession. I think that any reasonable person who is trying to make out a case ought to acknowledge that fact at least. The industrial and manufacturing base in Queensland are geared towards the processing of products especially in the agricultrual sector. Hence abattoirs, flour mills, sugar mills and manufacturers of agricultural machinery have all been affected by these two factors-the drought and world recession. The closing down of the General Motors-Holden's Ltd plant at Acacia Ridge, which has been referred to by Senator Collard, was not brought about by the Queensland Government as it was not brought about by the Australian Government; rather it reflects adjustments in the vehicle industry in Australia which flow from absurd levels of protection which have been offered in the past and which have promoted unrealistic growth and competition in that area , which we cannot afford in this country. To blame either the Queensland Government or the Australian Government is simply to compound the absurdities which exist in economic debates in Australia.

The end of the building and construction boom in Queensland merely brought it into line with other States where high interest rates and the general economic downturn have resulted in falling prices and falling demand. If anyone wants to dispute that I think they will have to put up some figures. I have not heard any in this debate so far. Queensland, by and large, is being affected in the same way as other States are being affected, regardless of the political composition of their governments. I think that fact ought to be accepted. Commonwealth payments and Loan Council approvals to Queensland have not been excessive. To be sure, on a per capita basis Queensland gets more than does New South Wales and Victoria, but that is part of the federation compact. Indeed, when one looks at the figures for 1983-84 we find that in terms of population New South Wales gets the lowest amount, followed by Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. In other words, the federation compact is being kept in 1983. The distribution of funds from the Federal level tends to be in an inverse relationship to the population of the States simply because smaller populations still need the same amount of infrastructure. I think that in any economic argument that arrangement ought to be accepted.

Those things said, I do not think that the Government of Queensland cannot be criticised. For example, if one looks at the policy that the Queensland Government has enunciated, particularly in its Canberra bashing, both of the previous Government and of this Government, one will find that it has talked a lot about the necessity of keeping down the deficit. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Queensland's accumulated deficit is over $1,000m, which is almost as much as the deficits of New South Wales and Victoria combined. If the accumulated deficits of State authorities outside the Queensland Budget are added, that figure rises to something like $2,000m. This amount represents the State's public borrowing requirements to be covered by Loan Council funds borrowing and other payments. I am not quoting Queensland Government figures; for the purposes of this debate I am using comparable figures that relate to Queensland and other States. Therefore, one has to take Australian Bureau of Statistics figures.

I think it is important that one looks at the way in which Queensland has managed to keep down its level of taxation by running up this deficit. I am not necessarily critical of a high deficit. I believe, and I have argued previously, that Australia could stand a high deficit. I think the good things that have followed the Queensland Government's action in having a reasonable deficit have been extremely useful for my State. However, I am pointing out that it is pretty absurd to argue on the one hand that Queensland has lower taxes and then suggest it has a lower deficit. It does not happen to have that. Queensland has the same economic structure, by and large, as every other State and the way it functions, as distinct from other States, is to run up an excessively high deficit. We can engage in a reasonable economic argument if we accept those factors. We can then weigh up whether or not we should have high or low deficits or try to run the furphy that Queensland has low income tax and a low deficit. The latter does not happen to be the case.

I turn now to the decline in both price and demand for coal which has been brought about by the world recession. The current revenue from coal producers accounts for about 14 per cent of Queensland Government revenue. This excludes Federal Government grants. If this revenue cannot be increased, and if one listens to the coal producers it is probably at a maximum, the Queensland Government in the following financial year, regardless of which government wins on 22 October, will have to raise taxes or reduce expenditure or let the deficit expand. They are the only economic avenues open to the incoming government. I think it would make a lot more sense if everybody in this place accepted some of the realities of economic argument so that we can conduct a reasonable debate. So far we have heard the suggestion that somehow Queensland has been able to wave a magic wand and do things that other States cannot do. However, Queensland is caught in the same grips and faces the same economic problems as all other States. Unlike other States, Queensland has depended excessively on speculative capital. When the bubble burst the effects were much more severe in Queensland than in other States. Again, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, the downturn was about 50 per cent in real terms in 1983-84. So that dependence on speculative capital, which went way beyond anything that the other States dared undertake, has led to many of the severe problems in development industries in Queensland.

I believe it is more responsible government not to go heavily into speculative capital of the kind the Queensland Government went into but rather to moderate one's demands in that area. Therefore, when the bubble bursts, as it inevitably does, the people who get hurt are not anywhere near as badly hurt as people have been in Queensland. There has been a nosedive, a crash, in my State. That is all it can be described as. I think that any responsible government that takes kudos for the good years, as the Queensland Government has done, ought to take the responsibility for the severity of the crisis which is occurring now. I think that is a responsible proposition to put to any government. To try to say 'We are totally responsible for the good things and the bad things are caused by someone else' is the operation that one finds amongst children in kindergartens and ought not to form part of economic debate.

In addition, the encouragement of foreign investment in the resources area was thought to be a good thing at the time of the boom but similarly is responsible for the severity of the decline that has occurred in my State. In other words, Queensland's economy has been too dependent on speculative capital and too dependent on foreign investment which gave the appearance of rapid economic growth. Queensland did have rapid economic growth in the short term. But this has led to reversals. The Queensland Government cannot escape the criticism for its past actions in that regard and, if it is a responsible government, it ought to accept that criticism and not simply try to shimmy out from under.

I believe that the current breakdown in the coalition suggests something about the state of the whole Queensland operation. If one looks at Queensland parliamentary debates in economic terms one can see that the attitude of the Queensland Government has been much the same in terms of its relationship with Canberra whether under the Liberal Fraser Government or under the Hawke Labor Party Government. The Queensland Government has been ruled by regulation. The Democrats believe that reform at the parliamentary level is of absolute necessity if there is to be reasonable economic growth and reasonable relations between the Commonwealth Government, of whatever political persuasion, and the State government. I do not believe that Queenslanders are well served by any government which seeks to promote itself at the expense of the Federation. I believe that the notion that one can have a stable government without a stable society is excessively bad. I would point only to the example of Russia which has an extremely stable government but an extremely unstable society. I prefer rather an accountable government-a government which is accountable to the people . This has not been the case in Queensland in the last 30 years or, for that matter, the last 60 years. One would hope that on 22 October the people of Queensland will see that there is very little choice in a unicameral parliament other than putting a minority government back into power and having a reasonable group of people holding the balance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Jones in raising this matter of public importance today. It relates to political instability in Queensland and mismanagement by the Queensland Government. It relates to the myth of resource development and growth and the reality that is now the State of Queensland. Lurking behind the glossy veneer of the growth State and the resource-rich State lies the reality of a State that is politically unstable, the reality of a State that is divided and the reality of a State that has a seriously declining economy. The State of Queensland has a narrowly developed and highly vulnerable economy. All that can be sheeted home to the Bjelke- Petersen Government. The economic problems of Queensland are far more serious than just being an internal State matter. The Queensland economy, because of the policies of the State Government and the dominant National Party, is severely retarding national economic recovery. That point should be made over and again. Queensland's economy is severely retarding national economic recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: The policies of the National Party to denigrate the public sector means that the public and private sectors of the economy in Queensland are not working together for State development. A partnership is urgently needed between the public and private sectors in Queensland. The economy there is performing worse than that of the nation as a whole. The blame lies with the Bjelke-Petersen Government, which proclaims good times for Queenslanders but hides behind the economic facts. The facts speak loudly for themselves. Queensland has suffered a far higher percentage rise in the number of unemployed in the past 12 months than the nation as a whole. It has experienced the fastest rise in unemployment in Australia. In the 12 months to August 1983 the Queensland jobless total rose by a massive 63 per cent. It went up from 67,000 persons to 110,000. Over the same period the national jobless total rose at a slower rate of 49 per cent. Unemployment is so bad in Queensland now that the jobless total there is about the same as for the entire population of Townsville. I find it a shocking state of affairs that the total number of people who are unemployed in Queensland is now about the same number as the largest provincial city in that State. In Queensland job vacancies are exceedingly short. In the 12 months to August 1983 the number of job vacancies in Queensland declined from 3,100 to 1,300. That was the worst reduction in the number of job vacancies in any State of Australia in that 12-month period. It was the worst record of any State. Queensland is not the jobs mecca or the home of the good life, as is popularly claimed by conservative politicians in that State.

The tragedy of the jobs crisis in our northern State is indicated by the fact that during this year 78 unemployed people were registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service for every vacancy in the Cleveland area. Similarly, there were 76 unemployed persons for every vacancy at Annerley; 67 at Redcliffe; and also 67 in Cairns. Those are shocking figures. There were 67 persons unemployed for every job vacancy available. It is absolute nonsense to talk about jobs for all. These indicators of the jobs crisis and the tragedy of the lack of job opportunities compare with an Australian figure of 56, so in a number of key centres Queensland is well above the national figure.

The economic position in Queensland is not just indicated by unemployment totals. Let us look at what has been happening in the housing sector where the worst performance in Australia is being recorded. Commencements for new dwellings for Australia as a whole rose 3 per cent in the June quarter compared with the same quarter for 1982, giving hope that building would be one base for a wider economic recovery nationally. Yet in Queensland, commencements actually fell by 12 per cent in the same period. We have a situation where, nationally, dwelling commencements are increasing but in Queensland they are going backwards . There were 900 fewer dwellings commenced in Queensland in the June quarter than in the corresponding period of 1982. For Australia as a whole there was an increase of over 1,000.

Popular myth would have us believe that thousands of people are flocking across the border to set up homes in Queensland. Yet the sun appears to be sinking on the Queensland building industry. If we are to believe that people are flocking across the border, as dwelling commencements are in decline, the conclusion must be that people are forced, in increasing numbers, to live in caravans or some other sub-standard form of accommodation. The housing downturn also shows a clear lack of confidence in the Queensland economy by the residents of that State. No doubt many Queenslanders are fearful of losing their jobs and being added to the swollen jobless totals in that State. Those who fear the loss of a job and a livelihood certainly are not going to purchase dwellings.

The problems of the Queensland economy are very evident in a number of other key areas. Registrations of new motor vehicles are taken by many economic and business analysts as an indicator of consumer confidence and economic activity. The information on new motor vehicle registrations tells the story starkly about conditions in Queensland. In the June quarter of this year registrations of new motor vehicles fell by a massive 18 per cent compared with the same period last year. There was a fall of 18 per cent in motor vehicle registrations in a State which is supposed to be growing rapidly. Nationally, the car industry is also going through hard times, as we know. The decline in registrations nationaly was held at 12 per cent. There was a much higher decline in the number of motor vehicle registrations in Queensland in the same period.

The latest comprehensive retail sales figures underline the problems of Queensland's economy and the lack of consumer confidence there. The figures indicate that retailers must be having a tough time at present in Queensland. Retail sales in Queensland, excluding motor vehicles, grew by only 4.6 per cent from the June quarter of last year to this year. That was well below the national growth in retail sales figures. Again, if we are to believe the claim that people are flocking to live in Queensland, retail sales, per head of population, must be very bad indeed.

The Queensland Government simply cannot have it both ways on the population question. I believe the Queensland people are able to see behind the paradise image of their State which is confected by Mr Bjelke-Petersen. The lack of confidence by the people in their economy and the Premier at its helm is reflected in the general business situation as monitored by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Westpac Banking Corporation in their September 1983 survey. It was clear from that survey that business believes Queensland has the worst general business situation of any State apart from Tasmania. The same survey found that Queensland was the only State in which the majority of respondents expected a decline in output. At the same time, the survey showed that for Australia as a whole the outlook was for an increase in output. The expected fall in output by Queensland business was reflected also in an expected employment fall, the worst recorded for any State, again with the exception of Tasmania.

Today in Question Time there was an interchange on the matter of industrial disputes. It is quite clear that in the last 12-month period the policies of the Queensland Government relating to industrial confrontation rather than industrial consultation and conciliation are having their effect in the labour market. There were 492 working days lost for every 1,000 employees in Queensland in the 12 months to July, compared with an Australian average of only 289. I must say that the figure in Queensland is some four times that of my own State of South Australia.

The Queensland Government, headed by its Premier Mr Bjelke-Petersen, has ignored its responsibilities to the electorate. Its policies have failed and the Queensland economy is floundering. The Premier and his National Party Government clearly have lost touch with the people's needs. The severe problems in Queensland of unemployment, industry decline and the economy are a direct result of the policies of the State Government. Queensland is being brought to its knees by a Premier who is blind to the extent of the economic problems confronting his State. The poor performance of the Queensland economy is reflected in the income per head of population of the State. Per capita income is the lowest in any mainland State. Only Tasmania has a lower income per person . Now we have the prospect of Mr Gray going up to Queensland to campaign for Mr Bjelke-Petersen. I presume that Mr Gray is going to Queensland to show that his State is worse in order to make Queensland look somewhat better, because in terms of per capita income Queensland trails all the mainland States. The low income per head of population in Queensland raises some very serious questions about what happened to the benefits of the so-called resources boom. It would appear that the incomes from the resources boom went elswhere other than to ordinary Queenslanders. Certainly they were not spread widely.

The Bjelke-Petersen Government does not want to be accountable for its economic and finanical failures. When Parliament wanted to debate the setting up of a public accounts committee to make the Government more accountable and to allow the scrutiny of spending by government departments and authorities, the Premier said No. When a member of his doomed coalition Government showed initiative and a progressive attitude towards accountability of governments to the people, the Premier said No, and decided to blow the coalition and go it alone. His Government will not be accountable for its mistakes and economic blunders. We must ask ourselves why. What has that Government got to hide? What is it that it does not want to see the light of day? All other States have public accounts committees. Queensland is over 30 years behind the Commonwealth Government in this very important area for making government responsible and accountable. Queensland must not be allowed to hold back the nation in all areas for the sake of one man's power drive. Mr Bjelke-Petersen has held back the State for long enough. It is time he went for the benefit of the long-suffering people of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened while Senator Maguire read his speech. (Quorum formed) I thank Senator Macklin for attracting an audience for me because I think the things I have to say are quite important. It is interesting that there were only four or five Government senators on the benches opposite when one would have thought with this matter of supposed importance that the benches would be crowded with Government supporters. The dismal quality of the debate speaks mountains for the quality of the Australian Labor Party in this supposed attack on the Queensland Government. It is a humbug waste of the Senate's time because there is no doubt about the figures we have here. Honourable senators from the other side can quote what they like, but if we are talking about instability, why did 85,000 people from other States flock to Queensland? Why do they go there? They go because foreign investment's going into that State, mining is going on, and the State is vibrant with activity. The Queensland Government has the fortitude to stand up to the Federal Government and get on with its own job.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite make me sick. They do not know anything about water schemes. They are not concerned about water resources in Australia. Senator Jones had the gall to get up and talk about the Bradford scheme. Obviously he is ill-informed. He does not know what he is talking about. The scheme he should have referred to was the Bradfield scheme. I am surprised that he should denigrate the idea of turning back the eastern rivers, which are currently being wasted by flowing into the coastal waters of Australia instead of being utilised internally. I am surprised that he is critical of Mr Bjelke- Petersen's idea of pursuing that scheme. Mr Wran, the socialist Premier of New South Wales, instructed his Government only 18 months ago to have a look at the Bradfield scheme with the object of doing a feasibility study into that project. I think those sorts of projects are imaginative and these are the sorts of governments we need to run this country. That is that sort of government that we need to be returned in Queensland. I compliment Mr Bjelke-Petersen for being prepared to go it alone with respect to the Bradfield scheme. He has foresight. He looks ahead beyond the next election. He looks 20 years ahead, and I admire the way he has been able to do that. I admire the way he has been able to control internal disputations in industry in that State. He had the courage to introduce an essential services Act in 1979 and that has been quite successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you admire the gerrymander?
—Order! Senator Cook will please refrain from interjecting.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Cook is making a quite relevant point about the gerrymander in Queensland. Even though it might be out of order, I think the speaker ought to respond to it.
—There is no point of order.

—I ignore inane interjections from the Government benches. I return now to the record of the Queensland Government with respect to industrial disputes. During the first five months of the Hawke Government, 54,900 working days were lost in Queensland because of industrial disputations, 512,700 working days were lost in New South Wales, and 74,800 working days were lost in South Australia. In that time the percentage of workings days lost in Queensland due to industrial disputation represented 6.6 per cent of the total working days, whereas in New South Wales the figure was 61.4 per cent, in Victoria 11.1 per cent, in South Australia 9 per cent, in Western Australia 9.1 per cent, and in Tasmania 2.5 per cent. That is a success story in relation to industrial disputations. Internal migration figures show that in 1980 17,000 people migrated to Queensland from other States, 35,000 migrated in 1981 and 34,607 migrated in 1982. The reverse was the case in New South Wales. In 1980, 2,000 people disappered from New South Wales, 14,963 disappeared in 1981, and 17,626 disappeared in 1982. The figures on capital improvements in Queensland are equally interesting.
—Indeed.

—Indeed. I like that parliamentary term. Everyone seeks to say ' indeed'. I will use that again; indeed. For every person living in Queensland the actual fixed capital expenditure for the 12 months to March 1983 was $1,354. 70. The figure for New South Wales was $999.60 per person. The figure for Victoria was $898.30. Compare that Queensland figure of $1,354 with the other figures. The Australian average is $1,063.40 per person. That again illustrates the success that has occurred in Queensland and should give some confidence to the people of Queensland on 22 October when they re-elect the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Many other aspects of life in Queensland appeal to South Australian's for example. I do not intend moving there, but many friends of mine have chosen to go there. One fellow went to Cairns; he is a real estate broker and a very intelligent person. At the time he was languishing under the Dunstan Labor Government, and he found it attractive to go to Cairns. There is growth there if ever I have seen it. I visited Cairns and there seems to be confidence in that area of Queensland. Another friend of mine is an architect and he moved to somewhere near the Gold Coast. He is employed in establishing a very large housing expansion in that region. All those things speak of a success story.

It interests me when the Labor Party accuses a State government, a so-called conservative government-I think it is a progressive government-of using foreign investment. It is very important that Australia employ foreign investment to develop its resources. I read a report the other day which indicated that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, recognises the value of this. In that report he suggested that it is time we looked at joint ventures between Australia and Asian countries. I think he is quite right. I think it is time that the Australian Government took some positive steps towards the establishment of an economic community in the Asia-Pacific region. If we look at the tremendous population in that area, about 1.8 billion people-and if we look at the capacity of Australia to initiate research and at the capacity of joint ventures with respect to the production that is capable of being achieved in our region of the world, we will see that that is the direction in which this Government ought to be going. I think that is the direction in which the Prime Minister would like to see Australia going. I give him my support because I think he is dead right, but I doubt very much whether he had very much support from the left wing of his Caucus.

I am not sure whether the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, would agree that the economic future of Australia lies in the Asia-Pacific region, but certainly Mr Bjelke-Petersen does. Mr Bjelke-Petersen is attracting attention to Australia. He has attracted the attention of foreign investment to Queensland. Both he and the Labor Government here in Canberra have agreed that foreign capital can be used for 40 per cent of an investment in a coal mining venture in Queensland-I think that is the area, I forget the particular geographical site. Nevertheless, that indicates that there is confidence.

If an industry or business venture is asked to go into South Australia it will say: 'You have a socialist Government there. We cannot mine uranium as we do not think that the Labor Party Government in Canberra will approve, although Mr Hawke said ''Yes, go ahead, we will allow you to mine the Olympic Dam project but we will not let you benefit from the exploitation of the Beverley and Honeymoon deposits''.' There is a very real reluctance by private enterprise to go into a State that is governed by a socialist Government because it knows the inherent dangers that lie there. It knows the philosophy of the socialists to take over government control of this, that and the other thing. Private enterprise has had bitter experience in the past. I recall a large organisation telling me on one occasion that it is sick of operating under a socialist administration and it is contemplating moving off-shore to get away from the influence that that sort of government exerts. Looking at the question of foreign investment proposals by value in the period July 1981 to June 1982, 20.3 per cent occurred in Queensland, which has 16.1 per cent of Australia's population; and of the actual fixed capital expenditure in the 12 months to March 1983, 20.5 per cent occurred in Queensland. In the three years ended in August 1983, 42,200 jobs were created in Queensland compared with losses of 42, 000 jobs in New South Wales, 19,200 in Victoria and 12,300 in South Australia during the same period. In the three years ended June 1983-we have said this before but it is worth repeating-there was a net inflow of 86,661 people to Queensland from other States compared with net outflows of 34,589 from New South Wales, 40,913 from Victoria and 17,420 from South Australia during the same period. Those figures are simple and factual and they demonstrate a contrary view to that which is being put forward by Government senators today-that is, there is not a lack of confidence in Queensland, far from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little confused in starting off my contribution to the debate on the matter of public importance today because I understood Senator Jessop was a Liberal senator. However, this afternoon I am not sure whether he has been speaking on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia of the National Party of Australia. Of course, Queensland is something of a grey area, and I think it is rather surprising that he has not been speaking up on behalf of Terry White. However, the main purpose of today's debate, which seems to have been ignored by the Opposition speakers, is to highlight the instability of government in Queensland, which has led to a failure of that Government to co-operate with the Federal Government to benefit the people of Queensland. That seems to be a point which has been totally ignored by the contributions of Senator Collard and Senator Jessop.

SPEECH.PARA: The present crisis in Queensland reflects a generation of instability and mismanagement. There is no doubt that the accumulative effect of the political climate which has created the confusion that is displayed daily-one has only to read the local papers to see what a total state of confusion and chaos the coalition is in-has resulted in total disruption to government. In fact, at several points this afternoon I considered taking a point of order when people mentioned the Queensland Government. There is no Queensland Government at the moment. The State is relying on a shuffling caretaker and a minority Government. While this is so, the business of government in Queensland is languishing. The situation is that the Queensland Premier is pushing the State Government to its financial limits with his election date of 22 October. Treasury advice was that finances for the Government could be guaranteed only until 19 November. But on Mr Bjelke-Petersen's electoral program the election writs are to be returned on 18 November. A government has to be formed and Parliament has to sit in order to pass Appropriation Bill (No. 2) to release more funds to government departments.

My colleagues on this side of the House have already referred to the fear and concern of public servants that in fact there will be a great deal of confusion if the coalition survives, such as it is-and that seems to be highly unlikely. The Premier seems to think he will be able to form a government after the 22nd. But his optimism is not shared by many in the Public Service. They fear that the election will result in a coalition having to be formed with weeks of wrangling- Queensland is used to that-before Parliament can sit, and never before have the writs from a State election been returned in under 30 days. The business of government in Queensland is in fact coming a very poor second to the machinations of running an election. I quote from an article in the Canberra Times:
The new National Party Minister for Transport, Mr Neal Turner, told his department chiefs on his first day . . . that they would not be seeing too much of him.
He said he would be spending much of the next eight weeks in his marginal western Queensland electorate of Warrego because 'otherwise I won't have the chance to be a minister after the election'.

That is the situation of a supposedly responsible Minister. He would rather be out there campaigning instead of dealing wth the affairs of his Department. Furthermore, the Queensland Minister for Health, the article reported, would be spending much of his time in his marginal electorate of Mount Isa. The article continued:
One of his senior officers described the situation as 'impossible', with major decisions, such as the introduction of Medicare, not receiving the attention they required.

The new Minister for Labor and Industry, Mr Vince Lester, now embarrassed about his featuring in a book about Australian eccentrics told his department he wanted to set up a manpower-planning section, only to be told that the department had had such a section for years.

Perhaps it is these incidents that lead to public servants in Queensland taking a very close look at the Australian Labor Party's policies because frankly that is the party they expect to be dealing with after 22 October. A great many allegations have been made and statistics cited here this afternoon. I would like to talk about people for a moment because I understand that the Queensland Premier and my colleague on the other side of the House, Senator Boswell, are very interested in people. In a book intitled Queensland Achievement, which conveniently came out about six weeks before the election date, the Queensland Premier is reported as saying:
''People'' policies have been encouraged and generated as basic to good government.

The Queensland Premier seems to be concerned with people. Senator Boswell also has said that Queenslanders today have the most desirable lifestyle of people of any State in the nation. However, I will cite some figures dealing with quality of life issues in Queensland. I think that honourable senators will agree that the lifestyle in Queensland is not nearly as good as the statements by the Premier and Senator Boswell would suggest.

I will consider first the health area, general medical services. In this area Queensland has the lowest expenditure of all States-$204.99 per capita. That compares with an average of $231.59 for all the States, with expenditure ranging up to $311 in Western Australia. A crisis exists with regard to hospitals in Queensland. A shortage of nurses is putting lives at risk. Funding for the Queensland free hospital scheme is inadequate. The Queensland Government is in no hurry to finalise the arrangements with the Federal Government. Meanwhile, it has a severe shortage of nurses in its free hospital system. If we look at school medical services, again we see that Queensland has the lowest expenditure in Australia-37c per capita compared with an average of $1.29 for all the States . Queensland also has the lowest expenditure on public health, at a figure of $2 .38 per capita, compared with an all-State average of $5.40.

I turn now to the welfare, which I thought was a people issue. On child welfare again Queensland has the lowest expenditure, with $11.33 per capita compared with an average of $14.38 for all the States. It is really distressing to compare the Queensland Government's expenditure on care for the aged with the expenditure of other States. It is hard to believe that a person who is aged himself would have so little concern for the aged in Queensland. Expenditure on providing relief for the aged and infirm in Queensland is $3.77 per capita, compared with an average of $9.22 for all the States. Furthermore, last year in a parliamentary report entitled 'In a Home or at Home' dealing with care of the aged, it was revealed that the Queensland Premier's Department did not bother even to put in a submission, although that was considered the norm in all other States.

If we turn now to education, again we see that Queensland has the lowest expenditure on a per capita basis. Technical and further education is an area I would particularly like to highlight as we have spent a great deal of time talking about unemployment. There is obviously a tremendous need for training in this area. On technical and further education Queensland is spending $24 per capita, compared with an average of $36 across the States. Secondary school funding is down compared with the other States, at $90 per capita compared with an average of $120 across the States. Again, if we look at culture and recreation we see the lowest level of spending is in Queensland.

If we care to leave those people issues that Senator Boswell and the Queensland Premier appeared to be so concerned about and look at railways, we see that after 26 years of National-Liberal government the railway deficit in Queensland has grown from $11m to more than $200m. Despite this enormous public investment in the State railways, the bulk of goods handling has been passed over to private contractors who are then given privileged freight rates up to 80 per cent below those of other railway customers. Railway jobs are threatened and since July 1982 400 railway jobs have disappeared. A recent analysis of future employment in the railways indicates that if the Queensland Government were to accept the report up to 7,000 jobs could be abolished over the next five years.

I return for a moment to the welfare area to make a few other points. In 1982 the Commonwealth Grants Commission indicated that $23.7m is underspent on welfare in Queensland. Expenditure on children's services which, as I mentioned, is $11.33 per head is 20 per cent less than it is in other States. Child care centres, as we know, are funded totally by the Federal Government. But let us contrast what is happening in Queensland with what is happening in other States which do, in fact, contribute to the funding of child care centres. For example, in New South Wales the State Government provides a 90 per cent salary subsidy to child care centres funded by it, plus a $5,000 grant for operating costs. So child care centres in New South Wales have the advantage of being funded by both the Federal and the State governments. Some 37 after-school care programs are running in the State of Queensland. It absolutely infuriates me to see State members turn up to hand over the cheques because, in fact, those programs are totally funded by the Federal Government. The Queensland Government makes no contribution whatsoever. While the Queensland Government contributes on a dollar for dollar basis to youth refuges, there is no extra funding as is the case in New South Wales and Victoria because those States recognise the tremendous importance of youth refuges.

I could go on with any number of examples that demonstrate that Queensland, when it comes to being a State that is concerned about people, certainly does not put its money where its mouth is. The caretaker Premier is, in fact, living in a fantasy world where he believes it is necessary to lock the doors against the demons from the outside world. He has failed to work with Canberra over a number of years. For almost 10 years now he has rejected money from the Federal Government. He is paranoid about working with another level of government. Of course, coming from local government, I know only too well that the Queensland Premier and the Government there are extremely reluctant to work in with local government. What we should be debating here this afternoon is how we can ensure that Queensland in future is able to work as one of the levels of government, co -operating with the Federal Government and working with local government to benefit all Queenslanders. There is only one party that is able to do that and, of course, that is the Australian Labor Party. Finally, I am not quite sure whether the National Party is misnamed because, from some of the things that have been said over recent weeks it is quite obvious that the National Party is not in fact a national party at all. It is extremely divisive. It is parochial and its leader in Queensland is disloyal to Australia and thoroughly un- Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this debate. As a matter of fact, last night I saw the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and asked him whether he could bring on a debate such as this.
—We got there first.

—The Government got there first, but this discussion gives me the opportunity to put on record just how well the people of Queensland are going by comparison with the other States. The matter of public importance is:

SPEECH.PARA: The adverse effects on Commonwealth-State financial programs caused by the political instability and mismanagement of the Queensland Government in total disregard for the people of Queensland.

Let me tell the Senate that if anyone has been disadvantaged it has been the people of Queensland. If there has been any financial mismanagement, it has been by this Federal Labor Government. I will prove in my speech that this is the case. Before I get on to those points, I want to take up a couple of matters raised by Senator Jones. He had the temerity to speak about the fishing industry and what we had not done for that industry. I will tell Senator Jones what the fishing industry thinks of his Government. Here it is in a Press release: ' Budget-castration, not consensus'. That is what the industry thinks about the present Government. The Press release states:
The commercial fishing industry in Queensland has demanded a complete re- structuring of the first Hawke Government Budget saying it will join the Prime Minister in consensus, not castration'.

It goes on. That is what the industry thinks of the Australian Labor Party. The ALP has just about brought it to its knees with this fuel price increase. It is tax by the petrol bowser. The ALP has nearly brought the industry down.

The matter of public importance that Senator Jones has brought forward is just a political stunt. The ALP campaign in Queensland has run into a brick wall. It has run out of steam. The people will have to choose between 27 years of good, stable, sound, progressive government, as against a leader who promotes the growing of marihuana in back yards. If Labor senators think that the people of Queensland will fall for that they have another think coming. No one in Queensland wants his family to grow marihuana in the back yard. That is the choice that people will have to make-the choice between Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who has led the State, or someone who says: 'Let our kids grow marihuana in the back yard'. No one in Queensland will fall for that. We will go on to the greatest resounding victory that has ever been seen.

In a number of speeches attempts have been made to bring in red herrings, preying on the emotions of the small people, employees and employers, and contractors, perpetrating malicious lies and just proving that Labor's policies are inadequate. They are hopeless. They have failed in New South Wales, in Victoria and in South Australia. This year the Victorian Government has collected $203m in extra taxes. In Queensland we have balanced our budget. In Victoria the shortfall was $487m; in New South Wales the shortfall was $35m; and in South Australia it was $68m. Queensland, since 1859, had had a deficiency of only $750,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe they should spend some on people.
—We spend a lot on people, and the people vote for us and return us. They have done so for 27 years.
—All 28 per cent.

—Twenty-eight per cent. I refer now to the malicious rumours and lies spread about Supply running out in Queensland. I will tell the Senate and the people of Australia what the correct program is and what the state of the Government in Queensland is. I shall read it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . supply available to the Government for July and August this year, under a previous appropriation, totalled $1.560 million. 'On August 3, 1983, in line with normal practice, State Parliament placed a further Appropriation Bill totalling $2.345 million to provide supply for a further 3 months', the Treasurer said. 'Thus in the first five months of this financial year, supply totalled $3.905 million.' Additionally, quite sizeable sums of State expenditure such as public debt payments are permanently appropriated and did not require supply. 'The Treasury Department has been monitoring the situation very closely and expenditure to November 30 is running well within Government estimates.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the Treasurer now?

—The Treasurer is the Premier. Does the honourable senator think that he would lie about that? Of course he would not lie. They are the figures that come from the Treasury Department. Let us get on to the wage pause program. That program is a bureaucratic nightmare. Queensland was waiting to allocate the first funds from its $42m entitlement under the scheme, but the Commonwealth has still not given formal approval to the State's Consultative Committee which is required to evaluate the project. Forty projects were being assessed and the first batch of these was expected to be approved at the next meeting of the Consultative Committee. This is the basis on which the Federal Government formally ratifies the composition--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. How can the Consultative Committee have met when the Queensland Premier is reported by Senator Button in this place--
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Reynolds, you have been here long enough to know that that is not a point of order.

—This is the basis on which the Federal Government formally ratifies the composition of the Committee, which includes representations of State, Federal and local government as well as representatives of women, Aboriginals, youth, welfare groups and the Trades and Labour Council. Let us take, for example, the community employment program. This scheme is a bureaucratic nightmare, as I have said. The red tape is enough to turn a saint to hard drink. Let us look at some of the provisions: Sponsors have to contribute 30 per cent of the project cost and women are to have 50 per cent of the jobs. We cannot even wait until the legislation comes through. The Consultative Committee has not been finally accepted. Queensland is waiting on advice from the Federal Labor Minister in regard to the Aboriginal representative. We put up an Aboriginal, but he probably was not one of Labor's boys. Queensland nominated Lew Stewart from Cherbourg, but he is unacceptable. Why is that? It is because he was not nominated by the National Aboriginal Council. It does not know or cannot decide who should represent its interests.
—Say that again.
—Do not give him another serve, Ron; just ignore him.
—All right, I will ignore Senator Colston. We have done everything in our power to get this program off the ground.
—Senator Lewis, you must not interject when you are out of your seat.
—I want to get on to the wage pause program, because the Senate should know exactly what has happened with that program. I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to table a schedule.
—Is leave granted? Senator Boswell, do you wish to table it or to have it incorporated in Hansard?
—I want to table it and have it incorporated in Hansard.
—You wish to incorporate it in Hansard.
—What is the Government being asked to do, Mr Deputy President?
—Senator Boswell is apparently seeking leave to incorporate a document in Hansard. Is leave granted?
—We want to know what it is. It would be courteous of Senator Boswell to consult the Government.
—I think it would be courteous, Senator Boswell, to pass it to the Government side. It can be incorporated at the end of your speech.

—What it says about the wage pause is that the Queensland Government's action on the Commonwealth wage pause program has provided more unemployed people with jobs than any other State. The Commonwealth's own statistical data shows that despite all the propaganda dished out by the Federal and State ALP's spruikers, Queensland created work for 2,743 unemployed persons under the wage pause program up to 31 August, and by the same date Queensland had spent $7.4m out of a total of $15.9m-more than any other State. In Victoria, the electoral back yard of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the State had created a miserable 874 jobs by the same date. Victoria has spent only $700,000 out of $ 26.3m received, and New South Wales spent $7.3m out of $35m received. A total of 2,251 unemployed people have been placed in jobs in New South Wales and only 874 in Victoria. In other words, Queensland has spent more than any other State, placed the highest number of unemployed workers, and spent by far the highest percentage of any money received. That commits Labor criticism, this Government' s unsubstantiated statements and the Prime Minister's utterances on the wage pause right into the garbage can, where they belong.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine a few other areas in which this Federal Government has helped Queensland. Let us look at the public hospitals. Queensland is seeking compensation for public hospital patients equal to the per capita average being paid to States-$50 per head; not merely $29 per head. You have short-changed Queensland by $31 a head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has done that?

—The Labor Party has done it. Then Labor senators say that we will not co-operate. Of course we will not co-operate when you are taking the money from us and robbing us. We will stand up and fight for what is ours.
—Direct your remarks to the Chair, Senator Boswell. I am not short-changing you.

—Let us have a look at welfare housing. As the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, has said on a number of occasions, the Government in Queensland should be disposed to provide more housing construction . He should move to rectify the allocations of welfare housing funds going to Queensland from the Commonwealth. Queensland's share of such funds this year was $20m less than it should have been per capita. With that extra money the State should have been able to provide an additional 600 dwellings for welfare housing throughout the State. Again we were short-changed, again honourable senators opposite ask why we do not co-operate and again we say that we would love to co- operate but the Federal Government keeps robbing us.
—You want to speak again. This is good stuff.

—The honourable senator should listen to what I say. The Medicare scheme will be a beautiful benefit for Queensland! Queenslanders will be paying one per cent of their total wages for something they now get for nothing. I am sure they will appreciate that! That is good business!
—Are you sure you have got your figures right?

—I have got my figures right. It is plain to see that the Federal Government does not care for Queensland one little bit. The Queensland people are not socialists. They will return a conservative government. The Federal Government has ignored them, it has written them off and the people will respond on 22 October by returning the conservative Government led by Premier Joh. Queensland has created 45,000 new jobs over the last three years. In Queensland, the home of private enterprise, Budgets are constantly balanced. The State's accumulated deficit in the consolidated revenue fund since 1859 is only $769,000. This is at a time when the Budget deficits of other States are running at around $4,000m to $5,000m. Because of the application of sound private enterprise philosophies, the Queensland economy has grown at a rate significantly faster than the Australian economy over the last 10 years. In this regard, Queensland's gross State product has increased over the past 10 years at the rate of 4.7 per cent per annum in real terms compared with 3.1 per cent per annum for Australia as a whole. Not only has Queensland's overall economy grown at a faster rate than the economy of the rest of Australia, but every single sector of the Queensland economy has grown at a faster rate over the last 10 years than the corresponding sector in the Australian economy. This is an outstanding achievement of the Bjelke-Petersen coalition Government in Queensland. The Australian Labor Party would do well to take up this successful private enterprise philosophy. Mr Deputy President, with the Queensland election looming this House has degenerated into a coward's castle for people who are politically opposed to the Queensland Government. These people are making statements which are without credit or which are inaccurate.
—I call Senator Colston.

—A point of order, Mr Deputy President. I think that Senator Boswell's speech is one of the best I have heard on the state of the economy in Queensland and I ask the Senate to extend Senator Boswell's time by three minutes.
—Do you seek leave to move that motion?
—I ask the Senate to extend the time. It does not require a motion .
—You said by three minutes.
—Leave is not granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Boswell from speaking for a further three minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes Senator Chaney's motion. Senator Chaney gave no reasons at all as to why Standing Orders should be suspended, so I do not feel that I have to give reasons why we object to it, except to say that it is a political stunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, says that there are no reasons for supporting this motion, but let me just say that ever since the announcement of an election in Queensland we have heard the greatest lot of nonsense in the Senate from Government senators about the state of the economy in Queensland. TALK.START.PARA: — The spectacle we have just gone through was a deliberate attempt to stop a member of the Government speaking for a full 15 minutes. I point out to those listening to the debate that two hours-
—I take a point of order. I do not believe that on the speakers list that was circulated Senator Colston was ever mentioned.
—There is no point of order, Senator Collard. The speakers list is informal. Senator Colston has the call.

—I point out to those listening that two hours are allowed for the debate. The debate is due to finish at 9 minutes past 5. If we had not had that division, I would have had a full 15 minutes. I now have about five minutes . That was the ploy of the Opposition, an Opposition which does not want to hear the truth about the Queensland Government and the absolute mess that the Queensland Government is in.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Australian Labor Party lost government in Queensland in 1957 the incoming Premier was Mr Frank Nicklin, a member of the then Australian Country Party. He was often referred to as 'Honest Frank'. Sir Francis Nicklin's Party has since then changed its name. Nevertheless it has experienced an unbroken term of government since 1957. After 26 years the term 'honest', the term that was used to describe Frank Nicklin, is the least likely adjective to be applied to the Queensland Government. In fact, the public of Queensland regards the Queensland Government as anything but honest.

How could that word be applied to a government whose Minister in charge of racing owns a major racing stable? How can the term 'honest' be applied to a government which uses taxpayers' funds during an election campaign to place misleading newspaper advertisements against the Federal Government? (Quorum formed) What credibility can be given to a government which has allowed Parliament to sit for a mere 14 days and 10 minutes in 1983? What credibility can be given to a government which plunged into crisis because it refused to establish a public accounts committee and which clings steadfastly to a grossly malapportioned electoral system? The Queensland Government's outrageous behaviour on a number of fronts makes legendary banana republics appear saintly. There is nothing to suggest that this state of affairs will alter if Mr Bjelke- Petersen remains Premier after 22 October. In contrast, the Labor Party Leader in Queensland, Keith Wright, has promised that he and his parliamentary colleagues will take Queenslanders in a new direction. A Labor government resulting from the Queensland election in a little over a week from now will offer stability. It will offer accountability, responsibility and credibility to the Queensland public. A change of direction of this nature will be a refreshing change.

Since 18 August this year Queensland has been governed by a minority Government . There is nothing wrong with minority governments if they have the confidence of the parliaments to which they are responsible. But the minority Government in Queensland does not have that confidence. The Queensland Parliament last sat on 9 August, and when it did so it sat for 10 minutes only. Thus, in all the time that the minority Government has existed, Parliament has not been in session. There has been no opportunity for members of that Parliament to express their confidence or lack of confidence in the Government which is administering that State. Parliament has been rejected by the minority National Party Government as merely of nuisance value, an institution which has to be consulted from time to time only to obtain Supply.

How did this state of affairs develop in Queensland? Ever since the non-Labor force came to power in Queensland in 1957 the National Party and the Liberal Party of Australia have governed in coalition. The Nationals have always been numerically stronger than the Liberals; thus the Premier has always come from the National Party and the majority of the Cabinet positions have also gone to that Party. (Quorum formed)
