TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to papers Nos. 3 and 4, I seek leave to have two statements incorporated in Hansard. The first statement relates to the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the second statement relates to the annual report of the Special Prosecutor.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows-
Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated
Ship Painters and Dockers Union-Interim Report
No. 5, Volume 1
The volume that I am tabling is part of the fifth interim report of the royal Commission on the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which was established on 10 September 1980 by Letters Patent.

The Commission has previously delivered four interim reports. The first and second interim reports dealt with unfolding investigations. On the advice of the Royal Commissioner, Mr F. X. Costigan, Q.C., they were not tabled. The third interim report, which dealt largely with fraudulent taxation schemes was tabled on 25 February 1982-its recommendations have been implemented. The fourth interim report dealt with bottom of the harbour schemes: volume 1 of this report (with two paragraphs excluded) was tabled on 24 August 1982 and an edited version of chapter 10 of volume 2 was tabled on 7 September 1982. Again on the advice of the Royal Commissioner, the remainder of this report was not tabled to avoid prejudice to individuals and to investigations.

The fifth interim report, with which this statement is concerned, is in three volumes. Volume 1 outlines the general structure of the report. Two chapters make some general comments on Commissions of Inquiry and on a National Crimes Commission. These have already been released publicly for the recent National Crimes Commission seminar in Canberra on 28-29 July. Volume 1 then concludes by listing the recommendations that appear separately in Volumes 2 and 3.

Volumes 2 and 3 deal with a major criminal scheme in relation to the income tax legislation. Volume 2 is a ''sanitised'' summary of volume 3. Volume 3 gives in great detail the names, dates, companies and financial transactions of the participants in this scheme.

Mr Costigan states that his investigations have now reached a point where he perceives a need for some legislative and administrative action. Mr Costigan says that he sees no reason why volumes 1 and 2 should remain confidential but concedes that there is a possible view that publication of volume 3 could impede fair trials. Volume 2 was prepared as a summary of volume 3 with a view to the publication of volume 2.

The Government has given very close consideration to the question of which parts of the fifth interim report should be tabled at this stage. In its consideration of this question the Government has been mindful of the public interest in making available as widely as possible findings and observations that support recommendations by a Royal Commission. The Government has also consulted with the Victorian Government and with the Special Prosecutor, M. R. Redlich. It has taken careful note of the views expressed by Mr Costigan on this point.

However, the Government has concluded that the public interest would be best served at this stage by tabling only volume 1 or the fifth interim report. It feels that the publication of volumes 2 and 3 would present a risk of prejudice to the fair trial of certain persons who have already been charged with certain offences in relation to matters discussed in the report and of certain other persons who may be charged. In addition, there is also a risk that publication at this stage might impede further investigations that are being carried out into matters that have been raised by the Royal Commission. Once all trials have been held the Government will consider whether it would then be in the public interest to table any more parts of the fifth interim report.

The Government is examining the recommendations that are summarised in volume 1 . Relevant Commonwealth Departments, in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory where necessary, will complete their studies of the report and make recommendations as to action on it within three months. If the Government decides that legislative action will be necessary, it will provide information as to the reasons drawing on relevant information that has been provided by the Royal Commission.
Annual Report of Special Prosecutor Redlich

Mr R. F. Redlich was first appointed as a Special Prosecutor under section 6 of the Special Prosecutors Act 1982 on 21 October 1982 for a period of 6 months. That period was subsequently extended by a further period of 6 months ending 21 October 1983. I propose to recommend a further extension of 6 months or the date when the first Director of Public Prosecutions is appointed, whichever is the earlier.

Mr Redlich's first mandate was to deal with alleged illegal activities identified by the Costigan Royal Commission, other than those activities being dealt with by Special Prosecutor Gyles, namely 'bottom of the harbour' tax evasion matters. Subsequently, I authorised Mr Redlich to deal with the activities referred to in Interim Report No. 7 delivered by the Stewart Royal Commission in November 1982.

Mr Redlich has now delivered an Annual Report covering his first year of operations in which many matters are canvassed. The first nine chapters deal primarily with the activities of Mr Redlich and his staff, some of the more important matters emerging from this discussion including the following:
The material coming to his notice was not of such a special nature as to require a prosecution independent of the control of the Attorney-General.
Mr Redlich has accordingly not felt inhibited in calling on the support of the Attorney-General's Department and the services of the Crown Solicitor.

The vast majority of the 'alleged illegal activities' reported upon to the Government by the Costigan Royal Commission before Mr Redlich's appointment remain in the area of 'intelligence' which may, on the discovery of further evidence, become viable prosecutions at some time in the future.

Accordingly prosecutions will flow from a very small number of the matters originally identified by Mr Costigan; as to the matters subsequently identified by Mr Costigan, a higher proportion will give rise to prosecutions.

As to matters arising from reports of the Stewart Royal Commission, Mr Redlich reports that his office, in conjunction with the Victorian Director of Public Prosecutions, recently completed the committal proceedings of an associate of Terrence John Clark identified in Interim Report No. 7. A variety of civil remedies are under consideration by his office.

Mr Redlich has been able to reach apparently satisfactory arrangements with the Victorian Government for co-ordination of efforts but arrangements with New South Wales and Queensland have been less satisfactory.

In paragraphs 4.5 and 4.6 Mr Redlich mentions that I invited him to serve as a Commonwealth representative on an inter-governmental committee to coordinate prosecution action flowing from the recommendations of the Stewart Royal Commission, set up by the Commonwealth, NSW and Victorian Governments. At its first meeting (which Mr Redlich attended) arrangements were agreed upon for coordination of prosecution action: these arrangements have been put into effect and appear now to be working quite satisfactorily. However, the matter is being kept under close scrutiny by the Commonwealth Government and, if any difficulties arise, prompt action will be taken to deal with them.

In chapter 10, Mr Redlich recommends establishment of a Director of Public Prosecutions. He also recommends that the DPP should be empowered to take civil remedies in relation to criminals whom he is prosecuting. At this point, I would mention that the Government has decided to establish a Director of Public Prosecutions to deal with Commonwealth offences and I can say that Mr Redlich's suggestions as to appropriate powers for such a person will be carefully taken into account in formulating the Government's proposal.

In Chapter 11, Mr Redlich makes detailed recommendations for establishment of a National Crime Authority. The views he advances are most constructive and have been taken into account by the Government when drawing up its own proposals.

In Chapter 12, Mr Redlich discusses how he has exercised the functions given to him to coordinate and supervise the taking of civil remedies for enforcement of tax liabilities in the areas assigned to him. I have brought Mr Redlich's remarks to the attention of my colleague, the Treasurer.

Difficulties and deficiencies in the enforcement of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations are discussed in Chapter 13. I have brought this discussion and Mr Redlich's recommendations for changes in the law and administrative practices to the attention of my colleague, the Treasurer.

In Chapter 14, Mr Redlich discusses the role that the Telecommunications Commission should in his view exercise in combating illegal bookmaking activities. In paragraph 14.11 the correctness of an opinion given by my Department that the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 would prevent the attachment of a device on the telephone of a suspected member of a bookmaking ring is queried. My Department has reviewed that advice and I am about to examine the results of that review. I have brought Mr Redlich's observations as to the role of the Telecommunications Commission to the attention of my colleague, the Minister for Communications.

Paragraphs 14.18 to 14.33 discuss difficulties that have arisen as to proof in Court of intercepts of telephone conversations. Satisfactory arrangements now appear to have been made and I do not need to comment on past misunderstandings.
In Chapter 15, Mr Redlich sets out a number of views of the Australian Federal Police and its proper role. I have brought these views to the attention of my colleague, the Special Minister of State.

Mr Redlich in Chapter 16 recommends changes in the law in quite a number of different areas, ranging from a uniform Evidence Act to amendments of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Customs Act 1901. So far as these laws come within my Ministerial responsibility I have directed my Department to make a careful examination of Mr Redlich's proposals and report to me on each of them. As regards laws discussed by Mr Redlich within the responsibility of other Ministers, I have referred Mr Redlich's proposals to the relevant Ministers.

The Report reveals a busy and fruitful year of office dealing with what in many cases amount to serious breaches of the law. Quite an amount has been achieved but much remains to be done. The experience gained in the year's operation will be very useful indeed in establishing and defining the continuing tasks of the Director of Public Prosecutions.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIA'S POPULATION FORECASTS FOR 1983-86 WITH PROJECTIONS FOR SELECTED YEARS TO 2021

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a very important paper. It deals with Australian population forecasts for 1983-86 with projections for selected years to the year 2021. The importance of this paper can be underlined by the fact that it is prepared with the assistance of a population consultative group. Page 1 of the paper which outlines the background notes states:

In response to a recommendation in the Report on the Commonwealth Government and the urban Environment by the house of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, the Population Consultative Group co-ordinates the preparation of population forecasts. The following Commonwealth departments and authorities participate in the Group:
Australian Bureau of Statistics
Bureau of Labour Market Research
Department of Housing and Construction
Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
Department of Social Security
Department of Territories and Local Government
Industries Assistance Commission
Social Welfare Policy Secretariat
Of course, it then goes on to say:

On the basis of these discussions the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, which has responsibility for population policy matters within the Commonwealth Government, selected the assumptions to be used in this set of forecasts/projections. The Australian Bureau of Statistics then prepared the figures using their projections program.

Against that background it is very interesting to note the projected figure for births, for example, fertility rates and the net reproduction rate. If we look at the net reproduction rate we are down to below zero at the moment. The projection for the year 2021 is that the net reproduction rate will be well below zero. That has significant effects for the aging nature of our population and also has significance in relation to defence and other areas of importance. Before I deal with that, I should like to look at the very interesting projection rates for life expectancy. The actual life expectancy rate at birth as at 1981 was 71.4 years for males and 78.4 years for females. The projected life expectancy rate for the projected year 2021 is 73.4 years for males while it is projected that the ladies will live until they are 82.6 years of age.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the male rate?

—It was 73.4 years. Of course, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and her colleagues-perhaps I should say cohorts- with their affirmative action and the like are going to put a dent in that projection and ensure that there will be some equality in that particular regard . If it were not so serious, it would be funny. In fact I assume that that will be the inevitable result of the economic pressures placed on mothers to go out against their will into the paid work force by the use of affirmative action programs and, of course, the sort of scatter-brained ideas that that involves which, of course, are not appropriate for any person genuinely interested in sex discrimination legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the point that is made in the population figures which deal with populations at young ages. It is most interesting and informative to understand the median age of population now and the median age in the projected year of 2021. The median age now of population in Australia is 30.13 years. The median age for the year 2001 will be 34.9 years and the median age for the year 2021 will be 38.58 years. It is quite significant for people to have a look at these population forecasts. Time does not permit me to examine all of them now. I commend this paper to honourable senators for study. No doubt many honourable senators have studied it in particular, I commend to the general public a study of the figures, the underlying assumptions and the implications of the figures of populations for the future of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am attracted to this report entitled 'Australia's Population Forecasts for 1983-86 with projections for selected years to 2021'. I am minded to remember the projections that were produced a few years ago by the Borrie Report on National Population Inquiry and by committees which have met since then. For those of us who are interested in social policy and in trying to look into the future in order to develop policies in particular areas, these figures are an important tool. One of the things that has happened is that it is clear that the figures which were produced, for example by the Borrie Committee, in the light of experience have turned out to have certain inaccuracies in them. One of the consequences of using and depending upon these figures is that one is likely to make errors. For that reason, it is important in this particular document to go to the beginning and to have a look at the assumptions which have gone into the production of the figures and the assumptions which have been set out which are really caveats on the figures people are asked to attend to. I would like to mention them because they illustrate just how difficult it is for anyone using these figures to place too great a degree of confidence in them. I do that against the background that I am grateful for the figures. I do it against the background that I am grateful to the department that has produced them.

SPEECH.PARA: At page 1 of the report under the heading 'Interpretation' a number of statements are made. I will outline several of them. In relation to international migration, it is stated:
. . . the assumption for the next three years represents the likely outcome of present policy. However, it must be recognised that this is subject to change . . .
It goes on to explain the ways in which that is subject to change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—That is fair enough, Senator, but if we are to sit down and use these figures with any degree of confidence we have to do it against the background that in most of the past few years that assumption was incorrect and I think in years to come it is likely to be incorrect. There are likely to be changes in policy and likely to be changes in migration. It makes it very difficult. The report then says that the other assumptions underlying the forecast deal with long term arrivals to Australia, permanent and long term departures, fertility and mortality. I suggest that all these are variables about which we cannot have great certainty. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: For these variables a best estimate has been made on the basis of currently available information. However, beyond the next 3 to 5 years these figures are also really projections rather than forecasts.

The difficulty is that people wanting to take these figures and derive assertions from them, which they would present with great force, should do so with the utmost caution. We have experienced in the last decade our demographers , using the assumptions available to them, working on the best policy guesses that they can and making the best assumptions about likely events getting it wrong again and again. The reports of those demographers have warned us, as this document does, that the assumptions underlying their mathematics are subject to change. I am one of the many people who want figures like this for the policy work we do or for trying to understand changes in Australia. But I draw the attention of those who may be reading this document to the large number of assumptions underlying the figures and the very great uncertainties which must go into the figures and which should underline any interpretations people make from them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak because of the extraordinary comments which Senator Peter Baume has just made. I would have thought that the report on Australia's population forecasts was a very valuable document which could not be ignored. Some very important decisions can and should be made as a result of that report, including the one that the Government made. If Senator Harradine's understanding is correct and our population growth is below zero, it is fairly obvious that we will have to make some very hard decisions about immigration.
—Just a degree of caution is all we are asking for.

—We will have to make those decisions. I am trying to say that the document is a very valuable one. I have the impression that the honourable senator denigrated and weakened that document by inferring that the assumptions weakened it. They do not. In fact, I think the assumptions in the first part of the document strengthen it. The document tells us that because of these projections it will be necessary for us to make some very firm decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous reports brought down by the demographers were ignored by governments. We were late in starting to reverse training programs in the education area and as a result we had a shortage of teachers when we needed an increase. This arose through misinterpretation of the demographers' reports in the past. My view is that the documents are sound but politicians' decisions, based on previous documents, have been unsound. We have to be careful with this document. We have to make certain that our decisions, based on those projections, are sound decisions. What Senator Harradine is saying is correct. If our population growth falls below zero we will have the awkward situation in which the numbers of our retired people dependent on social security will be on the increase and the number of those who have to maintain them will have been reduced considerably.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to be old, Senator.

—I suppose we could have the good old fascist approach. We could get rid of the elderly and the infirm and so solve the problem. Since we are not fascists and we do not take inhumane decisions, we have to make decisions through legislation, which will cope with the problems that the document reveals . I am suggesting that on this occasion Senator Harradine may be more right than is Senator Peter Baume. I say to Senator Harradine that I find it very hard to come to that conclusion. I find it a little uncomfortable to do so, because Senator Baume, in all these areas, has shown both restraint and humanity. Maybe I am pushing the subject a little hard at the moment, but the Opposition brought me to this point by making statements which weakened the impact of a very important document.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

As one would expect, this is a very important report, coming from Mr Costigan. It is a very small report but it is part of a major report. In fact it is part of three volumes, two of which the Government has decided not to table because they deal with details of a criminal syndicate and mention many names. Clearly, prosecution activity will occur as a result. However, this report has two very important chapters which discuss the nature of commissions of inquiry and what is required of them. It also contains a very valuable chapter on Mr Costigan's views about a crimes commission. In addition it has a number of recommendations on which the Government has not yet formed a view. I take it that when it does, the Government will make a full statement to the Parliament and that will be able to be debated properly and not in the five-minute exercise we have today.

One important thing about the report of Mr Costigan is clearly his very strong support for a national crimes commission with full powers similar to those that he has exercised as a royal commissioner. I believe that it is most important that this report be read very carefully with a very responsible attitude, particularly by the members of the Labor Caucus. We already know that the Government has been watering down proposals which are contained in the National Crimes Commission Act. It is now promoting in Caucus, as I understand it, a watered down version. It is perfectly clear that the Caucus of the Labor Party will water down even the mild proposition that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has put to it. I think it would be very salutary reading for every member of the Caucus to look at what Mr Costigan has had to say about the nature of organised crime and the imperative way in which it must be tackled. The only way in which it can be tackled on a national basis is by a body with the proper powers to do so. He points out very clearly the difference between sporadic unorganised criminal behaviour and organised crime. He makes it clear that organised crime cannot be attacked in the ordinary way. The report states:

Before it is confronted, challenged and brought under control, a great deal of information is required as to the identity of its personnel, the nature of its activities and the methods of its operations. It is only with that knowledge that a successful plan of attack can be prepared and put into effect. The gathering of information and its analysis calls for authority, power and ability .

Mr Costigan and his Commission have proved that that is required. The great amount of information which has become available from the Costigan Royal Commission is a result of the powers it had, the ability of the people working under Mr Costigan and the resources that were made available to him. Incidentally, all that was done by the previous Government. It is pleasing to note that Mr Costigan acknowledged that fact in the report he made last year, the most famous of the Costigan reports and perhaps the most famous report that has ever been tabled in Parliament on any subject. Mr Costigan acknowledges the very strong and satisfactory response of the previous Government in tackling and acting upon his recommendations. He points out-certainly this has been the problem with all royal commissions in the past-that there has not been the proper machinery for acting on the recommendations in a timely way. With the establishment of the special prosecutors, with the much greater co-operation which has occurred as a result of his report last year, he believes that we are now on the right track.

Clearly what is required in the future is a proper institutional arrangement such as a national crimes commission which can have the power to investigate and whose investigations are followed speedily and effectively by prosecution action when that is required and can be established. Therefore, as I said, this report is a most important one. Mr Costigan's recommendations are most important. I hope that the Government will be giving them early consideration and telling this Parliament what it intends to do about them. But most important of all, he emphasises the tremendous problem in this country of organised crime and the fact that it has to be tackled in a national way by a body of prestige, power and authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what inspires me today that has not inspired me on other days. However, I feel the need to speak on this report because it seems to me that Commissioner Costigan has timed the report in order to influence the debate in this place. I do not doubt that that is his right. However, it would have been much more considerate on his part if this report had been part of a substantial report to the Parliament instead of its being a small interim report of this nature.
—It is part of a substantial report. The honourable senator should read the tabling statement. There are two other volumes that we have not been able to table because they are confidential.

—That is a pity, is it not? If we cannot have the other two reports the value of this report is rather diminished. If the Minister is saying to me that there are two other reports which are substantial but which are not before us and therefore we have to accept-
—You are lucky to have got that report. We have not even seen that.

—It so happened that I asked for the report. I have five minutes in which to speak to the report and I would like to do so with the usual interruptions to help me along. But let me sound a note of caution. There seems to be the impression that there is very little opposition to the establishment of a national crimes commission. There seems to be some influence which endeavours to overemphasise that impression. There is considerable opposition to what Commissioner Costigan has recommended in his interim report. Perhaps the report may bring some further information to the debate which is now taking place within the party rooms and which will eventually take place here. But I think we ought not to forget that substantial opposition has been expressed. It was not minimal opposition, as some people would like to infer-imply, I should say-and others infer.
—That is good. You sound like a lawyer.

—Yes, that is what lawyers do to allow their thinking to catch up with their words. Senator Withers put me on to that track, but let me get back to the point I wish to make. At the same time as we read this report we ought to bear in mind the substantial criticism of the desire to establish a national crimes commission. I would like to attract honourable senators' attention to the fact that there has also been considerable criticism of commissions in general. I think it was Senator Withers who once said, when opposing the establishment of a particular royal commission, that he advised the Prime Minister of the time to be careful of appointing royal commissions because they take on a life of their own. That is quite correct. They take on a life and a term of their own. I am beginning to fear that the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union may be in that category; I am certain that the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies is in that category. We are now plagued by a whole series of commissions, both Federal and State.
—You need one overriding commission. That is why you need a national crimes commission.

—As I say, there has been a suggestion that another royal commission should be established. My view is that we have too many royal commissions. I could not, of course, express this concern in words such as those that were used by Justice Murphy of the High Court. I refer honourable senators to his opinion on the variety of royal commissions and how, instead of protecting the rights of individuals, they actually challenge, and in some way limit, the rights of individuals. If one needed an example of this one could perhaps refer to the position in which David Combe, a private citizen, finds himself now-that is, being under very close and rather tortuous scrutiny by a royal commission in a way that I did not think anyone in this country would permit. So I suggest that we should bring balance into our considerations of these matters and merely accept this report as a further opinion to which to refer during our debates on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should state briefly for the record that there is no substance whatever in any suggestion that the timing of the tabling of this report was somehow deliberately contrived , either by Mr Costigan or the Government, to coincide with any particular debate that is now occurring. The truth of the matter is that the two chapters of this report that are likely to generate most attention, those relating to the arguments for a crimes commission, were publicly released back in July at the time of the two-day conference in this chamber. It is a purely formal exercise to table them, with the other recommendations, on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just briefly add one other point in response to the formulations of Senator Durack on this subject. I found rather fascinating his passion for the particular model of crimes commission advocated by Mr Costigan in this report, given that the Fraser Government's own model for a national crimes commission when introduced last year was very significantly different in its structure and more particularly its powers and the limitations on those powers than the model actively proposed by Mr Costigan. It is not the case that either to the last Government or to the present Government-particularly in the context of Senator Durack's contribution I emphasise the words 'the last Government'-there should be a body with powers as stringent, as far reaching and as indifferent to civil liberties considerations as that that Mr Costigan tends to prefer.

Let me finally say this: I believe that it is necessary and appropriate that there be some better form of co-ordination and organisation of the attack on organised crime in this country than we have managed to achieve by the ad hoc series of royal commissions and other exercises of this kind in the past. But what is obviously extraordinarily important is that very careful attention be devoted to the detail of any such proposal and that there should be a very careful balance between the powers and the limitations on the power of any such organisation, for the kinds of reasons that Senator Georges among others has clearly indicated. It is exactly that detailed examination that is proceeding within the Labor Government at the moment and the Government, in this respect, is behaving no less responsibly than any government would behave in that endeavour at this stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is of such significance that I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Mr Redlich is one of the two special prosecutors who were appointed about this time last year as a result of the previous Government's response to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and under the Special Prosecutors Act which was passed through the Parliament at that time, again on the initiative of the previous Government. The role of Special Prosecutor is a new one for Australia. The special type of problem that was presented as a result of the Costigan report clearly called for that type of response. As I said, Mr Redlich was appointed to deal generally with breaches of the criminal law which were revealed by the report of Mr Costigan. The other Special Prosecutor, Mr Gyles, was appointed to deal specifically with the major but discrete problem of the bottom of the harbour schemes.

The exercise that Mr Gyles has embarked upon is one of very considerable magnitude. He has been given, very properly, considerable staff. We look with interest as to what will result from his inquiry. However, Mr Redlich found that there was not really sufficient basis for his appointment as a special prosecutor because he was dealing with a very generalised area of criminal offence. Indeed, he reported that he did not find there was sufficiently developed material in the beginning for prosecution purposes. Nevertheless, the experience that he has had over this 12-month period-I am pleased to see that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has extended his term to some extent -has been very valuable because it has given him an opportunity to look at the problems presented by the criminal activities which were revealed in the Costigan report. He has been given several other special assignments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate under Sessional Orders has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table additional information received by Estimates Committee D and seek leave for it to be incorporated in the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the ninth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Dairy Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1983, the Meat Inspection Bill 1983 and the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) 1983.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 September 1983, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a statement made by the Minister for Aviation and Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) entitled ' Australian Electoral Office, Education and Enrolment Campaign'. I understand that it is the intention that the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and this statement be considered together by means of a cognate debate.

—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering this statement and the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today we are considering a report which was brought down some weeks ago by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The first thing I wish to say is that the report, whilst I think it is an adequate one, on all occasions does not necessarily give an explanation for every recommendation that the Committee eventually came to. I point out the problem we had in terms of time. We were given a task that would have taken a normal standing or select committee two years to complete. We had to complete the task in four months. Nevertheless, I think the report is quite adequate. In part I think that is due to the hard work of the staff of the Committee. I wish to give them credit today for the work they did in preparing this report.

SPEECH.PARA: I also acknowledge the work that all Committee members from all political parties did. The attendance record at the Committee hearings and at meetings held to write the report was remarkable. There was virtually no absenteeism. The experience which the Committee members brought was of great assistance. We had a former Minister responsible for matters now handled by the Department of Administrative Services in Mr Hunt. We had a former Leader of the Government in this chamber who had served also as a State secretary of a major political party . A State secretary of a party on the other side of politics, the Labor Party in New South Wales, served on the Committee. We had a former Premier who had been responsible for electoral reform. All of these people brought expertise. I must say that at times that expertise was embarrassing to witnesses rather than anyone else. At times it occurred to me that the Committee knew more about electoral reform than those who were giving evidence.

I am not in any way disappointed that there are several dissenting reports at the back of this report. The Select Committee was not sent away, I think, to get a unanimous view. It was sent away to inquire into a matter and to come back with a number of views. I am in no way disappointed that we did not come back with a unanimous view because politics is about different points of view. On a subject with such breadth as the one which we considered it in no way surprised me that different political parties and individuals took different positions. I believe there was a need for this inquiry. At the time it was set up I think there was some thought that each member of the Committee would go in with a set piece position. To an extent, I guess that was true throughout the whole inquiry . On a surprising number of occasions people conceded some ground from their normally held views and did seek, in a sense of compromise, to come up with solutions which were acceptable to all groups.

There is a need for electoral reform in this country. At the turn of the century, in the early 1900s, Australia led the world in electoral reform. I do not think one could claim that this is the case at this point of time. There have been virtually no major advances in the area of electoral reform in the last few decades. There was a major attempt in the period from 1972 to 1975 to reform the electoral legislation but, given the combative atmosphere that existed in the Parliament at that time, it is not surprising that most of the legislation was seen as partisan, as an effort to entrench power in the existing Government and, therefore, was not passed. Since 1975 we have had many promises of electoral reform. Those promises never came to fruition.

The electoral legislation is complex. At this stage I pay tribute to members of the Australian Labor Party who have pressed ahead in this chamber-I mention Senator Gietzelt and Senator Sibraa-their interest in electoral reform. I think they will be very pleased at most of the results in the report.

The Committee will continue to look into certain areas that we were not able to consider in depth. Firstly, later this year and early next year we will be looking at political advertisements, whether there should be free time, what restictions should apply, whether spot advertisements should be banned, the length of advertisements and so on. The Committee will be looking also at the vexed question of tax deductibility of political donations in all their forms. Members of the Committee started to discuss this but never came to a resolution of it. It is a very important and complex area and one on which we hope to come down with a recommendation next year. The third area which the Committee will look at is the industrial election function of the Australian Electoral Office. The Electoral Office conducts many union elections. The Committee did not touch on that matter at any stage during its inquiry.

The Committee's report is a complex one. I do not intend in a period of 10 minutes to try to describe or justify what is in the report. I can only make this comment: We spend hours in this chamber on parochial claptrap. When we receive a report to which many members of the Senate are interested in speaking we are given merely 10 minutes in which to speak. I do not know who is to blame for that. I have been a member of the Standing Orders Committee for some time. I think that in this case the system beats us all. There is nothing we can do about it.

I wish to comment on a few key features of the report. If one has read the papers one will be aware that the key feature of this report is the concept of an expanded parliament. In actual fact, this matter did not figure largely in the thinking of the Committee. It was an incidental recommendation. It is not the key recommendation. If one asks any Committee member one will find that probably he would not have listed it in his top five or 10 reforms. It was a recommendation that a majority of members of the Committee made because they felt, from the evidence available to them and in the interests of Australia as a whole, that we would be best served by an expanded parliament. Everyone who thought that knew what the reaction the public would be. They knew what the reaction of the Press would be. They knew of the sort of anti-parliamentarian Philistinism that exists in Australia. The majority of members of the Committee thought that it was necessary for at least someone to say what he thought about it rather than duck the issue. It is now up to the Executive of the Government to come up with a decision. Then the matter will go to party rooms and so on to consider whether it will be introduced eventually.

I was very interested in the reaction of the Press. Some of the more responsible Press-I suppose they are responsible by my definition because they agree with me-gave the concept a fair hearing, but others jumped on the band- wagon and said that more pigs would be added to the trough, that the parliament would get an extra 36 politicians, et cetera. I want to put only one thing on the record. Since 1949 there has been no increase, apart from in the Territories , in the number of members elected to this place. The same number of members are here as were here in 1949 in spite of all the expanded tasks that we have been given and the increase in population. The Press Gallery-I do not include my friend up there-has increased fourfold in that time. There are four times as many Press people accredited to this Parliament now than there were in 1949. Yet , in actual fact, the numbers in this place have not expanded. I can draw two conclusions from that. Either we have increased our ability fourfold in terms of productivity and what we do, or-I hate to draw this conclusion-the Press is only a quarter as adequate as it was 34 years ago in 1949. But I stress that the whole debate around electoral reform does not hinge just on the concept of whether we should have more politicians.

One of the first recommendations we made-I have only limited time to mention it -related to the establishment of an independent electoral commission. It is here that I think we basically have unanimity. We believe that we should have an independent electoral commission. As members of the Committee we are genuine about its being independent. I do not use the word independent meaning that then we stack it full of a particular government's supporters. That, in the long term , whoever is in government, would do them damage because it is as inevitable as death and taxes that governments change. We recommend that three people be on the Australian Electoral Commission. We recommend, not surprisingly, that the membership of the Commission include the Chief Australian Electoral Officer as a full-time executive officer, a Federal Court of Australia judge who should be chosen by the Chief Judge and who has hopefully served at least three years on the judiciary, and a First Division public servant. Honourable senators may ask why a First Division public servant should be on this Commission. It is essential to put someone on the independent Electoral Commission who has no further to go in his career. If we start putting people on the Commission who are at the bottom of the Public Service and whose future promotion depends on the favours of the Government we will never get a degree of independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an agreed recommendation.

—Yes, it is an agreed recommendation. Unless there is that sort of mix and unless there is trust of the Electoral Commission, then democracy will not in any way be enhanced in this country. We expect the independent Electoral Commission to oversee all aspects of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, to supervise public funding, to supervise disclosures of donations, to supervise the disclosure of expenditure, to register political parties and to be in charge of redistributions and the whole gamut. I end on that point. I have probably just put my toe in the water in terms of what the report has said. No doubt when we get on to the second reading of the electoral Bill, hopefully this year, we will be able to put that point of view at greater length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight speakers are listed to address the first report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Of those eight senators, four are members of the Committee. I am the first person who is not a member of the Committee who has had the opportunity to speak. I would like to put on record that this first report is a major report and has been a major exercise. The report is an important one and it reflects great credit upon the Committee and upon the Parliament for what has been possible. It is comprehensive, thorough, well-argued and the amount of consensus that was possible and which was obtained on matters which are difficult and which one would think would attract polarisation and disagreement have been a notable achievement for the Committee and for its Chairman. The areas where there were disagreement have been presented in a way which will aid public discussion and debate. I pay tribute to the Committee for the areas where there has been agreement. I hope that there can be the maximum bipartisan or multipartisan approach on these matters. Also, on those matters where there has been disagreement, I ask people to give the closest attention to the different views that have been expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the parliamentarians who were not members of the Committee I would like to express thanks to the group. I would like to express my thanks to Dr Klugman, the Chairman of the Committee, for what was a remarkably frank, as well as skilful performance. I hope honourable senators will forgive me, but I have in front of me page 1299 of the record of proceedings. I am attracted to this example of just how frank and honest Dr Klugman could be. A question was asked about what the possible consequences of contributions to political parties might be. I will read a little bit of the transcript. Senator Sir John Carrick asked:
I am seeking to ask whether there is any such evidence.
That is, evidence of undue influence. The Chairman answered:

Let me say, because I think you would probably agree with it, and it is one of the black points in Labor Party history in recent years, that at least three members of the Labor Party-Whitlam, Combe and Hartley-at one stage solicited half a million dollars for the Labor Party during the 1975 campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—No, I want to make a point about the honesty of the Chairman. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think anybody in Australia being aware of it would, after that, have considered that the Labor Party's vote at the United Nations or wherever would not have been biased on that particular issue. You cannot get better evidence than the evidence that has been revealed.

That displays a remarkable and, I think, very praiseworthy tendency to bring out the facts in this Committee even where it may have been difficult. Honourable senators and honourable members who were on the Committee did a remarkable job. Mr Ian Harris, the secretary of the Committee, and the secretariat also have done a good job. They had the pleasure of spending most of the winter here in Canberra. We all like Canberra; we like the winter. But most of us have the view that the Canberra winter is something to be sampled a little bit at a time. These hardy souls spent most of the winter here. This document is a testament to their work and effort.

I select from the report a few interesting points. The first is the ready acknowledgment in the historical work in the first chapter of the partisan considerations which have been part and parcel of the history of Australian electoral legislation. The report sets out many of those examples. It sets out some of the examples from both sides of politics. It sets out some of the examples from my side of politics which we do not find attractive. It reminds us of the time when one took an alphabetical position on the ballot paper. It talks about the four Australian Labor Party senators, Amour, Armstrong, Arthur and Ashley. Those were four people whose names began with 'A'. They served in this place. That was part of a history over many years. That historical document, in itself, is something I have never seen produced before and it will be a useful source document.

The report also expresses its confidence in the capacity and the efficiency of the Australian Electoral Office. It does that in a measured way which I welcomed and I am sure the Electoral Office will be pleased to have that statement of support and confidence.

It seems to me that the goal of an electoral process has to be to produce an electoral system that is fair, equitable, efficient, workable and free of corruption. If this report helps us to get towards a system which more closely meets those goals, I will be happy. I would like to have a system which sees that any party that gets more than 50 per cent of the vote will assume government in whatever election it is competing.

If I had a criticism of this report it would be that, if one looks at what it has to say about the basics, about the type of electoral outcomes it wants to achieve and about the electoral goals it is pursuing, this is the area where it is perhaps most silent. If there is a weakness in the report it is, to my mind, a lack of any statement of any national electoral purpose or goal or a clear statement and declaration of the kinds of goals that should be achieved. I say that against a great degree of praise and support for the report. It will certainly help us in working towards an electoral system. But, nowhere could I discover that statement of goal or purpose which might have provided the conceptual context within which people will work.

It has been an admirable historical account and a careful analysis issue by issue. But the conceptual context has been hard to discover. The debate that will ensue when the particular enabling Bills are introduced or if the Parliament wishes to consider the issues which are raised, will need to be extensive, and it will be vigorous. The report does not pretend that there is agreement on every issue and neither do I. I recommend that those Australians who want to read this paper should read just as carefully the agreed recommendations. I think Senator Harradine and I are in agreement here. They should read the recommendations which are agreed, just to make sure that the process has been honest and that the agreed recommendations are themselves worthy of support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said it was a fix-up between the parties.

—I did not agree with that. As to the areas of disagreement, I do hope that there will be the closest examination of each of the issues. I confess to a personal concern about the question of polling hours-a very small matter for most but for someone of a minority religious faith it is not a small matter. It has direct consequences for the observant members of several religions. We should not actually have elections on Saturdays, but if we are to have them on Saturdays I hope the Parliament will examine very carefully any measure that would make it less possible for those who wish to cast a vote personally so to do.
—What day would you say?

—In some other countries elections are held mid-week and the process works perfectly well. I can see no real reason why the Sabbath day of any religion should be chosen as the day on which we have our polling. That is one of the points that are covered in the report and to which I hope people might give a little attention. Again I say that this report, this very substantial document, is a tribute to the work of the Committee. I assert that the dissenting reports display the same high standards of argument and intellectual content that mark the rest of the document. I look forward to the debates that will follow on each issue. Honourable senators will know that my Party is not disposed to agree to some propositions, but in general there is a considerable amount of support for what has emerged. I believe the report has been a real service to the community and to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to address some remarks to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I begin by supporting Senator Robert Ray, one of my colleagues on that Committee, in thanking all of those other members of the Committee, those other hardy souls who spent several months here during the winter. This Committee met day after day, week after week, during the recess. They were long days, but I do not think any of us ever stopped enjoying them. I found it, in all, a fascinating and rewarding experience. For a start, it was the first parliamentary committee upon which I had spent a lot of time and therefore it was a learning experience for me. I was fortunate to have around me at that table a number of senators and members who could teach me a great deal. I refer for a moment to our Chairman, Dr Klugman, known for bringing a certain individualistic flair to Caucus debates at times, much to the chagrin of some of the people on our front bench, especially someone close to me now. Nevertheless Dr Klugman displayed that flair in abundance for several weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Those honourable senators interested enough to look through the voting records of the decision-making processes of the Committee will find very often, even on the most contentious of subjects, where there were votes of six to three and five to four, strange names indeed make up the three, six, four and five. Party lines were not adhered to, even on some of the most contentious of the Committee 's decisions, even those decisions that will bring the most debate here. Senator Sir John Carrick's years of experience as a party offical, let alone as a senator and Minister in this place, were of great benefit to all of us. I particularly thank him for that. He and I, as party secretaries, formed something of an apparatchiks club and I think we were successful in helping along our respective party machines and making their lives a little easier in the future. Of that we are proud. I might say we failed in some of our endeavours. We were not always successful. Some of the less enlightened members of the Committee tended to vote us down on occasions. Nevertheless, we did our best.

Mr Steele Hall, who showed a lot of courage when he voted himself out of office in South Australia in getting a proper, fair and honest system of redistribution going in that State, again was a very valuable member of the Committee. Senator Robert Ray, who spoke earlier, I think has an encyclopaedic knowledge of this subject. I have not met anyone yet who has a greater knowledge of almost everything that is in that report. John Scott and Alan Griffiths also showed a great deal of interest. Ralph Hunt too showed courage, enterprise and, again, an individualistic flair. I came away from that long and arduous winter enlightened and I hope heartened at the future of the Parliament, given the display of the individuals on the Committee.

Having said all of that, unfortunately I have to agree with Senator Ray in saying that 10 minutes is inadequate even to begin to cover what is in this very long report. Senator Peter Baume mentioned the polling hours and the difficulty that some people have. That was the subject of a very long debate in the Committee. I think honourable senators will find that, whatever arguments are put up in this place or in the House, they were well and truly canvassed on the Committee which finally came down with decisions. They might not all be right, but nevertheless I think most of them are.

The only issue I want to address today in detail is that of public funding, which was one of the more controversial issues covered by the Committee. Submissions on public funding were received from a host of individuals and organisations. In favour of public funding were the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats, the 'A Call to Australia' Coalition-the Family Action Movement as it is sometimes known-the Communist Party of Australia and a host of others. Against us on the matter of public funding we had submissions from the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. Both of those parties, however, in putting up submissions which were opposed to the principle of public funding, also outlined the sort of system they would like to see brought in if the Committee and eventually the Parliament were to accept that public funding was the right way to go.

There were many arguments for public funding, but I think I can summarise them in a few moments, especially those of the Labor Party. The first and, I think, most important argument is that no party should be able to buy an election. That is covered to some extent in this report, and it is something that has concerned me as a party official for many years. When I looked at television campaigns during elections, when I looked at newspapers or listened to the radio, it was always apparent to me that my Party had very many fewer advertisements in any of those sections of the media than its opposition. I cannot believe that over time that is the right way to go. It is true to say, of course, that sometimes political parties, be it those on the other side of the House or my own, can rig up some pretty dreadful election campaigns, and the more time they spend on television the worse they will go. Given that we cannot do very much about that at the moment, I think it is still fair to say that over time no party should have a monopoly on big spending in election campaigns. That would mean that some elections would be bought simply by weight of the supporters' money. That is not the right way to go in a democracy, and I hope it is not the way the Parliament sees it in the coming months.

If the Government is the main source of funds for election campaigns, then any suspicions about who gives money and for what purpose will tend to go by the board, and that is something I hope we will see. There were a number of objections to public funding. The first was that public opinion has always been strongly against it. In reply to that, I remind honourable senators that in New South Wales that subject has already been an election issue. In the lead up to the election in New South Wales in 1981 it was a big issue. A campaign was run in our media and there were full page advertisements in the Sydney Morning Herald. The Liberal leader for the first part of that year, John Mason, made it his big thing for the first few months. He did not survive very long as leader, not many of them have in New South Wales in the last seven or eight years. His replacement was Bruce -

TALK.START.PARA: —MacDonald.

—I thank Senator Ray. I was finding it hard to remember that one. Bruce MacDonald did not last very long either. He also made the matter of public funding an issue. The point is that we won 69 out of 99 seats. It never got off the ground as an issue in New South Wales. It will not get off the ground as an issue in a national election either. The other argument that there are higher priorities for scarce funds can be advanced to try to stop any new initiative of government, be it public funding or any other new area at all. The other tack taken was that parties will have less voluntarism if they are relying on the arms of government. In New South Wales there has certainly been no lack of activity on the part of the rank and file of the parties since public funding was introduced only a couple of years ago. To that was added the argument that the administrative costs of a system of public funding would be so great that they would tend to make governments think twice about their worth. That argument does not really stand up either. As the evidence showed from Joan Adams, who came along from the New South Wales public funding authority from which she has just retired, the costs in 1982-83 were only $90,000. This involved the employment of only four people, two of whom were employed for only a short period.

SPEECH.PARA: The system that the Committee in its report eventually went for with respect to public funding is in fact nowhere near as complex, as demanding or as ardous for participants as the New South Wales system. Therefore, again, I think that we can effectively dismiss that argument. The Iraqi money affair referred to by Senator Peter Baume is a matter I also wish to mention. When one is asked the question 'Why should there be public funding?', I think the answer is: 'To be sure there is not undue influence from a foreign power, from multinationals, from trade unions or from anyone else because, if the parties are reliant on government funds there will be fewer and fewer questions asked.

The last matter that I wanted to go over was simply the level of the threshold. The Democrats argued that there should be no threshold. We finally decided on a magic figure of 4 per cent, which was used in a number of our other decisions. The basis for that decision was that we could not allow those parties that might be seen to represent a ratbag fringe to bring the whole system of public funding into disrepute. We thought that there had to be some reasonable threshold and the figure of 4 per cent, I think, will allow small parties their fair share of the public funding cake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform I also add my thanks to the secretariat for the enormous amount of work it did in such a short space of time and to the other members of the Committee. For my part, I found it a trying experience but one which I ultimately found very rewarding. Like Senator Richardson, I learnt a great deal in that Committee about the operation of political parties and about how things are done at different times and in different places. I also share with him the view that the debate which we will have here has been rehearsed very thoroughly already by the Committee. Various contentious issues will arise and I am sure there will be quite a furious debate on this matter. Indeed, I expect it will make the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill and the Sex Discrimination Bill look like pious exercises, because seemingly nothing excites parliamentarians quite as much as electoral reform or standing orders. If we could debate those matters together I am sure it would be a very interesting time.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time available to me I do not intend canvassing any of the issues that are contained with the report. Rather, I will look at the other statement which has been handed down because I believe that, interestingly enough, the issue that we were grappling with in the Committee was addressed in the ministerial statement put down by the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) probably in a more direct way than in the report of the Committee. The Committee in its report looked at a variety of changes of a machinery kind. The statement handed down by the Special Minister of State, which we are also discussing at this time, essentially looked at the problem of getting people involved in the electoral process. If people do not see the machinery as being responsive, as being useful or as meeting their needs, no matter how geewhiz or whizbang that machinery is or how close to making a perfect result it might be, we will not have achieved anything in a democratic sense.

The disappointing thing about the Minister's statement is that it does not actually go to the very heart of what the Australian Electoral Office found out when its officers went around and interviewed many people who were not on the rolls. Time and again the people who were not on the rolls said that they considered the electoral process irrelevant and ineffective. They saw their relationship with the Parliament as very tenuous indeed. The unfortunate thing about it is that the suggestion then flowing from that inquiry, in terms of interpretation, was that these young people were apathetic. I do not happen to believe that that is a correct diagnosis or interpretation to be drawn from the evidence.

What one ought to draw from the evidence is that by and large young people saw themselves as powerless in our community. If one accepts that interpretation there is a completely different remedy: If one sees people as apathetic, what one does is simply administer more of the same because it is their fault. If one sees people as powerless then what one must do is suggest that it might be the fault of the people who run the system or of the system itself. I think that is probably a far better way of looking at what those young people were telling us in their responses. They were telling us that their relationship to what actually goes on in this place is very tenuous indeed. An advertising campaign will do absolutely nothing, for example, to make political parties fulfil the promises they make in election campaigns. Surely when people vote they say: ' That is what a political party is promising. I will go out there and I will vote for that party'. Then when the party gets into power and they find it does not implement its election promises their response is: 'Well, what's the use?'.

I believe that in any reasonable, dispassionate argument with these people they would have the better of the debate. There is a very tenuous connection. I am certainly not advocating that people stay out of the political process. I have always advocated that they be involved in that process. But let us not push them aside with the rather patronising comment that they are apathetic. They are not saying that at all. They are saying that they are powerless. They are appealing to us, the people in political parties, the people in power, to look at our role and what we are doing and whether or not we ought to smarten up. I think that is a far better interpretation of the response of the young people than the rather patronising statements that were made in the ministerial statement, namely, that we are to have another advertising campaign to jolly them along and suggest to them that voting is a good idea.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you approve of the expenditure of $3m?
—No, I do not. I will come to that matter shortly.
—Wouldn't that argument apply to the older people as well?
—Yes, it does.
—Why can't we just have voluntary voting and be done with it?

—There was a voluntary voting discussion in the Committee. As I remember it, Senator Sir John Carrick and I were the only members who actually supported the notion of voluntary voting, so we did not get very far with that one. I think, in this circumstance, that we have to look very clearly at what young people have already told us. The reason I am talking about young people, I point out to Senator Harradine, is that by and large we found that the people not enrolled fell very heavily into the younger category under those findings of the--
—It is easier not to enrol.

—Yes, that is true. But I think that when one looks at the Committee report one can see that the Committee has attempted to address itself to the first step along the way to electoral reform. The next step is to look at parliamentary reform in an effective way. That is a much more difficult thing. It is probably not something that can be legislated for. It is something to which political parties have to address themselves. In the fullness of time there will probably be fairly dramatic changes compared with the position we are now in. One only has to look back 60 to 70 years to see that this House was totally different then from what it is now. Possibly in 60 or 70 years it will be a totally different House again. I do not believe that we should think that what we have now is the end product, and that it will always remain. But the types of evolutions and changes that would ensure that we end up with a better House in 60 years time will take place only if the people who are currently here address themselves to the issue and try to look at ways to make the system better and more responsive to the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems that must necessarily be met is that of political parties. It was not something to which the Committee was able to address itself as it fell outside its parameters. But I assure Senator Harradine that in the discussions-and I am sure that other members of the Committee would be able to back this up-time and again the problem of the independent was brought up, and people from all political parties there sought to make sure that the decisions being made were not being made in total disregard of the fact that in Australia many people stand as independents and many people are elected as independents and have been elected as independents since Federation. Every political party which was represented on that Committee and members of every political party looked at that issue as the various matters came up. It is an easy jibe to make, but it is an unsubstantiated jibe towards the members of the Committee, to suggest that they did not look at the very real issues and serious difficulties in a party dominated system for those people who stand outside of party systems.

The Committee's report will, in the next month or so, ensue into legislation, and it is at that time that we shall have a serious and thoroughgoing debate on the many issues raised. But I am confident that much of the Committee's report and many of its recommendations, if not the totality of the recommendations, will find their way into legislation. Having been a member of that Committee, I am confident that it will be to the benefit of democracy in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the members of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform on the report. It is a real milestone in Australia's electoral history. I congratulate them on the comprehensive range of recommendations made in the report. Electoral reform is long overdue in Australia at the national level. This country was once a world leader in electoral reform. In the nineteenth century the major reforms were the product of the pressures brought by the working class movement. In 1856 we had the introduction of secret ballots in Victoria and South Australia; in 1894 we had votes for women; and at the turn of century we had equal electoral boundaries for the House of Representatives, which, unfortunately, have deteriorated over time into unequal boundaries and a diminution of the principle of one vote one value.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially our electoral laws in Australia at present are nineteenth century laws written for small electorates where individual votes could be more easily influenced by a single candidate. In recent decades conservative government inaction and community complacency have let us fall behind world reforms. There has been no major overhaul of the Commonwealth Electoral Act since Federation. In the 1974-75 period the Labor Government, on a number of occasions, tried to reform the electoral laws but was frustrated. We need reforms urgently in this country because our voting system is among the most complex in the world. As a result of this report we can again become a world leader at national level in electoral reform.

One of the major recommendations of the report is the proposal for the independent electoral boundaries commission. I think that can go a long way towards providing a more accurate correspondence between votes cast for parties and the seats obtained by them. At present the system is very rough and ready. In the 1980 elections we had a situation in which the coalition got 50.2 per cent of the two-party vote but got a 23-seat majority. That was a large majority in relation to a very small margin. We have large disparities in our Federal electorates at present, particularly in the State of Queensland where they vary from 105,000 in Fadden to 65,000 in Kennedy, and clearly there has been a departure from the principle of one vote one value in the Federal electoral boundaries. This system, to a degree, is modelled on the system which has been operating in my State for some time, where electoral boundaries have been drawn by an independent commission since the mid-1970s. There is now public confidence in the system. I am pleased to say that both major parties have won elections on the boundaries drawn by those commissions.

The other major reform that appears in the report is the proposal for reforming the Senate voting system. I am a strong supporter of the list system of voting for such elections. I also endorse the proposal in the report for the electorate having a choice between the list system and exercising an option to cast votes under the present system of voting. I think that in South Australia, where we had the list system in operation for two upper House elections State-wide, in 1975 and 1979, the list system of voting showed its great worth in reducing informal votes. In 1979, for example, the informal vote for the Legislative Council in South Australia across the whole State was lower than the informal vote for the House of Assembly. The upper House informal vote was only 4.4 per cent, which is a remarkable achievement in Australian electoral history.

I am a strong supporter of any system which will reduce the informal votes in elections for this House. It is clear that many electors are frustrated by the present voting system for the Senate. As I have pointed out before in this chamber, at the 1983 elections the number of informal votes in New South Wales by itself was adequate to elect one senator. In Victoria this year also the number of informal votes would have been adequate to elect one senator. Nationally informal votes for the Senate in 1983 were the third largest block of votes in the elections.

In the Port Adelaide electorate this year, in two polling booths we had the amazing situation, under this voting system which compels people to put down scores of preferences, of some 27 per cent of the electorate casting informal votes for the Senate. That is an outrageous result. Those people are having their votes frustrated. Looking at the area we found that a number of the people who were being forced to cast informal votes because of the complexity of the system were either aged people or migrants from certain countries who had language difficulties. Any improvement in the system would advantage those people enormously.

I also support very strongly the proposal for party affiliations to appear on ballot papers against candidates' names. At present there is some lack of information on party affiliations of candidates in Australian elections. This reform would bring us into line with the United States, New Zealand, Canada, France and Norway, which all provide for party affiliations to appear alongside candidates' names on ballot papers. It is also very important to note that the report contains a proposal for doing away with alphabetical listing of candidates on House of Representatives ballot papers, a very small but important reform. For example, at the elections in 1980 the coalition's 23-seat majority came from winning 12 marginal seats. In nine of those the conservative candidate was ahead of the Australian Labor Party on the ballot paper-a statistically unlikely result.

I also endorse very strongly the proposal to have the Australian Electoral Office move its activities more into the area of voter education. At present the Australian Electoral Office gives priority, as it must under the Act, to the actual process of registration and enrolment for voting. I think that not enough attention is paid to voter education instruction activities in Australia. There is no doubt that a great deal can be done to reduce informal votes if people are given some assistance in how to vote correctly. In my State in 1980 the Labor Party operated a pilot project involving door knocking and assisting people with voting, for the upper House particularly, and we were very pleased to note that in the western suburbs of Adelaide in particular there were very large reductions in the informal vote and throughout the whole State an 11,000 reduction in informal votes, whereas for most other States there was quite a significant increase in informal voting.

I support the proposal to increase the size of the Parliament. There has been no increase in the size of this Parliament since 1949. Since that time the size of the Ministry has increased by 70 per cent. A larger back bench resulting from an increase in the size of the Parliament would strengthen Parliament's independence in relation to the Ministry. Also, there would be a larger pool of talent from which to choose the Ministry. Since 1949 the range of responsibilities carried out by the Commonwealth Parliament has become more diverse, and this had put greater responsibilities and work loads on back benchers. That is a very important fact to bear in mind when advocating an increase in the size of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the Senate is debating the first report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I was privileged to be a member of that Committee. The report itself is of some 322 pages, without, of course, all the supporting evidence of many hundreds of pages. It is a report which makes 130 substantive recommendations and at least as many minor ones, so quite clearly one cannot comment upon them all within the compass of some 10 minutes.
