SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was asked to look at the whole of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to see what reforms ought to be made to that very complex Act, to look at the report of the Harders Committee of Inquiry into the Disclosure of Electoral Expenses, to look at the public funding of political parties and the disclosure of donations, and many wider matters. Clearly, those matters are of enormous scope. The Committee has been made a standing committee and will move to wider things than those I have mentioned. The journey was an interesting one, as other senators have commented, and I acknowledge the comments of the preceding speakers, particularly Senator Ray and Senator Richardson. The Committee worked very hard and to great lengths under skilled chairmanship and I commend the input of my colleagues on the Committee.

The Committee looked at a wide range of matters. A lot of them were matters that over the years have needed to be brought up to date. I should acknowledge and commend the work of the Commonwealth Electoral Office and its senior officers who gave us very valuable advice and the benefit of their experience. I commend those who gave evidence, and I commend to those who are interested in the whole electoral process the evidence and the documentation which will go far beyond this report and will provide a library of information for those studying the procedures of democracy. So I do acknowledge all those who contributed by way of written and verbal evidence, those who came as skilled advisers, and the secretariat.

The Committee has made a wide range of recommendations, many of them of very great interest to the electorate. I refer to the new proposals to put the registered names of political parties on ballot papers and to ballot for positions so that candidates are not in alphabetical order. There is a whole host of such recommendations. There are some very contentious matters in the report. For example, some matters get to the heart of quite complex issues. I do not want to be in any way contentious because with every one of these issues there is a respectable view on both sides. It is very important to understand that. There are some great issues. Public funding and the disclosure of donations led to an important series of principles having to be thought out. They are not unconnected, for example, with the recent disclosure here of ministerial pecuniary interests, and one can see the difficulties when one directs oneself to that. The size of the Parliament is a huge and complex matter because one cannot direct oneself to that without looking at the relationship between the size of the Senate and the size of the House of Representatives and whether we wish to maintain that nexus, whether it could be broken by referendum , whether in fact increasing the size of the Senate would be a good thing in itself and, depending upon the numbers, whether it would be manageable or would simply create a deadlock situation. I say these things to sketch the magnitude an the nature of the debate that will take place when the legislation comes before the Senate.

I personally indicated that I felt that at least for the time being the Houses of Parliament should not be increased in size. I will expand upon that view in the future. I want in due course to express a view in the negative on some of the key issues. That is not to say that there are not some 80 or 90 issues with which I concur; that is to be understood in view of the magnitude of this situation. For example, I would want to argue very strongly that we should not reduce the polling hours to 6 p.m., not only for religious reasons but for other very valid reasons. Eight per cent of all electors have chosen over the years to vote between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. and we should be in business to aid the electors not hinder them. In due course I will express very strong views against the proposal for a list system in the Senate. In my judgment, the recommendation in regard to that system will simply complicate the procedures; it will bring in much more difficult problems than have arisen in the past and will do nothing at all to help. Those things are just problems and I repeat that they should not obscure the fact that so many of the recommendations coming before the Senate will find unamimity of opinion from the whole of the Parliament.

As to other matters, I will be strongly arguing against public funding and against disclosure, not because I want to hide something but, to the contrary, because I think we will be looking at great principles, such as whether one can legislate for honesty or whether one must look towards honesty in terms of a code of integrity for parliamentarians. In any case, the worst of all worlds would be to pretend that we are achieving honesty when in fact we may be putting up a veil. I simply say those things to give an impression of the width of debate we will have when the legislation comes before us.

This report covers such matters as the redistribution of electoral boundaries, how they are to be changed and how that will be done in an objective way. It ought to be said, and said publicly, that over the post-war journey, the last 40 years, there has been ample evidence to suggest that Federal electoral redistributions have been honest and have served both sides of the Parliament well. In other words they have expressed a fair system for the people of Australia. It is not a question of looking to tidy up something that has been bad. What we are doing is looking to entrench an honest system for the people.

I make a final comment in this very short speech. So much of what was done in this report was in fact delimited by one thing, that is, that the majority view of the Committee, a view that I do not share, was that compulsory voting is a key factor. Once it is decided that there should be compulsory voting-once it is decided that people will be compelled to go to the polling booth and actually vote-then an enormous number of adjustments have to be made to the Electoral Act itself. One then has to ponder the imponderable. When we know there is a donkey vote of a very significant percentage and that the margins of election results are no bigger than the donkey vote why is it that we want to compel people who do not want to vote-they may in fact cast a vote that may be quite irrelevant as far as they are concerned-to cast a vote? Why should we introduce a whole system of compulsion instead of trying to develop a responsible democracy. Australia is one of the few countries that has compulsory voting. I believe that a much better and fairer system would operate if voluntary voting were established. I commend the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allocated under the sessional order for consideration of committee reports has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (SIMULTANEOUS ELECTIONS) BILL 1983CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ADVISORY JURISDICTION OF HIGH COURT) BILL 1983
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (REMOVAL OF OUTMODED AND EXPENDED PROVISIONS) BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was talking about the nine Constitution Alteration Bills that are before the Senate. I indicated my opposition to the Constitution Alteration ( Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1983, consistent with the views I have expressed over the years. That is now history. I still believe that the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill does present some danger to the authority of the Senate. Therefore, I will be opposing that Bill and will vote against it in the Senate at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that the founding fathers of Australia-they had been presented with the wishes of the States which said that they would agree with Federation provided the Senate was established, thereby giving the States equal representation-carefully drafted the Constitution to protect the interests of the States for that very reason. On the last occasion the people were faced with a decision in this matter of a referendum, Senator Peter Rae wrote an article on the significance of this measure. I would like to quote a few paragraphs from it . He said:
Politics has a tendency to be subjected to over simplification and sloganeering .
Complex issues are treated as if their complexities did not exist.
The two controversial referendum questions, which are those relating to the Senate, have certainly been subjected to that treatment by the proponents of the 'yes' case.
I shall endeavour to tread the path between undue complication and over simplification.
He went on to say:

Let me refer briefly to the history of our Federal System. When the separate colonies joined together to form one nation they did so with a considerable degree of mutual suspicion. They also recognised that the far-flung nature of the small population on our huge continent made desirable that State Governments be retained and further that the two biggest population areas (Sydney and Melbourne) would dominate the national government. The agreement to federate was therefore subject to carefully drafted provisions to limit the powers of the central government and to provide two powerful checks upon it to prevent it from taking power from the States.

These two checks were, (1) a written constitution which limited the powers of the central government and ensured that any further powers would be given only if a majority of the people in a majority of the States agreed, by referendum, to make the change; (2) a powerful Senate having an independence from the executive government of the day and made up of an equal number of Senators from each State.
Careful provision was made to give to the States powers in relation to the timing of elections for the Senate and the replacement of vacancies in the Senate caused by death or retirement.

It was made possible to have elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives on the same day, but the constitution was careful to provide that the Senate could not be dissolved whenever it pleased the Prime Minister of the day to do so. The Senate was to be dissolved when its term expired or when it had reached a stage of confrontation leading to a deadlock between the two Houses.

In the case of deadlock there is provision for a double dissolution when all members of both Houses have to go back to the people for election. This is the sanction imposed on the Senate to ensure that it does not behave in an unreasonable way.

There are many other fine points of the balance which the Constitution provides to ensure that democracy is preserved along with the Federal system. But it seems that, of late, central governments in Canberra have become greedy for more power.

First the Labor Party in 1973, 1974 and 1975 tried to push through bills for a referendum proposal identical with the proposal called, by what is deliberate misdescription, the Simultaneous Elections question.
He went on to say:

It was the first Prime Minister of Australia, Sir Edmund Barton, who said, 'We cannot fail to remember that the Constitution designed the Senate to be a House of greater power than any ordinary second chamber. Not only by its express powers, but by the equality of its representation of the States, the Senate was intended to protect the States from aggression'.
An attack on the powers and independence of the Senate is, without doubt, an attack upon the rights and powers of the States.
There are other paragraphs in that article that I believe are of interest but, in the interest of time, I-

TALK.START.PARA: —Is New Zealand a democracy?

—I would imagine that people could consider that. I know the sort of democracy that the Australian Labor Party wants to see in Australia, it wants to abolish the Senate. That is clearly enshrined in the objectives of the Labor Party. I believe that this was evident when the Whitlam Government came into power. It tried to weaken the authority of local government. It tried to regionalise local government into 48 regions throughout Australia. It tried to destroy local government with the object of eventually destroying the States. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) should ask me whether New Zealand is a democracy. He is dedicated to centralised power in Canberra. There is no way he can convince me otherwise. I will be opposing simultaneous elections for that reason alone.

SPEECH.PARA: Another measure about which I am suspicious is the interchange of powers. I will not oppose that emphatically. I have a question-mark about it in my mind. I do not like the thought of the Federal Government, under socialist administration, perhaps having a chance at some future time-remote though that might be-of going to bed with socialist governments of the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Yes. What an unholy marriage. What a danger to the future of Australia if that ever happens. Therefore, I have troubles in my mind, but I might not object too much in regard to that matter. The Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill proposes parliamentary terms of four years. I believe that that is fair enough. I think that people are a little tired of elections. I believe that Bob Hawke, for example, ought to have a little longer than three years to convince his left wing that to develop the uranium resources of Australia is the right way to go. It will take him that long. You might give him some help, Senator Grimes, because I believe that you are one of those within the Labor Caucus who happens to be interested in the welfare of the Australian workers and in the job opportunities and in economic advantages that the uranium industry in Australia can provide. I sympathise with your problem. I believe that you might need another year to get the left wing radical element within your Party to agree to such development, thus helping the economic progress of Australia. Unless you want me to go a little further, I will continue with the next Bill. I can talk for a long time on that issue because I think you are behaving in a very peculiar fashion if you are interested in the economic recovery of Australia.
—I take a point of order. If Senator Jessop is addressing the Chair he has just made some very derogatory remarks about the Chair. If he is not addressing the Chair, I suggest that he do so.
—Bearing in mind that it is just after dinner I have allowed a certain leeway to Senator Jessop. I ask him to address his remarks to the Chair.

—I have enjoyed my mineral water very much, thank you. I intend to continue to go through my objections to these Bills. I have demonstrated my opposition to the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill. I do not like the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill. I think it is an abrogation of the responsibility of Parliament to refer matters to the High Court, even though they may be advisory. Plenty of advice which we can utilise is available to us from lawyers and senior counsel from all over the place. I am saying no to that Bill. I will say yes to the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill.
—That is not necessary. Do not worry about that.

—I think it is all right. I do not mind that. I do not think there is any constitutional threat to the Senate in that Bill. I will say no to the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. Certainly, I am prepared to agree with Senator Rae's proposition about the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this debate on the nine Constitution alteration Bills. I say first that that number of Bills is in itself somewhat intimidating. I hope that the nine constitution alterations will not all be placed before the public when it comes to vote on them, because it will be difficult for the public. I think it is even difficult for honourable senators in this chamber to realise what each Bill is about at various times.
—Speak for yourself.

—I speak for myself. I am only a simple lawyer and, therefore, I am not absolutely sure I can always recall what every Bill is about. I suggest that there should be some winnowing of the list before we go to the people with a list of constitutional alterations of that dimension.

SPEECH.PARA: We originally had a proposal for fixed terms of Parliament. I spoke a couple of weeks ago in a state of some dismay when I found that the Australian Labor Party has so foolishly moved from the proposal of fixed terms. It was apparently misled by some of the pragmatists in that Party and would not continue with the fixed term proposal of which, according to the polls something like 75 per cent of the public were in favour. The carriage of that proposal would have been a major achievement which would have removed the prime ministerial right to cause the number of elections which we have had in this country.

We have had so many elections that although we in the Senate, who are supposed to have six year terms, have only one senator in this chamber today has ever served a six-year term. Such is the ludicrous situation to which we have degenerated through quick elections and short terms of parliament. Instead of the fixed term proposal, the Government has brought back the two proposals in regard to simultaneous elections and parliamentary terms of four years. While good, they are to my mind a second best solution. I think that later we will have to get back to the concept of fixed terms to ensure that terms of parliament are not truncated by actions of Prime Ministers who see a quick gain and advantage in having early elections, therefore disrupting the economy of this country.

I support the two referendum proposals for simultaneous elections and terms of four years for the House of Representatives and eight years for the Senate. I will certainly campaign for them, as I did in 1977 when the previous Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, and I travelled this country to seek votes for those proposals. We know that although those proposals failed narrowly to be accepted in two of the States and badly in Tasmania, they were overwhelmingly successful in the other three States and enjoyed the benefit of the vote of 62 per cent of the population. Unfortunately the proposals did not become the law. I trust that on this occasion they will become the law and we will be able to eliminate the ludicrous situation in this country whereby, since Federation, parliaments have sat for an average duration of two years and five months, not even the three years for which the Constitution provides.

I trust we will realise that the value of these proposals is to be seen in other countries. For example, among the democratic world at present 24 parliaments have a five-year term, 25 parliaments have a four-year term, and only four, including Australia's have a three-year term. One need not advance very much into the arguments, which are so significant, to show that it is necessary for parliaments to sit for a certain time in order for governments to be able to develop their policies and have their economic programs operating so that they are not always facing the immediate post-election or pre-election Budget. They can therefore do more to stabilise the economy of the country. Most of the States in this country have either accepted four-year terms or are in the process of changing their terms to four years, so the proposal is on their books . It is not necessary for people to vote for both of these alternative proposals . They can vote for both one or neither, as the Bills provide. I hope that people will vote for both proposals because I believe they are in the best interests of this country. With regard to the other constitution alteration bills, I do not propose to speak on some of them at any length because I have already spoken on them when they first came before the Senate in May of this year. I draw attention to the speech which I made. It is to be found on page 676 of Hansard of 19 May 1983. I set out my views on the six Bills which were then before the Senate in respect of constitutional alteration. Five of these Bills are in the list we are debating tonight. I will deal briefly with four of them.

I think that the proposal in respect of the interchange of powers between the States and the Commonwealth is an excellent proposal. It is one which was accepted by the Australian Constitutional Convention. It provides that in a number of areas where there is a need for a variation of powers, where it is necessary to overcome grey areas in the Constitution and to ensure somebody is taking action, the States can refer certain powers to the Commonwealth without losing them forever. Likewise, the Commonwealth can do the same thing. Those proposals, which have been worked out by representatives of the States and the Commonwealth deserve support and should be supported in the constitutional referendum.

The fourth proposal before us is one which provides the power for the High Court to give advisory opinions. In other words, it enables the High Court of Australia to give advisory opinions. It means that in the future the High Court will not have to wait for a case to develop fortuitously, which might take years and years to come, to judge the constitutional validity or otherwise of one of the Acts of this Parliament. We all remember that it was not until about a year ago that the 1975 racial discrimination legislation was determined as being constitutionally valid by the High Court of Australia. I think it is desirable that the same power should be held by the High Court as is held by the Supreme Court in Canada and as is held by the Privy Council. There is nothing unusual in that provision. Indeed, some attempt has been made in the past to give the High Court some power in this regard but the right to have full power to give an advisory opinion that is not based on a particular case has been rejected.

Some of my colleagues and other people in the community, some of the johnny- come-latelies in this field, have discovered some objection. Some of the High Court judges have expressed, as they have in the past, some thought that they might not want this power, that they might be overworked, or that they might have too much business. This has not happened in Canada, it has not happened elsewhere, and I believe there is no reason why it should happen here. I note that an amendment to this Bill has been proposed by Senator Durack which would enable individuals who have an interest in a particular Act of the Parliament to be able to join in and seek an advisory opinion. I hope the Government will think carefully--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not seek an opinion; to intervene and put argument.
—I understand it goes further than that.
—No, it does not. If it did I would not accept it, but I am going to.

—I see. That being so, it does seem to me to be a desirable thing that individuals should be able to intervene in that way. I am glad to hear that the Government will accept that amendment. The advisory opinions proposal of course, is based on recommendations of both the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs under my chairmanship, made in October 1977, and Committee D of the Australian Constitutional Convention. As our proposed terms were slightly at variance, we got together and there was agreement about them. This change has been a long time coming and I believe that as this proposal has the support of the Constitutional Convention there is a question that it should also have the support of the Australian people as a desirable power to be given to the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: I think little needs to be said about the third of these five proposals, the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill 1983. It is desirable that we should clear up some of the debris of the Constitution that is no longer needed. The Constitution is not exactly an exciting document for people to read. It is better that they should not have to read things that no longer have any bearing in the governing of this country.

We come then to two other of the private member's Bills that are part of the package of nine Bills before us. One is the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1982 [1983] which was proposed by Senator Mason of the Australian Democrats. This Bill provides that Acts, constitutional change, and so forth can be initiated by individual members of the public. I think 250,000 people would be required to sign a request for a Bill, which must then be put to the people. I believe in parliamentary democracy. I do not believe in the participatory form of democracy that this would involve. If we look at that proposal, we would be stuck with Bills the terms of which had been drafted by individuals outside the Parliament. There would be no room for debate and change inside the Parliament. If the legislation were then carried in a referendum, we would be stuck with a piece of law which we would have to get rid of by the same complicated process. I have spoken on this proposal before and indicated my entire opposition to it. I hope that the Government will not have a bar of it. I hope it will not be put forward because it would be confusing and dangerous. It appears to give to the people rights, but what it would do would be to hog-tie the Parliament of this country and really to remove from parliamentary democracy the essence of debate, compromise and determination of Bills, which are essential and which are part of our traditional Westminster system of democracy.

The next of the private member's Bills is one on which I have also spoken before. I refer to the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill 1983 which was introduced by Senator Peter Rae. What he is proposing is what is known generally in the trade as the 'Court' proposal. Disputes have gone on in the Constitutional Convention over the years. One of these was the 'Whitlam' proposal, which would have taken away the right to deny Supply so far as the Senate is concerned. That proposal would never have been accepted because there were always enough people to oppose it. Such a proposal could never have succeeded at a referendum. The alternative 'Court' proposal now promoted by Senator Peter Rae says this: If there is a dispute, if Supply is refused, if there is objection of this sort on the grounds that the Government does not have the finance to govern, there must be a double dissolution. This proposal would force the situation so that there must be a double dissolution of both Houses. The advantage of such a proposal, of course, is that, as the Constitution stands at the moment, it is possible if there are no double dissolution Bills around for the Senate to force the other House to an election and not have to go to an election itself. That, I think, is notoriously bad and should be changed. On the other hand, this proposal would also allow the Senate to send the House of Representatives to an election because the Government in the House of Representatives is unpopular or is doing necessary but unpopular things. This proposal would give to the Senate too much power. Frankly, I would not like to see this chamber given the power to force the House of Representatives at any time to an election. Frankly, I could not support that proposal, as I indicated when it first came before this chamber.

Two of the Bills we are considering tonight are new and are before the chamber for the first time. The Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill 1983 has been proposed by my Victorian colleague, Senator Hamer. We have a situation at present where the Government in the House of Representatives can hold onto Bills rejected by the Senate for months or years and subsequently apply for a double dissolution. The Government can hold the Bills over the head of the Senate. The Government can then go before the Governor-General and say: 'Because of this objection to our Bills, because of this obstruction of the Government in the House of Representatives, we want a double dissolution'. We had a typical example of this, of course, at the beginning of this year when a double dissolution was obtained by Mr Fraser on the basis of sales tax and other Bills which he made clear during the election campaign he did not intend to proceed with. The same thing happened in 1975 when the notorious constitutional crisis took place. On that occasion a double dissolution was granted to Mr Fraser on the basis of Bills of the Whitlam Government which Mr Fraser had no intention whatsoever of proceeding with. They were the very Bills that he and his supporters in the Senate, including myself, had defeated.

In my opinion it is absurd that the Government can have the power, that it can hold over the Senate Bills which have accumulated over a period and which it has no intention to proceed with, and then subsequently seek a double dissolution on that basis. I think it is an excellent initiative by my colleague Senator Hamer to suggest that Bills can be retained for only three months, that if they are not used in that period and they are not genuine causes of conflict between the two chambers then they cease to have effect. I hope that this proposal will be accepted by the Parliament and by the people as a very necessary way of avoiding what have been hypocrisies in the past in the misuse of these powers, and that double dissolution procedures will be used hereafter only in genuine cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —And place the Governor-General in an unnecessarily invidious position.

—As Senator Chipp says, the Governor-General is quite unnecessarily placed in an invidious position. He may have to accept statements that he may doubt very much are truthful. In fact, doubts were cast in regard to the 1975 incident, and I cast them myself, as to whether that was a valid use of the double dissolution power since the new Government had no intention whatsoever of implementing the Bills that were the cause of the double dissolution. I therefore strongly support that amendment. I hope that the Government will do likewise. I believe that it ought to be adopted by the Australian people as part of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: The last of these Bills-the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill 1983-was introduced by Senator Macklin and is designed to break the nexus contained in the provision that the number of members in the House of Representatives must be as near as possible to twice the number of senators. Quite frankly, I know that my colleagues believe this is a good idea. It was put forward by a non-Labor government years ago and was disastrously rejected by the Australian people. I have the gravest doubts as to whether this proposal would pass the people. Quite apart from the genuine arguments about the Bill, I have no doubt that there would be a great deal of red herrings cast in the road of it. There would be suggestions that if we are able to increase the membership of the House of Representatives without tying it to the numbers in the Senate we would probably increase it very considerably and that in the party rooms of the Parliament the senators would be less significant. I can imagine several State Premiers, who will remain nameless, coming to the conclusion that this proposition would weaken the power of the State.

Apart from that I think there are genuine considerations. There is no doubt that if we remove the nexus we can increase the number of members of the House of Representatives by five or 10. This can be done each time there is a redistribution. At the moment most people think that we can increase the number of senators only by 12 or 24. It would be possible, of course, to increase the membership by half that number. There is nothing in the Constitution that says there must be an even number in the Senate. It seems to be regarded as the common practice that we would increase the number of senators by 12 and, therefore, we would need 24 of so members of the House of Representatives, or that we would increase the number in the Senate by up to 24 senators in which case we would need double that number in the House of Representatives. When we return to the argument about electoral reform I intend to put proposals in regard to the way in which the increase in the Senate does not necessarily have to be six persons standing for election each time. The number could be seven and five. But that is a different subject.

So far as this subject is concerned I want to say this: I think there are some grave doubts about the desirability of breaking the nexus. In my opinion there is a great need in this Parliament for more senators. We are not able to cope with the work load of this Parliament and in particular with the committee work with which we are involved. The other House does not pursue committee work to anything like the same degree as the Senate does. I do not see much need at all for the breaking of the nexus, and nor do I think it will pass the public. On those practical grounds I very much doubt whether this proposal is worth persisting with and, therefore, causing perhaps some confusion in the eyes of the public and raising the hackles of various war horses from various States who will proceed to see in it an attack upon the Senate and its powers.

Let me say in summary that I support most of the proposals. I think it is highly desirable that we have a continuance of the constitutional process. Like the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), I have been concerned with the process of constitutional change and the desire to see that we will get across the boundaries to agreement on constitutional change. There is a great deal of agreement across the boundaries in these proposals. In 1977 we achieved three amendments to the Constitution. As I have said, the fourth proposal failed- although it had a 62 per cent positive vote-because of the necessity of having a majority of four States. I believe we have in these proposals, generally, the opportunity of securing fewer elections, longer and more stable terms for the Parliament and less trickery in the operation of our constitutional process. I believe that, taken generally, they are useful reforms, with the exception of a couple which I think should not proceed.

I believe that the updating of our Constitution is the duty of members of this Parliament. It is very easy to say: 'It is not the important issue; there are terribly important issues in connection with the economy'. Of course there are. But we are living with a horse and buggy Constitution. We are living with a constitution which, unfortunately, every now and then breaks down and leads to some sort of constitutional crisis. It is therefore the duty of members of this Parliament to look carefully at these proposals and to bring forward the most important ones for decision by the people. The people have the ultimate say in this matter. I hope that they will not be misled in campaigns by red herrings and fears which people will raise, but that they will look at the proposals carefully and recognise that the great support which is shown for them in the Australian Constitutional Convention and in this Parliament means that they deserve a great deal of consideration and the Constitution of this country may be improved by their inclusion. I support the proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this cognate debate on nine Bills which seek constitutional change. If one looks at the mood of Australia over the last seven to eight years, or perhaps the decade, one sees that constitutional reform is no longer the prerogative of members of parliament . It has become much more a movement of the people. It has become much more a matter to be discussed in the lounge rooms and in the everyday lives of ordinary Australians. No matter where one stood during the 1975 crisis, no matter on which side of the House one was seated or which side of the House one supported, there is no doubt that the events of 1975 reached each and every Australian. Those events have given the movement for constitutional reform some appropriate impetus. We are now at the stage where several groups in our community are working towards constitutional reform on an almost constant basis. It is to the credit of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that he has taken a leading role not only in parliamentary discussion of constitutional reform but also in the community at large. Today we are looking at five Bills which he introduced to seek some change.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I wish to discuss the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill. There are three good and valid reasons why the Australian people ought to carry a referendum to seek simultaneous elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives. The first is the disruption and the inconvenience that a spate of elections can cause. I wish to take a few moments to look at the plight of electors in New South Wales. It is by no means a plight that belongs to them and them alone. I think that other States have suffered in a similar fashion. But in New South Wales in particular the electors, the ordinary citizens, are simply tired of elections. There have been far too many. There is one almost every year. Let me run through them. In 1961 there was a Federal election; in 1962, a State election; in 1963, another Federal election; in 1964, a half Senate election; in 1965, a State election; in 1966 a Federal election; in 1967, a half Senate election; in 1968, a State election; in 1969, a Federal election; in 1970, a half Senate election; in 1971, a State election; in 1972, a Federal election and in 1973, a State election. In 1974 and 1975 we had double dissolutions. In 1976 there was another State election; in 1977, an early Federal election; in 1978, a State election. The year 1979 was the big year-the year the people of New South Wales had to wait almost 20 years for; there was no election. In 1980 there was another Federal election and in 1981, a State election. The year 1982 was another vintage year for New South Wales electors; there was no election. There we were again, in March of this year, back with another double dissolution election.

When one looks at that long litany of elections in New South Wales, the first and immediate conclusion which one can draw is that were this Bill to be passed and were the referendum to be carried, automatically at least three of those elections would not have taken place. I certainly would be one who would suggest that those half Senate elections of 1964, 1967 and 1970 were hardly the hallmarks of Australian democracy. Had those elections not occurred I do not believe Australian democracy would be in tatters. It would not be shattered by these elections not having occurred. Unfortunately though, the requirements of the day brought the elections along. Then, in the 1970's when we would have again suffered a spate of these unnecessary half Senate elections, instead we had three double dissolutions in less than a decade, something that had, again, hardly been the hallmark of Australian democracy in the previous 80 years. Therefore, we can see that in New South Wales and around Australia ordinary citizens at least would not have been forced to the polls and often forced to consider the same issues again and again for no good and apparent reason.

What is more, it must be acknowledged that all of those elections cost money. I suppose that these days everything costs a lot of money. But I am told, on reliable estimates from the Australian Electoral Office, that it costs $16m to run an election in Australia today.

That is money that could be well spent on something else. I am never one to advance the argument that there are other priorities in government as being the only reason why one should oppose new legislation. It is always presupposed when one is looking at that argument that the reasons one is advancing for the original cost of the proposals are valid. Given that I can see no reason for those half Senate elections, I can see no reason for the waste of money.

Whenever there is no provision for simultaneous elections there is a temptation for governments to run to an early election to try to bring back the Senate and the House of Representatives into some sort of electoral kilter. When one looks at the role of politicians in this respect-it does not really matter what party they come from-one sees that they have not shown themselves to be much different from Adam and Eve when it comes to resisting temptation. Unfortunately, as a consequence, time and time again governments have chosen to use that option to go to an early election. In fact, over time, House of Representatives terms have averaged two years and four months. That is hardly much when one considers that it is supposed to have three-year terms. The tendency of recent times suggests that the average will be brought down even lower. It has been no secret, of course, that people in the Hawke Government at least looked at a proposal to have an early election in the term of this Parliament to bring about simultaneous elections for the two Houses in order to save costs and to get the two Houses back into kilter. Again, that is hardly something that will be of great benefit to the people, but it is something that every government has to look at in practical terms.

There are a number of things to look at. If honourable senators look at, for instance, the Senate reflecting public opinion appropriately and reflecting it on a day-to-day basis, they will see that if there are half Senate elections there will always be a temptation on the part of electors to kick governments and to say: 'Look, we'll have a check. We'll put a brake on them. We won't vote for them this time in the half Senate election, even though we voted for them in the House of Representatives election'. If that is to be something that we can all be proud of, unfortunately we have to look at the effect it has had on governments in that period, because it has not meant that Prime Ministers, Ministers and governments at large have reacted in a wonderful way to it. All that has happened in the end is that those governments have worried about any form of long term planning. They have looked at short term gains and short term benefits. As a consequence, Australia has suffered. There is no real evidence that any government in the post-war period has undertaken any form whatsoever of long term planning. They were either interrupted by unplanned double dissolutions or concerned about the possibility of half Senate elections, or they were simply not doing too well and decided: 'We'd better go early. One year more of us and they mightn't cop us again'. I do not believe that those sorts of reasons are what the Australian people are looking for in elections.

If we have simultaneous elections there will be fewer opportunities for the Senate to avoid the consequences of its action. There is no doubt that in recent times, as the new-found militancy of the Senate has come to the fore, Senate power and Senate muscle has been exercised more and more. If it has not been exercised more and more, certainly the threat of that exercise has occurred more and more. Very often, whatever the Senate may have done to exercise that power or whatever legislation it may have considered rejecting, these will not be the issues at a half Senate election. What ought to happen is that both Houses should come out together and every senator and member of the House of Representatives should have to face the people at one time. They have to look at the issues that affect the whole of the nation. We ought not to think that issues that affect the House of Representatives are different from or should be different from issues that affect Senate elections. In listening to the contributions of some honourable senators opposite one gets the impression that, while the argument is often advanced that they are trying to protect Senate powers, too often they are trying to affect the powers and privileges of senators. Obviously those two things are very different. Like all of the five proposals put up by the Attorney-General, this is an attempt to give some extra stability to government. I submit that after the controversy, heated at times, of the last decade in respect of government in this country, with the double dissolutions and all the rest of it, stability is something everyone is crying out for.

I turn now to the Bill which seeks to have a referendum on four-year terms for the House of Representatives, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill. I would have thought that bringing Australia into line with the rest of the world in the form of its democracy would have been a worthwhile course of action for anyone in the Parliament. Indeed, when one looks around the world one is hard pressed to find too many democracies that still operate on three-year terms. All we have to look at today is New Zealand, which probably has a three- year term because we have it; Thailand, and one would not want to speculate on why it has it, and Sweden which alone among the Scandinavian countries, is stuck with a three-year parliamentary term.

If we hark back to 1977 we get a real chance to look at a government grasping for electoral advantage and going early to the electorate, again, adding to the instability that I mentioned. In 1977 when the Fraser Government was faced with problems over interest rates, inflation and unemployment about which it had made promises it could not possibly keep-I suggest the record shows that it did not keep them-the excuse was used about the synchronisation of the Senate and the House of Representatives and off it went to an early poll. Again, democracy in this country was not enhanced by that decision. Not only did we fail to improve the stability of Australian government; I think the record shows that we failed to improve the quality as well.

Four-year terms will allow for greater continuity and a better chance for governments to engage in economic planning which, as I mentioned a few moments ago, is something that has been sadly lacking in Australia for far too long. I might also mention that were we to adopt four-year terms for the House of Representatives, when looking at that very long list of elections in New South Wales which the elector of New South Wales had to face in over 22 years-again after eliminating three elections for half Senate elections-one could eliminate another three or four as a result of the four-year term proposal. I think that would have been to everyone's advantage because at least it would have meant that governments could have stuck to their plans. That is something that not too many governments have had the courage to do. Generally speaking, when a government is elected it has the first year to settle in, when the Ministers find out where their department is, who is in it and what sort of information is provided by it. In the second year the Government takes stock. It can also-I think the record shows that it often does-take some hard decisions. But then, in the third year, when it has to face the people again, it introduces a give-away Budget. It has not really mattered who has been in power; the record shows that that happened again and again. In that third year the give-aways are on, the race to the polls is on and the campaign is on. Good, stable, and effective government with planning for the future goes out the window. Unfortunately, that has happened time and time again. The system does not allow for real values and principles. It finishes up allowing only for expediency.

The argument has often been advanced by members of the Liberal and National parties about monetarist economies and their virtues. The argument is espoused by honourable senators on this side of the House about expansionist Budgets and all the rest of it. Unfortunately, the Fraser Government, in its number of terms , never had the time to implement its monetarist policies. It had a lot of rhetoric about them, but the exigencies of the day prevented it from ever bringing that rhetoric into practice. I say 'unfortunately' only in the sense that had it introduced them there would really not have been any argument in Australia today. The people of Australia would have seen how bankrupt those policies were and how they would have bankrupted Australia. If the proposal for four-year parliaments had been adopted, if governments had had longer terms and time to settle down, and if that had given them some of the courage of their professed convictions, perhaps we might have had a chance to evaluate the success of the Fraser Government in that endeavour. We might also have a better chance to look at what the Hawke Government will do in the future. If two years and four months is the average time then even if we make it three years and four months I think we will be doing the people of Australia a great service. If we can make long term planning the order of the day rather than the exception to the rule I think we will have done Australia a great favour.

I will now refer to some of the comparable democracies that have four-year parliaments. The ones that readily spring to mind that are more like ours are in West Germany, Japan, Switzerland and Austria. Those countries have had four-year parliaments for many years. I do not think anyone has suggested that those governments get too far away from their people. Most of those countries have enjoyed stable government, often over very many years-sometimes for decades. Britain and Canada have five-year parliaments. So what is suggested in this Bill is hardly a radical proposal. It is a proposal to bring about what I think is something that Australia has needed for far too long. We must also look at what has happened in the States. Only a couple of years ago a referendum was held in New South Wales for four-year terms and it got more than 80 per cent of the vote . Four-year terms already exist in Tasmania and in the Northern Territory and I believe Australian Labor Party governments in Victoria and Western Australia are currently seriously looking at referendum proposals on this issue as well. So this move will bring the Commonwealth into line with the general movement of States and it will meet with the agreement of the people as shown by that massive yes vote in New South Wales only a couple of years ago.

I do not want to say too much about the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill except that for the first time it would give the Commonwealth power to refer its powers to the States. It would make it somewhat easier for the States to refer powers to the Commonwealth but it must be acknowledged that the States already have that power. It would also allow the States to vest in Federal courts jurisdictions in matters arising under State law, with the exception, of course, of the High Court of Australia. It would do something to promote co-operation among the Commonwealth and State governments. It would get them talking in a more co-operative manner than we have seen so often in the last couple of decades, at Loan Council meetings or Premiers Conferences where they have simply fought, haggled and bickered rather than looked at the great problems of the day. For those who worry about the erosion of Commonwealth power , it will be provided that the Commonwealth can revoke an interchange at any time.

I now turn to the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill, which Senator Missen touched on a short time ago. This Bill is confined to jurisdiction in relation to enactments already passed or actually before a Commonwealth or State parliament. It can also relate to constitutional and treaty questions, although in respect of the treaty questions only the Commonwealth can seek the advisory opinion. I think that this will aid those in government, particularly from the point of view of State governments, a great deal. So often now State governments when looking at revenue raising matters, have to be concerned about the possible effect of actions in the High Court on the constitutional power to levy whatever sum they are seeking. If they are able to go to an appropriate court, such as the High Court, and find out its views, then not only are they going to be saved a lot of time and effort but also surely the people of Australia will be saved having to wait months and months for those sorts of decisions. When legislation enacted by parliaments is taken to places such as the High Court, decisions can be held up for years and years. If one summarises this Bill one could say that the only losers will be the lawyers. If that is the case I for one will shed no tears.

I think the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill is of no great controversy for the Senate. We have still got transitional provisions in the Constitution. The sorts of things that will be removed if this referendum proposal is carried really should have been removed 50 or 60 years ago, let alone now. I hope that all those on the other side regard this proposal as uncontentious and worthy of support.

I now turn to Senator Mason's Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill, which seeks constitutional change. I read a speech about it made by the present Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) when he was the shadow Attorney-General. This was after the Bill was introduced by Senator Macklin. I will not seek to use the extravagant language of that speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not extravagant; colourful.

—Colourful. All right, I will agree with colourful. I would not call this Bill or referendum legislation a piece of two bob populism but I would say it is misguided populism. I have no doubt that there is a superficial attraction to people who look at it superficially. It is suggested that a large number of electors-admittedly it is a large number, 250,000-who sign some sort of petition may propose some law. This may be a good thing but I think there are some very serious and deeply rooted problems with it. First, as I have said about all of the proposals for a change in the Constitution that I have so far spoken on, the real purpose of the lot is to make government in this country more stable and more certain. But if this sort of proposition is carried the programs of governments could easily be thrown into disarray. Governments could be elected on important policies, the big policies of the day, and then find that they have to consign those important policies to some sort of legislative limbo while referendum proposals are carried out. That would hold up good government. There is no good reason for it. It would undermine stability. Uncertainty would abound. Governments would have no real opportunity to establish priorities in their legislative programs. Also, appeals to ignorance, to fear and to prejudice in referendums of the kind proposed would finish up bringing the system into disrepute very quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: An obvious example is the oft talked of proposition 13 in California by which billions of dollars were taken away from the State treasury. It is hard to see too many people in Australia voting against a proposition that says we will not pay so much tax. This proposal will cause the same sort of problems here as it did there. Those problems were immense. In fact California still has not recovered and overcome the budgetary problems caused by that proposition. What is more, the idea spread like wildfire and terrified legislators all over the United States. I would not want to terrify anybody. I hope we do not have to abide by this proposition. If honourable senators consider that 250,000 people is indeed a lot of people, I ask them to consider a couple of fairly simple examples. There is a great deal of controversy among very many migrant communities about the policies of government in respect of family reunion. I am not suggesting that there is a particular controversy over the politics of this Government. There were controversies over the policies of the last Government and no doubt there will be over those of the next Government. It would not be difficult-indeed, it would be easy-to get the number of signatures that this Bill calls for. I hope that we do not go down that track. It could only undermine the stability of government in Australia and I, for one, am very strongly opposed to it.

I now turn to Senator Macklin's Bill on the nexus, the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill. I for one have no dispute whatsoever with the principles embodied in the Bill. The first thing that should be said is that the principles embodied in this proposal for a referendum have been espoused by a great many distinguished Australians in the other place and here over very many years. It is not new. It was put before the people in the 1960s and was narrowly defeated. I believe it will be passed by the Australian people in, I hope, the not too distant future. But I caution those in the Australian Democrats who are genuine about constitutional reform. If one puts up too many controversial proposals at once one runs a grave risk that either one or all will be affected by that course of action. When one looks at the number of referendums that have passed in Australia over the course of Federation one sees that in round figures only eight out of 40 have passed. I suggest that that is not an impressive record for constitutional change.

Because I believe that the proposals for simultaneous elections and four-year terms are so vital, I hope that the Constitutional Alteration (Parliament) Bill can lie on the table for some time. After discussion with the Australian Democrats and the Government it could then be reintroduced at an appropriate time when it will not be confused with a host of other issues. We might then get to the point of being able to put it to the people and have it passed. One should never underestimate the innate conservatism of the Australian electorate. Even with the support of Robert Menzies and Arthur Calwell and both sides of the House in the 1960s the proposal did not get up. I believe that it would be difficult to have it passed at the moment. I caution the Senate that it might be more propitious at another time.

I turn now to Senator Hamer's Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill, commonly called the stockpiling of Bills in double dissolutions. I know that this Bill will cause quite a degree of debate. I am one who worries about the exercise of Senate power such as we have seen over the past decade. I do not doubt its constitutional validity, but that does not stop me from being most concerned about it. I think that any honourable senator here who is prepared to vote to bring down Government legislation must be prepared to face the consequences of that action. A government can stockpile Bills and bring about a double dissolution if it considers that there are so many of them, that they are objectionable. It can go to the people and make that Senate rejection of Bills the issue in an election campaign. It should have the right to do so. Unfortunately, earlier in 1983 when the stockpiling provision was used, that did not happen.

The Bills that were rejected by the Senate were not of the type that the Fraser Government wanted to raise in the election campaign, let alone to make them the central issue. I would feel a lot happier about Senator Hamer's Bill if more people on the other side had raised those objections in February of 1983 when the election was called. However, from my reading of the Press at the time and the knowledge I gained from talking to people from both parties I believe there was not a great deal of criticism from the other side. The criticism was muted; it was non-existent. The last chance, the last gasp, of the Liberal Government in going for that double dissolution it would seem was opposed by very few before the event. After the event, when the Liberal Party was slaughtered at the polls, of course, everyone disowned it and said that it was a silly idea in the first place.

I turn very briefly to Senator Peter Rae's Bill, the Constitution Alteration ( Appropriation Bills) Bill. I oppose it very strongly. It raises the dark spectre of Sir John Kerr's actions of 1975 once again. That sorry piece of our history should never be repeated. If Senator Rae's Bill was to be put to the people and passed, the stability in government that I think constitutional reform should be all about would forever be in doubt. That action in 1975 caused divisions in our community that to this day have not been healed. I hope that by passing this package of Bills introduced by Senator Evans and by putting them to the people and the people passing them we can set about healing some of those divisions and restore some stability, sanity and, I hope, quality to government in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I once again find myself opposing moves by the Government of the day to undermine the powers of the Senate. I will speak primarily on the so-called Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill , because it is the Bill to which I am most violently opposed. The people have already spoken twice on this Bill. It has been put to the people of Australia on two occasions and the people of Australia knocked it back on both those occasions.
—There was a 62 per cent affirmative majority.

—It does not matter what Senator Evans tries to say in this place. I am quite well aware that by his use of the external affairs powers of the Constitution against our State he has shown that he has little regard for the Constitution. I am well aware of that situation, but it does not really matter what he says in this place tonight. The people of Australia knocked back the proposal for simultaneous elections on two occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it quite clear from the start that I am not against simultaneous elections. The Prime Minister has the power to call simultaneous elections, that is, an election of the House of Representatives and the Senate at the same time, whenever he so chooses. All he has to do is run the House of Representatives for the required time and call it out when the half Senate is due for re-election. There is nothing magical about that. He can do it whenever he likes. I object very strongly to the name of the Bill. It is deceiving. It is not all about simultaneous elections. It is about the simultaneous dissolution of the House of Representatives and half the Senate. I turn to the policies of the two main parties of the Senate. The Liberal Party platform on page 7 states:
Maintenance of the Senate as an institution for the effective representation of all States and Territories and as a House of Review.

I have not bothered to look up the Labor Party's policy on this because it has changed quite markedly over time. But in 1977 when I was last on my feet debating this Bill, Senator McLaren, a former senator, made it very clear what this Bill was all about. Indeed, he acknowledged that it was the first step in abolishing the power of the Senate, and he added the words 'the sooner the better'. The now Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, also assured us at that time that his Labor Party would take every opportunity to delimit the power of the Senate. The aim in 1977 was quite clear because it was at that time a part of the policy of the Labor Party to abolish the Senate.

When Senator Evans, the ultimate politician, came into this place he decided that the policy should not be in writing. The aim should be there, but after all , he believed it was not electorally palatable. It would not go down too well in the electorate. So we find that at his council meeting he said, 'Let us get rid of it; let us take the words out of our policy platform. There is no need to destroy the aim, but let us take the words out'. That is what happened because we can no longer find the actual words declaring that the Labor Party wants to abolish the Senate. But the aim is still very clearly there. That is what this Bill is really about.

Let us look at the history of the Senate. In 1890 when our founding fathers were debating the structure of the Senate they came up with three main points if the federation of the States was to take place. The first was that there should be an equal voice in the Senate for all the States. The second was that senators should have a six-year term and that half the Senate should go to the people every three years. The third was that there should be a double dissolution; there should be a method of dealing with a clash of opinions between the two Houses. I believe that Senator Peter Rae's Bill overcomes the previous problems that we had in that area.

Let us look at the reasons why those wise men decided that the Senate should have an equal voice for the States, why it should be called the States House, and why the Senate should have the powers that it has. We have 10 senators for each State sitting in this place. As I have said, that gives the smallest State, my State of Tasmania, with not quite half a million people, the same power as the people of New South Wales. Looking at the Tasmanian position in the House of Representatives, it will be clearly understood why the Senate is so important to Tasmania and to the other small States. New South Wales has 43 members in the House of Representatives, Victoria has 33 members. Of the small States, South Australia has 11 members, Queensland has 19, Western Australia has 11, and Tasmania has five, with the Territories having only three representatives. Adding the two large States together, we find that New South Wales and Victoria between them have 76 voices in the House of Representatives. The small States- South Australia, Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Territories- together have the voices of only 49 people. It is 49 versus 76.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is more than your population entitles you to.
—Senator Evans says that that is more than we are entitled to, he coming from one of the large States.
—More than your population entitles you to.

—It seems to me that that is exactly what the large States say: They should have the power; they have the population; it really does not matter what small States have. The fact that Tasmania has only five voices in the House of Representatives versus the 43 from New South Wales is quite immaterial to Senator Evans. In this place the situation is totally different. Tasmania has an equal voice.
—Don't we know it.

—I am very glad that Senator Evans acknowledges that in this chamber Tasmania has a voice equal to that of the State of New South Wales. That is the importance of the power of the Senate. Why should the founding fathers have come up with their next decision that senators should have a six-year term and that half the Senate should go to the people every three years on a fixed term, unless there are just reasons for a double dissolution? The reason for that is the stability of government in this place. We know that in the House of Representatives there are large swings from Labor to Liberal and back to Labor, and that has gone on over many generations. That wild swing is not always a good thing and I shall come to that matter shortly. But the wild swings do not occur in the Senate. That gives the stability to the Government, because the Senate has checks and balances that overcome those wild swings in the lower House.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) can call an election whenever he likes in the House of Representatives. On the merest pretext he can call an election. He does not have to have been in office for any length of time at all. Whenever the political situation is favourable to him, he can call an election for the House of Representatives. Under the present Constitution he cannot take the Senate with him unless the Senate has been obstructive and has not backed some of his important Bills. He must have the required number of Bills put aside to prove to the Governor-General that the Senate has been obstructive.

The House of Representatives can go to an election on any pretext at all, and I give an example. At present we have the situation with the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and we have Mr Young, who has rather substantial support in Government ranks. A bit of a barney is going on between members of the Labor Party who are supporting Mr Young and those who are supporting the Prime Minister on this issue. If that barney continues and the Prime Minister finds himself in a very difficult situation-it does not have to be a political situation concerning Bills; it does not even have to concern legislation but just a difficult political situation within his own Party-he can refer this to the Governor-General and call an immediate election in the House of Representatives. That has nothing to do with the Senate, and the Senate cannot rightfully be called to an election under the present Constitution.

If people doubt that the House of Representatives can be called to an election on the merest pretext, they have to go back only to the time when the House of Representatives had a majority of just one. We find that just because there was a majority of one and the Prime Minister of the day thought that that was difficult to handle, he was able to call an election. Under the present Constitution we have big swings in the House of Representatives, and the Prime Minister has full control and can call that House to an election whenever he desires, whenever the political climate suits him. Under the new legislation, the situation could arise that, if the Prime Minister at his whim were able to call the Senate to an election with the House of Representatives, if he had won an election with a large majority but did not have the numbers in the Senate, within a very short time he could call another election. Within a very few months he could call another election for the Senate, and during the honeymoon period, during the period of euphoria that often accompanies these large majorities, the people could well vote in a Senate according to the political persuasion of the Prime Minister of the time.

I believe that the people of Australia need some time to have a look at the Government they have put in. We have only to look at the Whitlam Government. That was first put in with a very large majority, but the euphoria was very short lived. That Government was out in a very short time. The people realised that it was not the Government they had hoped they were electing. That Government handed out all the goodies and the people thought it was all right for the first few months. If this proposed legislation had been in force, Prime Minister Whitlam could have at that stage called another election and the Senate would have been to his choosing. Any rogue government could do the same thing.

I refer to the present Government. The Prime Minister has got in with quite a substantial majority. Again, I believe that the honeymoon period, the euphoria of the people of Australia after the election, will be very short lived. We have only to look down the list of problems that the Government has made for itself since it has been in power. We started off with the spy flights that Senator Evans thought were rather good at the time. We then got on to the attack on Dame Leonie Kramer by Senator Button. We then went to the Wran royal commission, the David Combe-Australian Security Intelligence Organisation royal commission, the Budget attack on the disadvantaged, the broken promises that have resulted from that Government in the Budget and the turnaround on foreign policy when, I think , Mr Lionel Bowen suggested that Japan, along with Australia, might send troops into Kampuchea. Now we have reached the Dawkins situation and the people of Australia are beginning to wonder what they have elected to this Parliament.

If the Senate were to become just a rubber stamp, if it were able to be called to the people at the political whim of the Prime Minister of the day, then it would no longer be a States House; it would no longer be a House of review because, should it review the legislation in any sort of unfavourable way, the Prime Minister would immediately call an election. We have been told by some people that we have had too many elections, that there are too many elections if the House of Representatives and the Senate go to the people at different times. In Australia we are a true democracy and, if we complain about having elections, then my goodness, we must be laughed at by the rest of the world because many countries would give their eye teeth to have the free elections that we have.
I turn to what I suppose we could call the Bible of the Senate, the fifth edition of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice. In referring to the defeat of the referendum in 1974 Mr Odgers said:
It was considered that the proposals would have undermined the Federal structure and destroyed the independence of the Senate.
How true. He also said:

Of most importance was the assertion of the supremacy of Parliament over the Executive Government, demonstrated by the exercise of the power of the Senate to withhold Supply and the dismissal of a Prime Minister who refused to advise an election or resign when denied Supply by Parliament.
That is what the power of the Senate is all about. He went on to say:

The Senate has always had to fight hard for recognition of its constitutional rights and independence, but the Upper House has never lost a financial battle with the Executive Government or the House of Representatives.
It is not going to lose this one either. Finally, in referring to the powers of the Senate, he says:
Those powers are checks and balances against any concentration of unbridled power in the Executive Government, or against any misuse of power or mismanagement by a Government.

I believe that is what we are all about in this place. Senator Macklin tonight complained when he was talking on the Constitutional Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill that the Government was able to stockpile some Bills that the Senate has passed, putting them on the shelf to be used at its convenience to call on an election; yet he is supporting simultaneous elections. How can he possibly complain about the Bills that the Senate knocks back being used by the government of the day for convenience? With simultaneous elections the whole of the Senate would be used at the convenience of the Government. It is something that I and my State certainly would not go along with. We have already lost at the hands of this Government much of my State's powers with the use of the external affairs powers. There is no way that we will go along with the loss of more powers in the Senate for my State or for the other small States.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with Senate powers, and you know it.

—It has everything in the world to do with Senate powers. If Senator Evans, who has not been a member of this Senate for terribly long, is not aware that this has everything to do with Senate powers I would be most surprised. As he has said, and as I indicated earlier, the Australian Labor Party really is about abolishing the Senate. He does not like the words in the Labor Party policy so he has taken them out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Other Bills are before the Senate tonight, but, as I said earlier, I will just touch on some of them briefly, my main concern being the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill. The Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill is to enable the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments to obtain advisory opinions from the High Court of Australia on specified types of questions. We have already had experience of what the High Court can do and how it can alter the Constitution of this country , and there is no way I or my State would go along with that Bill.

I am also opposed to the maximum term of members of the House of Representatives being increased to four years and that of senators to eight years. I would like to go along with the four-year term for the House of Representatives, but I believe that eight years is a very long term for members of the Senate. Unfortunately, we cannot have one without the other. Consequently I will be forced to vote against that Bill.

I am totally opposed to the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill. I am firmly committed to the independence of the Senate and the unhampered voice of the small States. I believe that this is perhaps one of the most important pieces of legislation we have had before us. The Australian people have to think very carefully when they consider changing our Constitution. It has served us very well over the years. Very wise reasons were given for the Senate being an independent House and for having the powers that it has and for each State having a voice equal to that of every other State. It is with these sentiments that I oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is claimed that the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1983 should be supported because it will lead to fewer elections. The reality is that the number of elections is due not to the inherent weakness of the Constitution or lack of perception by the founding fathers; rather, they have been caused by various governments which have chosen for quite political reasons to call early elections. It is not without some sense of irony to me that this proposal for simultaneous elections has also been designed for political reasons. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not want simultaneous elections to reduce the number of elections but to eliminate the need for his Government to face a half Senate election by June 1985 without a corresponding House of Representatives election. We can all be assured that the Prime Minister will have a general election at the end of next year if it suits his purposes, irrespective of the outcome of this referendum proposal. The only practical answer to having fewer elections is to have four-year term parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been pointed out on previous occasions, the very name of this Bill is misleading. It is not a constitutional amendment to provide for simultaneous elections but rather a constitutional amendment providing for a half Senate election to be held on the same day as the Prime Minister chooses to hold an election for the House of Representatives. In other words, an election for the Senate would take place upon a date chosen by the Prime Minister, and that may be any time, irrespective of the terms served by members of the Senate. Theoretically, we could find ourselves having a Senate election every 12 months. Simultaneous elections will not cause fewer elections; all that proposal will provide is a capacity for the Prime Minister of the day to have half Senate elections on the same and every day that he chooses to have House of Representatives elections. I see no reason why that is likely to lessen the number of elections a Prime Minister will call. In fact, knowing that he will not have to have a half Senate election on a different date can only give greater encouragement to a Prime Minister to be more capricious and less restricted in the timing of elections.
