If that discipline were not removed, of course he would not have that constraint.

No one should misunderstand that the proposal for simultaneous elections now before us can have but one result as it relates to the Senate. It will irreversibly reduce and weaken the powers of the Senate and it will irreversibly reduce the capacity of the Senate. It is a fall-back position from the Government's earlier proposal of fixed term parliaments which was designed, amongst other things, to remove from the Senate the power to reject or defer Supply. The Australian Labor Party ultimately removed that proposal once it got into office because, whilst diminishing the power of the Senate, it would have reduced at least superficially the capacity of the Prime Minister to call early elections. Without retracing all the well established facts in regard to the intended role and functions of the Senate, I remind honourable senators of section 53 of the Constitution which, in part, reads:
Except as provided in this section, the Senate shall have equal power with the House of Representatives in respect of all proposed laws.

It refers to not more, not less, but equal power. If the Senate is to be subject to elections because of events in the House of Representatives it automatically loses that status; it becomes an appendage, a poor relation which meekly follows and must be subject to the whim and wishes of the House of Representatives. Its very survival will be in the hands of the Prime Minister and the House of Representatives. By the very provisions of the proposal it is intended that the Senate will be inextricably tied to the House of Representatives and will no longer have independence of mind or action, so its functions as a States House will be thoroughly dissolved. It will simply be an addition to the House of Representatives; it will rely for its future upon the political fortunes of the government of the day. Affairs and matters of the House of Representatives which have no bearing on the Senate would dictate its duration and its composition.

In the event of a political convulsion in the House of Representatives which caused the Prime Minister to call an election for that House, the Senate would be compelled for no good or sensible reason to be subject to a premature election. If, for example, a number of members of the government of the day crossed the floor and that government lost its majority in the House of Representatives, or alternatively if the government of the day had a very slim majority which was eliminated by a number of by-elections, the election to resolve those problems would drag the Senate into the crisis. I ask, for example , why should a crisis in the House of Representatives in which neither the Australian Democrats nor independents have representation and over which they can have no influence cause their terms in the Senate to be terminated and force them to the polls? Of course, it ought to be remembered that we need not have a political crisis in the House of Representatives for the Senate to be affected. If for purely pragmatic political reasons the Prime Minister of the day decides that his fortunes or those of his Party are best served by an early election, half the membership of the Senate will be required to be re-elected. Its stability, independence, continuity and smooth functioning will be totally destroyed. Its reason for being will, in my view, be very much diluted.

Should the Senate dare to exhibit its inherent characteristics, such as those of rejecting, amending or deferring legislation that it considers obnoxious for any one of many reasons, the government of the day need not have a double dissolution but may simply stand over the Senate with the threat of a general election. The effect of that step is to bypass section 57 of the Constitution, which was the subject, as we all know, of a great deal of debate in the various Constitutional Conventions. The reason that section was subject to such vigorous and detailed debate is that the participants from the various States in the Constitutional Conventions determined that the Senate was to have fixed terms which could not be short- ened by events which took place in the House of Representatives. The Senate was to be a States House with equal numbers from all the States elected for six years and was to have powers equal to those of the House of Representatives except in respect of initiating and amending certain money Bills. Given that the Senate was provided with such distinct characteristics and powers, the problems which faced the delegates was how to overcome the deadlocks betwen the two Houses. The answer was found in section 57 of the Constitution, which section it is now intended to bypass.

Mr Deputy President, for the Senate to lose its independence is for the smaller States to lose their only effective voice in the Federal Parliament. Need one wonder why the constitutional amendment now before us has already been rejected twice by the less populous States of Australia on two previous occasions? On the latter occasion both the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party strenuously supported it because they recognised that the voice of these States would be lost in Canberra to the numerically more powerful influence of the eastern States. For the very same reasons the States of New South Wales and Victoria have either been ambivalent or favoured the proposals. They have nothing to fear. New South Wales and Victoria alone return something like 76 members to the House of Representatives while the other four States return a combined total of something like 46 members. As I have observed on a previous occasion, more members are returned from outer metropolitan Melbourne and Sydney than from all the other States and Territories. Metropolitan Sydney and Melbourne return 51 members, and the whole of the smaller States and Territories return only 49 members.
It is no accident of history and no oversight by the draftsmen of the Constitution or of our founding fathers that section 7 of the Constitution reads :
The senators shall be chosen for a term of six years . . .
Section 28 reads:
Every House of Representatives shall continue for three years from the first meeting of the House, and no longer, but may be sooner dissolved by the Governor -General.

The distinction is quite clear. The founding fathers deliberately set a fixed term for senators of six years and, except within the limits of section 57, no less a period. The same founding fathers set a maximun of three years for the House of Representatives but made clear provision for any lesser period. If it had been intended simply that the term of a senator should be twice the length of the term of a member of the House of Representatives, the term of a senator would neither be fixed nor six years but rather twice the term of a member of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. Things have changed.
—Nothing has changed. All that has changed is the intention and the ambitions of the ALP to destroy the Senate.
—Mr Fraser supports it.
—Mr Fraser's judgment, with the greatest of respect, notwithstanding the fact that he was my leader, was shown to be not impeccable some months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: There were very good reasons for the term of a senator to be both fixed and for a period of six years when the Constitution was drafted. Those and other reasons remain both contemporary and, in my view, quite excellent. I add that, of course , had not sections 7 and 28 of the Constitution stood within the Constitution at that time there would have been no Federation. In fact, from my reading of constitutional debates, with the exception of one speaker in the Adelaide convention debates, I think of 1897, who called for a four-year term of a fixed nature, there was almost total agreement at that time on the timing, fixing and rotating of senators' terms. To accept that the Senate is to be able to fulfil the function for which it was and is intended is to accept the need for those provisions. To argue for its demise is to argue against those provisions.

The framers of the Constitution intended the Senate to be a States House, a House of review and a House of second deliberation, not in any way dependent upon any other chamber of the Parliament for its rights, responsibilities or existence. It was intended to be unfettered by and insulated from the machinations and political fortunes of the political parties in the House of Representatives. It was intended to have a continuity and stability which is not and cannot be available to the House of Representatives and the House responsible to the Government. In the event that there was or is to be an irreconcilable conflict between the two chambers, ample and adequate relief is provided already, as I said, under section 57 of the Constitution.

The term of six years by rotation provides both continuity and a reflection of contemporary community attitudes. The Senate stands in the Constitution removed from the actions of the Prime Minister. Only action by the Senate, not the Government, not the Prime Minister and not the House of Representatives, can cause the Senate to be held accountable to the people. I might add that if the Senate uses its powers capriciously or irresponsibly it will suffer the wrath of the electorate. In the event that the House of Representatives puts legislation to the Senate and the Senate rejects it, or fails to pass it, and the House of Representatives presents it again to the Senate-for a second time-only then can a Prime Minister approach the Governor-General to have both Houses dissolved and a simultaneous election held.

If the Senate is to function effectively as a House of review and if it is to have independence from the House of Representatives, individual senators must have a capacity to reflect that independence. No doubt our founding fathers did not expect there to arise a political party which would make expulsion axiomatic upon a senator of that party crossing the floor. However, they did perceive both party groupings and a place for independence within the chamber. A six year term does or should, in those other than members of the Australian Labor Party, instil a sense of responsible independence of mind which does not always necessarily reflect the views of their party or, particularly in the case of independents, the views of the majority of the House of Representatives.

I do not stand here today to condemn the general proposition that having a House of Representatives election on the same day as a Senate election has some merit, although there is much to be said for allowing people to monitor and review the performance of governments between general elections by way of a Senate election while, at the same time, bringing into sharper focus the purpose of the election; that is, to elect senators from the various States and to pass judgment upon the performance of those senators within the chamber. However, this Bill now before us is not about having a House of Representatives election on the same occasion as a Senate election. It is designed to have a Senate election on the same day as a House of Representatives election whenever and for whatever reason the Prime Minister of the day chooses to have an election. The veneer of credibility which has been glossed over this proposed constitutional amendment is that it will cause fewer elections, but beneath that veneer is a mechanism which is cunningly designed to reduce the independence, the potency and the power of the Australian Senate and those small States which it best represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would that it did.

—Would Senator Evans wish that? It has been put by Senator Evans and other misguided senators on the other side, with the odd aberration on this side, that the fact that there was a general vote at the last referendum of 62 per cent in favour of simultaneous election is a very good argument in favour of putting the proposition again. It is put that that reinforces the argument of those in favour of simultaneous elections, suggesting that they have the imprimatur of the majority of voters in Australia. Those who follow that argument completely dismiss or ignore the fact that we have a federation of six States and that it was those six States that provided us with a federal parliament, a constitution and the system of government we have in Canberra. To suggest for a moment that there is no relevance in the fact that four of the six States voted against simultaneous elections is to ignore the fundamental concept of federalism. I shall without hesitation vote against this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support these very important Bills brought into the Senate by the Attorney-General (Senate Gareth Evans) for voting on by the people of Australia in February 1984. The referendum process is, of course, the highest expression of our democracy. Certain unusual majorities are required-a majority of electors throughout Australia and a majority of States-thereby safeguarding the federal principle within our national arrangements. Given that there is some difficulty in obtaining these majorities, it is not surprising that the Bills have been brought into this chamber by the Attorney-General in the form they have been to achieve the purposes which are there set out, because the principal Bills undoubtedly are those designed to bring about simultaneous elections of the House of Representatives and the Senate and to bring about a four-year parliamentary term. These were not the original proposals of the Australian Labor Party, but it is well known that at the Constitutional Convention held in Adelaide earlier this year a consensus developed supporting these two proposals. Indeed, if nothing else, the fact that we are debating these matters tonight in order to put them to the Australian people proves that something worthwhile can come of the Constitutional Convention process.
—What is the definition of consensus?

—A definition of consensus in this case is a negative situation in which it became apparent that the fixed term principle would not achieve widespread support amongst substantial political groupings in Australia; yet the proposal for an extended four-year term for the House of Representatives and for simultaneous elections was shown to be a preferable course of action in order to achieve that stability of government which is so desirable and which ought to be the aim of constitutional amendments. Despite the fact that the Constitutional Convention was undermined and manipulated by the most conservative and reactionary Premiers in Australia, Premier Bjelke-Petersen of the National Party in Queensland and his National Party colleague in Tasmania masquarading as a Liberal, Mr Gray, a consensus did emerge supporting the ideas of a four-year term for the House of Representatives and simultaneous elections.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore it is quite proper, on the basis of that full discussion, that these proposals should come to the chamber tonight for endorsement and presentation to the Australian people.

The fact is that Australia has been plagued with too frequent elections, in recent years in particular. The average term of post-war parliaments has been two years and five months. In the 14 year period from 1963 to 1979 there were no fewer than 10 separate national elections. This has caused intensive community dissatisfaction. I believe it was one of the reasons why the electorate reacted so viciously against the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, when he called the early election earlier this year. People in Australia are sick and tired of that manipulation of the process in order to achieve an early election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad he is not here to hear your policy, Senator Tate.

—I know that the honourable senator is not a supporter of Mr Fraser in relation to these Bills. He attacked him very robustly in the course of this debate. The honourable senator pictured the former conservative leader, Malcolm Fraser, as a socialist in sheep's clothing who had somehow become a rabid centralist and was overriding the States in regard to these proposals. I am delighted to see that Mr Fraser is amongst those who on 7 February said that if re-elected his Government would bring both of these proposals to a referendum as soon as possible. We are helping Mr Fraser to cast a vote for these proposals in February of 1984. I am sure he will be campaigning as a private citizen of Australia to help us get these referendums through.

SPEECH.PARA: The four-year proposal will preserve the existing discretion of the Prime Minister to call an election when he thinks it is politically opportune. I am being quite frank about this. To be frank, I think that the fixed term concept has more attraction when a party is in opposition than it does when a party is in government. I believe that should the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), of whom I am a very strong supporter, judge that it is necessary to review his mandate with the Australian people at some time within this four-year extended term, if the level of frustration, impeding and hindering of the Government's program has reached a level which is distracting him from the true, deliberate and considered government of this country, which he tries to undertake day by day, he ought to be able to go to the people and renew his mandate. In general, I believe it would be very worth while extending the terms of the House of Representatives so that we have four years within which to achieve the program of the Government.

Earlier in the debate this afternoon, Senator Macklin said that he thought that to extend the term from three to four years would somehow diminish the accountablility of government. On the contrary I believe that it increases the accountability of the Government. I agree that governments ought to be as accountable as possible, but I am led to a different conclusion. Because a three -year term is so short and notoriously, as I have said, it generally lasts for two years and five months, governments do not fulfil the mandate that they are elected on. The first year is spent getting into stride. The second year is spent in carrying out some difficult and quite often unpopular measures and the third year is a pre-election year. Governments ought to be accountable to the electorate for the fulfilment of their mandate. I believe that a term of four years provides a better opportunity for that to occur. Indeed, four years is not an unusual term. As honourable senators would know, in some of our States the term of office is four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmania has a four-year term.
—This includes my State of Tasmania. I believe that such a proposal is before the Victorian Parliament at the moment.
—Yes, it is.
—Is that the case in New South Wales?
—It will be after the next election.

—So clearly a move is on at the State level of our Federation to endorse the four-year term. As has already been pointed out by Senator Missen in the course of this evening's debate, some two dozen countries-I am talking about democracies-have five-year terms. Another two dozen have four-year terms and only three or four have three-year terms. Quite clearly this is not an outrageously radical proposal; it merely provides an environment within which those decisions which are difficult can be taken, an environment within which electoral mandates can be fulfilled and then properly judged by the people. It also provides, of course, quite apart from the beneficial effects on government, an environment within which business, private enterprise and those who wish to conduct their affairs can do so in the knowledge that the Government, unless utterly hindered and frustrated by the Opposition, will be in power for four years.

SPEECH.PARA: I find the notion of simultaneous terms such an utterly sensible concept that I find it difficult to understand the opposition to it. When I was elected in December 1977 I had to wait seven months until 1 July 1978 before entering this chamber. For that seven months I was in limbo, while those who had been voted out of this chamber by the Australian people were passing legislation and making laws. Those who had announced they wished to retire were in that position also, whereas those who had been elected and supported by the Australian people in December 1977 were, as I say, in limbo without any legislative powers being available to them. That seemed to be absolutely ludicrous. This proposal will bring senators into this chamber at the same time that the members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament take their seats. This will mean that between the two chambers we will have overall a much more representative grouping of persons who will be able more properly and truly to express the current wishes of the Australian electorate. I think those two matters ought to command the support of the chamber and the Parliament, as I am sure they will and, indeed, of the Australian people, as I am sure they will, despite the difficult majorities that must be achieved.

I briefly mention some of the other proposals that have been put before the chamber. I do so but briefly because I know that many honourable senators wish to speak. Senator Mason has introduced a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws; that is, to allow the referendum process to be initiated by a sufficient number of electors indicating that they want the proposal to be put to the people. The answer to this really lies in the fact that it draws on the political experience of countries which are not similar to Australia and which do not operate in the same way as we do. The Swiss example is often quoted. In that country there is a widespread use of the electors' initiative in order to pass referendums, recall legislation an so on. Of course, the federal parliament in that country can pass laws outside its actual powers. It can pass laws and try to get away with it on the basis that that law can be recalled and disallowed by a subsequent referendum of the people. That is a completely different process to the one within which we are operating.

Further, of course, the Swiss example is particularly bad because it was a notoriously undemocratic country in the sense that until two or three years ago women were disenfranchised. It may well be that a system of initiative such as prevails in Switzerland is needed, where the actual system of electing the Government is notoriously undemocratic in disenfranchising a considerable number of the people. But I believe that with our extremely democratic system of electing the Australian Parliament, which I believe is one of the most honestly elected national parliaments in the world, this proposal for an elector's initiative to initiate the referendum process is misconceived and comes from a completely different political culture.

Senator Macklin introduced a Bill to alter the Constitution so that the number of members of the House of Representatives may be increased without ncessarily increasing the number of senators; that is, to break the nexus between the two chambers which is presently required by the Constitution, so that one must have roughly a two to one ratio between the number of members of the House of Representatives and the number of senators. This proposal was put to the people and defeated. I think that leads to the conclusion that, given the fact that we have so many proposals which will, I believe, have the general endorsement of the substantial political groupings right across the board in Australia for the February referendums, it would be mischievous or putting in peril those very good proposals to introduce into the list of matters to be voted on something which, I believe, will generate a lot of hostility around the electorate. We will have the sort of argument that Senator Crichton-Browne puts up that somehow this proposal would undermine the powers of the Senate and the States. We will also get misunderstandings about the numbers of politicians who can best serve Australia. I believe that whilst we should perhaps endorse this Bill in principle, I signify that by passing it, I do not believe that we should put it before the people in February. It ought to be kept for a later referendum. As I say, it is not that I accede to the sort of argument that to break the nexus--

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have the same arguments at a subsequent referendum.

—It is very clear from the Adelaide Constitutional Convention that we will have widespread support for simultaneous elections and for the four-year term proposal. I do not believe that that sort of widespread support has been indicated for the breaking of the nexus. On that basis I think that that matter ought to be left for another occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer has introduced a Bill to amend section 57 of the Constitution to provide that a dissolution of both Houses of the Parliament shall not take place by reason that the Senate has twice rejected a Bill if more than three months has elapsed after the Senate has so treated the proposed law. In other words, the aim of the proposal is to stop the stockpiling of Bills and to require the double dissolution process to take place, if at all, within three months of the second rejection of a House of Representatives measure by the Senate. I think that this proposal is not so clear. There are good arguments for the proposal put by Senator Hamer. But I believe that there could be occasions when perhaps a major measure could be rebutted by the Senate too early in the term of a government to really justify that government going to the people for a re- affirmation of its mandate. Nevertheless, if there were such a major measure and if the situation were then compounded some six, nine, 12 or 15 months later by a series of harassments and the impeding of Government legislation, and if there were other issues perhaps just as major or an accumulation of minor frustrations , then it could be proper for the Government to go to the people. The basis could include that original rejection of the major measure some months earlier in the term of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to have more than one matter to go to the people.

—No, but it then follows that the Government is entitled to have a meeting of the House of Representatives and the Senate together in a joint sitting. The Parliament would then become a unicameral legislature and the Government could try to obtain the passage of the Bill. I think that is the fundamental answer to what Senator Hamer is saying. I see that the honourable senator is half nodding his head in agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The final Bill has been introduced by Senator Peter Rae. It seeks to alter the Constitution to provide for automatic and simultaneous dissolution of both Houses of Parliament in the event of disagreement between the Houses in relation to the passing of proposed laws, appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual service of the Government and for related purposes. In other words, to put it in a fairly bold way, the proposal seeks an automatic double dissolution in a case where the Senate refuses to pass Supply. What this proposal would do, of course, would be to accord quite excessive importance to the role of the Senate in our parliamentary national system of government. We in the Australian Labor Party can never accept that one should have an automatic dissolution of the whole parliament flowing from a Senate rejection of Supply which amounts to a vote of no confidence in the government. Of course what we have always maintained, and maintained very strongly in the light of the events of 1975, is that under the Australian system a government is elected because it enjoys the confidence of the House of Representatives. Consequences should follow only if the Government loses the confidence of the House of Representatives. A government's creation and its sustaining through the term of a parliament depends on, as I have said, the House of Representatives giving that support.

Let me explain the other reason why I find it impossible to support the proposal from Senator Peter Rae. The real reason why this proposal was brought in by Sir Charles Court-he may have been Mr Charles Court at that stage-at one of the early constitutional conventions that I attended was to preserve the status of the Governor-General untainted by the need to exercise discretion to dissolve the Parliament. It was designed so that this automatic consequence would follow on the rejection of Supply by the Senate. Somehow that would keep the Governor-General above political controversy. The answer to that, of course, is that the Governor-General should act only on the advice of the government which enjoys the confidence of the House of Representatives. That is the convention which ought to be honoured in relation to the action of the Governor- General. If he is to exercise a discretion to grant a double dissolution, whilst it may be couched in terms of a discretion, that power ought to be exercised only on the advice of the person who commands the support and confidence of the House of Representatives. Therefore, the automatic following of a double dissolution on the refusal of Supply by the Senate certainly cannot be supported be me.

Whilst supporting one of the proposals introduced for passage by senators on the other side of the chamber-they are not for putting to the people-and whilst rejecting all the others, I conclude by re-affirming my support for the referendums to do with a double dissolution and the extension of the term of the House of Representatives to four years.

In relation to Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution, it is simply untrue to say that the proposal of the Australian Labor Party, of the Government, and supported by many honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, diminishes the powers of the Senate. It is stripped of no power whatsoever by these referendum proposals. I ask the questions: As a result of the passage of these matters by the Australian people, what legislation may the Senate not reject? What subjects may it not discuss and deliberate upon, send to its committees, bring back reports and vote upon? What inroads will be made by the passage of any of these matters by the people in February 1984? What inroads are made on the asserted power of the Senate to reject supply? Whan all of those questions are answered truthfully, the conclusion will be reached that there is no diminishing whatsoever of the powers of the Senate by these proposals. They are simply an extension of the term of the Senate to coincide with the extended term of the House of Representatives and the bringing into a simultaneous situation the elections of both chambers in order to ensure that the current will of the people is more properly and immediately represented in the deliberations of both chambers of this Parliament.

The few Opposition voices raised against these proposals have not proved convincing. I have indicated my support for the Bills introduced by the Attorney -General. I believe that I have discharged my obligation to this chamber and indeed to the Australian people in relation to these referendum Bills to show why they deserve support. I believe that they will enjoy that support. I look forward to the campaign leading to their passage in February 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many ways this is an unsatisfactory debate. We are debating nine important Bills. Each honourable senator has half an hour in which to speak and this allows us three minutes twenty seconds on each of the major Bills on constitutional changes. Therefore, one's treatment of them is necessarily somewhat superficial. I would like to make a few points about each of the Bills. The first couple-they are put to us for debate together-are the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1983 and the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1983. The latter Bill will increase the term of members of the House of Representatives to four years and the term for Senators to eight. This tackles two problems. One, of course, is the length of the life of each Parliament. The second is the possibility of having separate elections for the Senate, which most people-I think nearly all-would agree is very unsatisfactory. If we can organise it so that elections are held conjointly for the two Houses I am sure that would be widely accepted by the Australian community. I do not like the solution. I think the proposal put up previously by the Government for fixed terms was a much more satisfactory way of tackling this problem. Nevertheless, I do accept that that particular fixed term proposal had no realistic chance of passing in a referendum. There were too many opponents of it. Therefore, this proposal has been put forward as an alternative.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill cuts the term of the Senate. Instead of having a fixed six-year term, or eight years in the revised version, if the parliamentary terms are changed, senators' terms would be two terms of the House of Representatives. This proposition was put to the people before in 1974 and 1977 and was rejected on both occasions. I doubt whether it will pass this time. There is a point about the increase in the length of the term which I should put very clearly. People are talking about a four-year term for the House of Representatives and an eight-year term for the Senate. In fact, it is a term of up to four years for the House of Representatives and two terms of the House of Representatives for senators. It certainly will not be for periods of four years and eight years. At the moment, with three-year terms the average length of our parliaments has been 2.3 years. I suggest, by extrapolation, that if we go to a four-year term nominal we will have a three- year term for the House of Representatives and effectively a six-year term for senators.

I do not believe it will be easy to argue to the public that an eight-year term for senators is appropriate. I think it is too long. There is certainly argument for a four-year term for members of the House of Representatives, but the problem with the continuing nature of the Senate-half the senators going out every election-means that we are locked in if we want to go for four years for the House of Representatives and eight years for the Senate nominal. We will not achieve that in practice. Therefore, I think this proposal is unsatisfactory. I would much prefer the fixed term proposal, which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) proposed before.

Another point I should make is that one of the limitations on a government calling a double dissolution, if it gets the grounds-it can easily manufacture the grounds if it wants to do so-is the fact that by the Constitution it is not allowed to have a double dissolution within six months of the ordinary due date of an election. This has been a limitation with three-year terms because not many governments like having their terms cut back to 2 1/2 years. With the extension to four years many governments would accept a cut to 3 1/2. There would be a much stronger impulse towards manufacturing a dispute with the Senate and having a double dissolution after 3 1/2 years. I think we will reach the situation fairly soon where there will be a double dissolution at every election and the Senate will have been destroyed as a continuing body.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's news? It has almost got to that now.

—I will come to that in a moment. I do not think we should enshrine it in the Constitution. As Senator Missen knows, I have a proposal to reduce the likelihood of that. I will deal with that matter in a moment. For those reasons I think these two proposals by the Government are very much second best. I think that at least one of them will not pass. The proposals will not achieve the objectives claimed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill. The powers of the State and Federal governments are laid down in the Constitution. There is no doubt that the arrangements in the Constitution for the transfer of powers either from the Federal government to a State government or from a State government to the Federal government are unsatisfactory. The Federal government cannot transfer powers to the States, even if it wants to. For instance, we cannot give State governments power over sales tax, which in most federations, is the largest single source of provincial revenue. Even if we want to we cannot give those powers to the States for them to raise revenue at their own discretion for their own purposes. There is a problem in the transfer of powers from a State government to a Federal government. It is far from clear whether, the States having yielded powers and given them to the Federal government, they can then take them back when there is a change of government. This makes for a very unsatisfactory basis for distribution of power.

What the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill would do is clarify that situation and permit horse trading-if that is what we want-between State and Federal governments over powers. The Federal Government could say: 'I will give you, say, sales tax if in return the States will transfer to the Federal Government some powers that the Federal Government wants'. That is a peculiar way to amend the division of powers in the Constitution. It may be a fairly practical way, but I do not think it is the right way to tackle this very serious problem. The division of powers provision in the Constitution has been undermined for many years. Section 96 of the Constitution states:
. . . the Parliament may grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit.

This provision has widely undermined State powers. For instance, all the education grants are given under section 96. Education is not mentioned in the Constitution. Therefore, it is a State power. Nevertheless, the Federal Government has been able to move into various areas through its use of this financial power under section 96.

In addition to making grants and directing how they are to be spent, the Federal Government can demand matching grants from the States on a one-for-one, two-for-one or even a three-for-one basis. The States do not like this. A former State Premier faced with this referred publicly to the Federal Parliament as 'a bunch of bloody pirates'. He used to be much ruder than that in private. Nevertheless, section 96 is being used in this way. It is changing very much the balance of power between Federal and State governments. We should certainly look at it. Of course we have the very recent events-though they have origins going back more than 40 years-whereby the use of the external affairs power to give the Federal Parliament power to legislate in areas it otherwise would not have, again is changing the division of powers between the Federal and State governments. Rather than this sort of horse-trading, ad hoc way of changing the division of powers, I think that this whole area of division of powers between Federal and State governments-how we decide what those powers should be and how we decide how they should be changed-needs to be looked at overall. Although I know it has support from the Australian Constitutional Convention this seems to me to be merely tinkering with a far more significant problem. I very much doubt that it will achieve what it is intended to achieve.

I will leave the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill 1983 to the lawyers. The Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill 1983 is trivial but I think worth passing, as it tidies up the unnecessary parts of the Constitution. The Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1982 [1983], introduced by the Australian Democrats is typical nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say no more!

—I will say a couple more words. This Bill, if passed, would introduce into our Constitution, I think, a largely American concept. I know it is used by other people. The version the Democrats have chosen is very much the American concept which the Americans, I point out, have been wise enough not to touch in their Federal Congress. The States use it. It is very unsatisfactory because it encourages irresponsibility and single issue politics. What politics or political administration is all about is balancing competing needs and forces . If a single interest group is able through this technique to impose its views in a particular area one has, I submit, very unsatisfactory government. Therefore, I have not the slightest doubt that this Bill will be rejected by 59 votes to five.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill 1983. This Bill, proposed by Senator Peter Rae, would overcome a problem in our Constitution which is that if the Senate blocks a Budget or an Appropriation Bill-of course, done with a view to forcing an unwanted election on the House of Representatives-there is no way in which the Senate can be forced to an election with the House of Representatives unless it has already given other grounds for a double dissolution. I think it is well known that I do not approve of this use of the Senate's power. I do not think it is an appropriate use of our power to force an unwanted election by refusing Supply to a government. Nevertheless, the power is there. I do not think it will be used for many years, if it is ever used again. I think what the Bill provides is that, if the power is used- certainly if it is used in time for the ordinary double dissolution procedure of rejecting legislation twice after intervals of three months-and an election is forced, it should be a double dissolution. As I said, I do not like this power. Nevertheless, while the power is there, there should be provision in the Constitution so that, if it is used-I hope it will not be used-the consequences will affect the Senate at least as much as they do the House of Representatives.

The Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill is designed to break the so- called nexus between the two Houses. The provision is that the number of members of the House of Representatives should be, as near as practicable, twice the number of senators. This proposal was put to the people in 1967 and resoundingly defeated, despite the fact that it was supported by all the major parties. In fact, the only party resisting it was the Australian Democratic Labor Party. Aided by two Liberal Party senators. I think there was a campaign of extraordinary misrepresentation. Nevertheless, one got the impression that the purpose was to permit more politicians. One could always drum up votes opposing the proposition that there should be more politicians.

I think we should be prepared to look at this matter seriously because the only reason which was ever given for this nexus, this two to one ratio, was that, after a double dissolution, if the Bill or Bills that caused the double dissolution were still in dispute they could be settled by a joint sitting of the two Houses. There was a joint sitting in 1974, of course. I do not think that reason is adequate ground for retaining this nexus, because the numbers in the Senate, while it retains proportional representation, will always be narrowly balanced. If the Government has won any sort of victory in the House of Representatives, the margin in the House of Representatives will always be able to overwhelm the very narrow balance in the Senate. Therefore, I do not think the problems of a double dissolution are justifiable grounds for retaining the nexus.

The disadvantage of the nexus is that the requirements of the two Houses are quite different. The reason for the increase in the number of members in the House of Representatives is to do with servicing electors and electorates, the problems of electors such as transport and so on. The problems in increasing the size of the Senate are quite different. They would normally include the pressures of committee work, the problems of getting through the ordinary business of the Senate and all its committees. They are quite distinct. There is no reason why the numbers should progress in a two to one ratio from here to eternity. Fundamentally, the proposition is nonsense. It is important to remember, though, that there is no constitutional limit on the number of members of parliament. Parliament can provide any number it likes. The only limit is this two to one ratio between members of the House of Representatives and members of the Senate.

There is a curious feature in clause 3 of this Bill which provides for the first time, if it is passed, for a limit on the number of members of parliament. I imagine that was put in to soothe the feelings of the people who thought that the removal of the nexus would allow open slather or an increase in the number of members of parliament. Clause 3 states that the number of members for the House of Representatives should be not more than one member for every 85,000 people. If that proposal had been passed in 1967 and used the House of Representatives would now be entitled to have 181 members. I do not think many people would argue that that is an appropriate figure. It is not the first time there have been attempts to put this sort of limit on the number of representatives, or some direction on to the ratio between population and members of the House of Representatives. In the 1891 Constitution, which, of course, was never adopted, it was provided that there should be one member of the House of Representatives to every 30,000 people. If that proposal had been adopted, the House of Representatives would now have 513 members. The point is that as populations grow, the appropriate ratio between members and the public must be adjustable. Too rigid a provision such as is provided in this Bill would seem to me unwise. Certainly 85,000 people per member of the House of Representatives is far too low.

Let us look at a different federal system. In the United States, the House of Representatives has 435 members and each represents an average of 540,000 people . If we used the United States criteria and its ratio, the House of Representatives would have 29 members. Most people would think that was too small. On the other hand, if the United States used the criteria provided in Senator Macklin's Bill for breaking the nexus, it would have a House of Representatives with 2,750 members. I am only pointing out the difficulty one has in trying to pin down in this way the maximum number-Parliament can provide for a lower number, of course-of members of the House of Representatives. The problems are that as a country grows the ratio changes; we have problems of space-Australia's area is almost the same as the United States-and we have the possibility of staff members carrying out some political functions, as they do in the United States, which we expect members of parliament to do.

If this Bill proceeds, we should certainly amend it so that the maximum number of members in the House of Representatives is not more than one member for every 100,000 population. This would mean at the moment a maximum size in the House of Representatives of 154, but it would grow proportionately as the population grew . I think the idea of providing a maximum of one member for every 85,000 people creating a possibility of a House of Representatives with 181 members which would also grow as our population grew, would have no chance of success. It would be ridiculed by the public and the Bill would fail on that ground alone, quite apart from any merits which it had.

The final Bill I wish to refer to is my own Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill. Its purpose is to bring the deadlock power back to what was originally intended. When members were discussing at the constitutional conventions of the 1890s the problem of deadlock between the two Houses, the first suggestion was that if there were a deadlock it should be solved by putting it to the people in the form of a referendum. Referendums were very popular in the 1890s, which seem also to be the spiritual home of the Australian Democrats. In the 1890s, referendums were thought to be the panacea solution to all problems, but that attitude changed eventually and the present procedure was adopted. If a deadlock was established in certain laid down ways the Government, if it wished, could have a double dissolution. If after the double dissolution and after the election the deadlock persisted and the Government wished to pursue a Bill, it could be determined by a joint sitting of both Houses. The original system for overcoming deadlocks was used in 1914 and 1951, only twice in our first 70 years. It has been used three times in the last 10 years, and we almost automatically have reached the absurd situation that although senators are supposed to be elected for fixed six-year terms, only one of the present 64 senators in this chamber has ever served a full six-year term.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that?

—The President. Only one present honourable senator has ever served his full six-year term, and this is reaching the height of absurdity. As I said earlier, if we move towards a four-year term it will remove an inhibition the Government has had about forcing double dissolutions, because it cannot have a double dissolution within six months of the expiry of the House of Representatives term. It is reluctant to cut its term back to 2 1/2 years. If we went to a four-year term it would find it easier to cut it at 3 1/2 years. Unless we do something about it we will have a double dissolution at every election. This will destroy the continuing Senate-the basis on which we were founded and which I think is very important to the operation of our Parliament. So I propose that we keep the deadlock power but provide that, if the Government gets the ground for a double dissolution through a particular piece of legislation of critical importance and does not exercise its power to solve the deadlock through the means of a double dissolution within three months of gaining that power, that power should lapse. That would bring the measure back to its original purpose. It would still be open to the Government to serve up a potential double dissolution Bill close to an election, but not within six months. Then it would be within the power of the Senate to decide whether it wished to fight an election on those grounds. If if did not, if could pass the Bill.

—What would you do about the death of a thousand cuts inflicted upon a government by an opposition with a series of small irritations and harassments which in themselves are not sufficient to justify perhaps a full scale double dissolution?

—I do not think, as our politics work in this country, that the grounds for a double dissolution are ever significant during an election campaign. The grounds for the double dissolution which led to the election in March were a series of Bills passed about a year before, Bills which the Government, I must say, admitted during the election that it had no intention of reintroducing even if it won the election. So, given the way our elections are fought I do not think the actual grounds would normally be a very significant part of the election campaign. Suppose the Government is, as Senator Evans puts it, suffering the death of a thousand cuts. When it gets fed up with it it can bring a Bill as a double dissolution Bill and then have its double dissolution and fight the election if it wants to. Alternatively, if the Government is having trouble with a lot of Bills, it could serve the Bills up in succession and the Senate at any stage would have to make a decision either to put up or to shut up. It has to say: 'We will pass this Bill because we are not prepared to fight an election' or: 'We will defy the Government and take the consequences'. That is the purpose for which the original provision was designed.
—But if you are re- turned with a mandate should you not be able to wipe the slate clean in one go with a joint sitting going back over all those earlier measures?

—I do not think that is necessary. Senator Tate raised this point earlier. If the Government wins the election, particularly when the Senate has, in the Government's view, been obstructive, the Government will have, as I think the Senate has shown, a mandate to introduce its program. We have not been obstructive with measures on which the Government fought the election.
—What about bottom of the harbour recoupment?
—Bottom of the harbour recoupment was not in your election program .
—It was indeed. Don't tell fibs.
—You promised no penal legislation.
—It is not penal legislation; it is recovery legislation.

—I think the question of whether it is penal or not penal is not relevant to this point. Senator Evans has diverted me from the fundamental thrust to which he does not like being brought back of the purpose of the Constitution and the way in which it should work. As I think I made evident, I support some of these Bills. I am not very impressed by or prepared to go along with some others, and I strongly oppose the one providing for referendums to solve our political problems on the initiative of small pressure groups. Whilst I think it is important that all of these measures that can command support in both Houses should be put to the people, we must ensure that our Constitution is a living document. The Government may fail the first time. But I think it underestimates the intelligence of the people if it is not prepared to put admittedly controversial proposals because it thinks that it might damage the prospects of the passage of other Bills to which it is attracted. There is no evidence whatever for that proposition. People have shown in their voting that they have distinguished very sharply between different propositions put to them by way of amendments to the Constitution by referendum. I am sure that that is what we can achieve when the referendum is held early next year.

SPEECH.PARA: We must make our Constitution a living document-a document capable of change and capable of adjusting to the needs of the coming decades. These are the requirements that we have as a Parliament. I suggest that it is the duty of the Government to put sensible proposals for amendments to the Constitution to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a somewhat difficult debate in that it concerns nine different Bills which, if passed, will take different proposals to the people by means of referendum pursuant to the provisions of the Constitution. Really, only one of those nine Bills requires no attention at all; that is the Bill to remove certain transitional and outdated provisions. I believe that all the others require some attention and, although the time to speak is very restricted, it is my intention to deal with them.

SPEECH.PARA: I deal firstly with the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill. I make the point right from the start that I oppose this Bill. I do not oppose the principle of simultaneous elections, in fact I am in favour of simultaneous elections, but I oppose this Bill. I believe that my position is consistent with the position I took on the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill , which I supported. I opposed the right of a Prime Minister to call an election at will at a time that he assesses as politically propitious. Governments should be elected for a term and they should serve that term. Electors should have the right to assess a government on its performance over the whole of that term. At the moment, of course, we have a fixed term for the Senate and, therefore, subject to double dissolutions, the people have that opportunity. But we have an unfixed but maximum term for the House of Representatives.

The Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill, which until very recently we had before the Senate, would have left the Senate position intact and would have provided also a fixed term for the House of Representatives. But I regret to say that the Government has failed all those who have supported such a change and it has now withdrawn that Bill. But it has not found a compromise. It has, rather, totally reversed direction. It now proposes not only that the term of the House of Representatives should be unfixed but also that the Senate fixed term should be abandoned. We will now be left with a situation in which not only will the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) be able to call the House of Representatives to the people at will but, in so doing, he will also call out the Senate. For those of us who see a failing or a weakness in his being able to do so, we must see in this Bill a double failure. For those of us who believed that the Government was genuine in supporting the concept of fixed term parliaments, it is a double disappointment.

That does not mean, as I indicated, that I do not support the holding of simultaneous elections. I do. It was one of the great advantages of that Bill, but unfortunately it has now been withdrawn. There is no reason why, under the existing system, simultaneous elections cannot take place. It is only premature House of Representatives elections, for whatever reason, that the Government may advance, that throws the Houses out of sequence and inflicts extra elections upon the community, with all the additional costs and distractions that such unnecessary elections encompass. As I indicated, I intend to oppose the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill.

I wish to speak briefly on Senator Macklin's Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill which is to break the nexus between the numbers in the Senate and the numbers in the House of Representatives which is, of course, created by section 24 of the Constitution. As all honourable senators will know, the number of members in the House of Representatives is to be as nearly as practicable twice the number of senators. To assess the desirability of that provision it is obviously necessary to look at its purpose. A number of arguments have been advanced from time to time in its favour. An argument one hears relatively often is that it enables the Senate to retain its powers. That, of course, is nonsense . The Senate is a most powerful Upper House by virtue of its wide power to amend and total power to reject. Whatever one thinks of the merits of such powers they certainly have nothing to do with the nexus tying the number in the House of Representatives to no more than twice the number of senators.

A further argument one hears from time to time is that it is necessary to retain the nexus to retain the Senate's influence. Again, I have great difficulty in following that argument. The influence of the Senate in my opinion will depend on its performance and the quality of the contribution of its members, not on the number of Senators vis-a-vis the number of members in the House of Representatives. I know it is always dangerous to make comparisons with systems elsewhere, but I reflect upon the United States Senate which I think Senator Hamer mentioned in his speech immediately preceding mine. The United States Senate has maintained its status and influence although its membership numbers much less than half that of the House of Representatives.

The third argument that I sometimes hear for maintaining the nexus is that it is seen as necessary to protect the position of the smaller States. Such protection, as far as it exists, does not lie in the nexus between the size of the chambers. The Senate, as I have said, has the powers and the protection lies in the equal representation from each State, whether large or small. But I am afraid that in any event that protection, or the belief in that protection, may well be overrated. Certainly, senators here promote and argue for the interests of their States but I reflect upon the question of whether senators from smaller States join across party lines to match the larger States. In my experience the answer is never. Strict party allegiance has very much diluted this role which was seen as important by some of the founding fathers, although it is interesting to note that others were sceptical as to its importance and function right from the start.

The strongest argument that seems to be put to retain the nexus is that in relation to joint sittings. But in a Parliament with already a 2:1 ratio it is very unlikely that a breakdown of party allegiance in the Senate, although half of the senators have been elected on each of two separate occasions, will have any effect upon the outcome of a joint sitting. Therefore, I cannot find arguments for retaining the nexus that are particularly persuasive. Rather, I believe that the correct approach is to look at the role being played by the respective chambers and assess the number of members and senators necessary to carry out such functions.

The Australian Democrats have promoted in this Bill and in the second reading speech the need to break the nexus on a desire to increase the size of the House of Representatives and not the Senate. A debate on the numbers is not really relevant tonight. It is a debate that we will face in the not too distant future . But I will use this opportunity to register a concern. It is said that members cannot carry out their representative role adequately with electorates of their present size. But again, looking at the United States where the average electorate is, I understand, in the vicinity of half a million we see that with adequate staffing and servicing, members appear to be doing the job quite satisfactorily.

I want to contrast the role of the Senate. One can look at the review role of the Senate in relation to the quality of legislation which is passing through this chamber. One can look at the Senate's safeguard role in relation to the protection of human rights and liberties. One can look to the Senate's function in examining wider constitutional, social, trade, resources and other issues. These are all matters of critical importance and matters on which, I believe, the performance of the Senate can be improved. I noted Senator Missen's contribution earlier tonight in which he particularly made that point in relation to the committees. Some would therefore see and argue a need for increasing the number of senators. On the other hand some might argue that the difficulty is inadequate servicing. But, as I indicated, that is not an argument for tonight. Let us assess the need for the number of members and senators on the basis of the need to carry out functions responsibly, not according to a now largely irrelevant formula.

The third Bill I wish to look at very briefly is Senator Hamer's Bill. That Bill provides that when there is a double dissolution trigger, action must be taken within three months or the potential for that double dissolution will lapse. As Senator Hamer preceded me and eloquently put arguments in support of his Bill, I do not want to spend a great deal of time on it. But I do commend it to the Senate as a proposition which has considerable merit. This game of a Prime Minister holding double dissolution Bills over his party, the Senate and the Parliament as a whole cannot facilitate the efficient functioning of this institution. Senator Hamer's proposal will mean that the provisions of the Constitution will operate in the way that I see they were designed to operate. I believe that this is a real test for this Labor Party Government. I suspect that it is a proposal that would have received the support of the Labor Party had it been in opposition. It will be interesting to see whether the exigencies of office have again tempted the idealism honourable senators opposite used to claim.

The fourth Bill which I wish to look at briefly concerns the extension of terms . If we are not to have fixed terms for the House of Representatives I support extension of the maximum term to four years. It would allow a genuine government better opportunity to implement its program. I support also the extension of the term of the Senate, although I must confess that I am not entirely happy with the prospect of eight years. That seems to me to be too long a term. Standing by my desirability for fixed terms, I have had to balance the undesirability of a longer term for senators with the desirability of retaining the potential for keeping the Houses in sequence and the consequence, hopefully, of fewer elections. Without a lot of conviction I have therefore found for the latter.

The fifth Bill I wish to touch upon is Senator Rae's. That Bill provides for automatic and simultaneous dissolution of both Houses in the event of disagreement between the Houses in relation to the passing of proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys for ordinary annual services of government. In the speech I gave on the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill in May of this year I made clear my attitude on this Bill. The Constitution is silent as to what is to happen in the event of the Senate refusing Supply. The unique set of circumstances that occurred in 1975 might indicate that when the Senate defers Supply and a double dissolution mechanism is in place, if a Prime Minister refuses to go to the people and an Opposition Leader promises to do so, a Governor-General may dismiss the government. But even then I am not certain that in the same circumstances, if they were ever to be repeated, the Governor- General would act in the same way.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., in accordance with the sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter through you, Mr President, with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to a newspaper article that appeared in the Canberra Times recently headed: 'Prosecutions under brothel laws dropped'. There seems to be some confusion in the community as to exactly what the Attorney-General has in mind by not proceeding with prosecutions. It seems there is no suggestion that the police did not have adequate evidence to take the matters to court. Whether or not they would have succeeded I have no idea. But the Police Offences Ordinance 1930 says, in section 18:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who-
(a) manages or conducts a brothel; or
(b) is knowingly concerned in the management or conduct of a brothel,
is guilty of an offence and is punishable, upon summary conviction, by imprisonment for a period not exceeding twelve months.
I think that many people would assume from that that if a person runs a brothel and gets caught at it, he is likely to be prosecuted. Another significant section, section 19B, states:
A prosecution for an offence against section 18--
and two other sections-
of this Ordinance shall not be instituted except with the consent of the Attorney-General or a person authorized by the Attorney-General to give consent for the purposes of this section.

Perhaps it is a lack of understanding of that section that has caused some people in the community to wonder what the Attorney-General's reasons are in this matter. The newspaper article to which I have referred said:

Senator Evans said in reply to questions put yesterday, 'a number of considerations were taken into account including, in particular, the almost complete lack of complaint from members of the public'.

Most people would know that if they drove down Canberra Avenue at 120 kilometres per hour and the speed limit is either 60 or 80 kilometres per hour, they would be prosecuted if caught; whereas in this situation it seems that even though it is an offence, people will be prosecuted only if others complain about it.

It may well be that in relation to brothels there have not been many complaints . People know that it is an offence to run a brothel and assume that the normal procedures will take place if they do run a brothel. The Senate may think that the analogy with a motor vehicle speeding is absurd, but I think that many people would feel that that is reasonable, and that it is not a question of complaining. In fact, I understand that a couple of people have complained to the Attorney-General, so the question then is: How many have to complain for this to be a relevant fact in the Attorney-General's consideration of prosecution? Senator Evans is alleged to have said further:
The question whether, in the light of the surrounding circumstances, the public interest required the institution of proceedings-
and to have also said:
Each case must be considered on its merits.

I think that the Attorney-General should spell out for this community what his reasons are. He has said 'a number of considerations' in addition to 'complaint from members of the public'. What are the other considerations that he takes into account when determining whether or not to prosecute in this situation? Perhaps he is considering repealing the legislation and legalising brothels. I certainly do not know what he has in mind, but I think that we are entitled to know the matters that he takes into account in deciding not to prosecute. People are entitled to know how many people must complain before he would consider a prosecution. I should be glad if he would give his views on this matter so that they can be made public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 19B of the Australian Capital Territory Police Offences Ordinance is very unusual, among the provisions of that Ordinance-perhaps it is unique; I have not checked-in that it requires that the Attorney-General's affirmative consent, or his delegate's affirmative consent, be given prior to the institution of proceedings . That is in contradistinction to the normal provision where there is a residual discretion in the prosecution authorities, ultimately the Attorney-General himself, to withdraw from proceedings, come in over the top, if he feels or the prosecution authorities feel that for one or other reason a prosecution should not lie. That I suggest is an important point to appreciate at the threshold because it indicates to me that there is a quite proper emphasis that should be placed on larger public interest considerations in each particular case that comes up for possible prosecution. It is appropriate that some attention be paid to those public interest considerations in a way that perhaps might be not so appropriate for ordinary offences where there is not that preliminary threshold requirement of consent.
—What are you talking about?
—Brothels in the Australian Capital Territory. Senator Georges should curb his racing hormones and he will hear all sorts of interesting things.
—How do you happen to be discussing the subject of brothels?

—Because Senator Reid has a passion for the subject and she has raised it quite properly on behalf of her constituents. So much for the preliminary point I want to make. I go on to say that it is the case that I have recently declined to give my consent pursuant to that section for the institution of proceedings in respect of seven cases of alleged offences against section 18 (b) of that Police Offences Ordinance. The decision not to consent to the institution of proceedings was carefully taken in accordance with the established guidelines for the making of such decisions. The guidelines to which I refer are set out and available for public consumption in that splendid document entitled 'Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth' which was tabled in the Parliament late last year by the then Acting Attorney-General in the absence of Senator Durack. I assume that Senator Durack would have been only too happy to table the document had he been around. It is a very useful compilation of the appropriate criteria to apply for all considerations of prosecutions, including the application of prior consents as are required here.

SPEECH.PARA: The available evidence was considered by me in each case, together with the question of whether the public interest required the institution of proceedings. The primary public interest consideration to which I had regard was, as I have already stated publicly, the extent of the public complaints that had been received in relation to the various premises the subject of the prosecutions. In only one of the seven cases had there been any public complaints. There had been several complaints made in respect of the particular premises in question but that was only one of the seven and in that one case the evidence was in fact substantially less strong that was the case for the other six in respect of which no public complaints had been made. I do readily acknowledge that the evidence on the face of it was substantial in relation to those other six premises and I make no criticism at all of the dedication of the police force in the compilation of the material to support the prosecutions in question.

My Department's advice to me on this subject was accompanied by the annotation 'one in, all in'. But I thought that a more appropriate response, which I in turn annotated on the advice, was rather 'withdrawn in all'. My decisions in the cases referred to should not be taken as an indication that I would never consent to the institution of proceedings for such offences. I have made it clear that I regard it as appropriate to treat these matters on a case by case basis. I would, however, point out finally that prostitution laws in the Australian Capital Territory are archaic and badly in need of review. Preliminary work has already been undertaken on this review and I hope that the results of this work will be available in the near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.10 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Lands Acquisition Act-Statements (2) by the Minister describing land acquired by agreement under sub-section 7 (1) of the Act, for specified purposes.
Public Service Act-Appointment-Department of Health-R. S. McClory.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minster representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 25 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which manned lighthouses provide a weather reporting service to the Bureau of Meteorology.
(2) Would the loss of reliable weather reports provide a hindrance to coastal shipping if these lights were automated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Queensland: Low Isles, Fitzroy Island, Cape Cleveland, Pine Islet, Cape Capricorn, Bustard Head, Lady Elliott Island, Sandy Cape, Double Island Point, Cape Moreton.
New South Wales: Cape Byron, Smokey Cape, Norah Head, Point Perpendicular, Montague Island, Green Cape.
Victoria: Gabo Island, Point Hicks, Wilson's Promontory, Cape Schank, Cape Otway, Cape Nelson.
Tasmania: Deal Island, Low Head, Swan Island, Eddystone Point, Cape Bruny, Maatsuyker Island.
South Australia: Cape Willoughby, Cape Borda, Neptune Island.
Western Australia: Cape Leeuwin, Cape Naturaliste, Rottnest Island, Cape Leveque.
Northern Territory: Cape Don.
In addition, Booby Island off the Cape York Peninsula sends in rainfall reports only.
(2) Yes. The loss of reliable weather reports from lighthouses could provide a hindrance to coastal shipping for the following reasons.
(i) weather reports from lighthouses form a very important part of the Bureau's surface network, which is used as a basis for its analysis and forecasts;
(ii) loss of these reports would significantly decrease the accuracy of detailed coastal weather forecasts;
(iii) coastal reports broadcast as part of weather bulletins assist marine users in monitoring and interpreting Bureau coastal waters forecasts;

(iv) automatic weather stations, whose installation is dependent upon capital and provision of adequate maintenance, could provide a partial replacement for reports from manned lighthouses, but loss of observations of sea and swell would have a significant impact on the quality of marine weather services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 7 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps has the Australian Government taken to ensure that its aid to Sri Lanka is reaching the Tamil refugees and not the Jayewardene Government's military and police forces which participated in the recent acts of genocide against the Tamil minority in Sri Lanka.

(2) Is the Australian Government, through its High Commission in Sri Lanka and other independent sources, receiving accurate numbers of the Tamil people that have been killed, the houses, shops, factories and businesses burnt and the total number of refugees displaced, or is it relying on press releases issued by the Sri Lankan Government for world consumption.
(3) What measures are the Jayawardene Government taking to ensure the safety, security, health, education and work programmes for these displaced refugees.
(4) Are there no telephone, train or shipping services to Jaffna, now under military occupation.

(5) What measures are the Jayawardene Governement taking to rehabilitate the 65 ,000 persons acknowledged by that Government to be still in the Colombo refugee camps and without homes and work places.

(6) Will the Australian Prime Minister and Foreign Minister initiate a series of inquiries at the United Nations and co-ordinate these with the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting conference to be held in November in New Delhi.
(7) Will the Australian Government as a sign of Australian concern, consider freezing its aid to the Jayawardene Government, including military and police training, until these matters are resolved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government's contribution of $100,000 as humanitarian assistance to the Government of Sri Lanka was made available on the basis of reimbursement, on receipt of certification by the Secretary, Ministry of Plan Implementation, that all expenditures were directed towards relief activities for displaced persons. During the peak of relief activities the Australian High Commission attended daily meetings held by the Secretary, Ministry of Plan Implementation, in his capacity of Deputy Commissioner-General of Essential Services responsible for co-ordination of relief assistance. These meetings were also attended by aid officers from other donor countries and representatives of non-government organisations. There were thus adequate opportunities to assess how relief activities were being managed and whether expenditures reflected needs. All officers were offered free access to the camps.

Emergency relief has been jointly co-ordinated between Sri Lankan Government officials and non-government organisations.
