Officials from the Sri Lankan Social Security and Health ministries provided up-to-date reports on conditions in displaced person camps, shortages and arrangements for the transport of displaced persons. The non-government organisations accepted functional responsibility for providing data on the numbers of people in camps, arranging the transfer to Jaffna by sea of displaced persons and providing advice on such matters as hygiene. These organisations were well placed to monitor relief requirements and distribution. Overall arrangements were adequately observed by the Australian High Commission in Colombo.

Certified statements seeking reimbursement from the Australian donation have been submitted for items which include flour, sugar, rice, jams, bread, textiles for clothing, cooking and eating utensils. Our High Commission's involvement at coordinating meetings confirmed that these items were in heavy demand.

A balance of approximately $50,000 of the Australian contribution remains unexpended. The Sri Lankan authorities have sought our approval to utilise this amount for relief to displaced persons in the predominantly Tamil populated centres of Jaffna, Batticaloa and Trincomalee.

Our High Commission's contacts with other donors and non-government organisations suggest that emergency aid was not misdirected, and that the relief to displaced persons was satisfactorily handled. The major problems were hygiene and food storage facilities and water supplies as most camps were located at schools. These problems were quickly identified and did not reach crisis point as the numbers in the camps were reduced within a reasonable period .

With regard to the safety and security of the camps, a joint statement has been issued by the representatives of United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, Campaign Against Racial Exploitation, Redd Barna, IHAP and Save the Children Fund. It stated:

'At the request of the Government, our organisations assisted in the running of the relief camps and transport of supplies with professional personnel. We would like to take this opportunity to place on record our collective appreciation for the speed and efficiency with which the Government mobilized the necessary resources to meet the immediate emergency, as well as the good co-ordination of the efforts of so many governmental agencies. We also wish to record our satisfaction with the sufficient and correct security measures provided for the camps. Likewise, we have been impressed with the order and efficiency of the evacuation by sea and train of those refugees wishing to leave Colombo for other parts of the island, and especially the consideration shown to the refugees in providing provision, medicines, security, etc., during their stay in the camps and in transit to the points of departure.'

(2) The Australian Government, through its High Commission in Colombo, has been kept informed of developments in Sri Lanka, including the extent of damage and estimated numbers of persons killed and displaced during the recent violence. Data has been gathered from the official statements of the Government of Sri Lanka and from information provided by other, non-government sources, such as the situation reports of the United Nations Disaster Relief Organisation and the League of Red Cross Societies.
The Government of Sri Lanka's estimate of damage to property equivalent to A$ 100m is reckoned by observers to be generally accurate.

With regard to the number of deaths, there are widely varying estimates and accurate information is difficult to obtain due to the relocation of a large number of Tamils including those who took refuge in such places as India, Singapore, and the United Kingdom, some of whom may have been reported as missing. Australia has accepted the Sri Lankan Government figure of 381 deaths.

(3) and (5) As at 12 September, there were 15,272 displaced persons in camps in Colombo and 6,000 in camps in other centres. Approximately fifty per cent of breadwinners have resumed employment and return to the camps in the evenings.

Sri Lankan voluntary agencies are 'adopting' families to assist with their rehabilitation in their original areas of residence. These amount to approximately 6,000 people who fled to the north from the plantation areas. The World Vision organisation, Society for Economic Development and the Red Cross are assisting with this program. Their immediate needs are being met by the distribution of food parcels provided by Government agencies.

A social security scheme under which food rations will be provided to displaced workers (approximately 24,000) for the next three months, was approved by the Sri Lankan Cabinet last week. Private firms have been requested by the Government to take in approximately 4,000 displaced persons. Approximately 5,000 people have been re-employed by companies affiliated with those destroyed and are being paid half salary. The shortfall in salary is being made up by food assistance. A further 9,000 displaced self-employed persons are also receiving assistance under this scheme. Approximately 2,000 persons who held middle management positions are not included in this scheme but the Government is examining the possibility of making cash payments to supplement food aid to give them a total income equivalent to their July salaries. Civil servants were provided with leave on full pay for the period of disruption.

The Government has established the Rehabilitation of properties and Industries Authority (REPIA) to assist both owners of business and private residences with rehabilitation. A freeze was placed on all privately owned properties and they were placed in REPIA's control as a safeguard against unscrupulous transactions. Landlords of properties formerly leased by Tamils are prohibited from entering into new lease agreements without approval of the Authority.
Government Departments are endeavouring to relocate Tamil officers to the location of their choice.
School Superintendents have been directed to facilitate the enrolment of displaced schoolchildren.
(4) Telephone services to Jaffna were not disrupted and train, shipping and road transport services have resumed.

(6) The recent communal disturbances in Sri Lanka have been the subject of discussion at the current 36th session of the United Nations Sub-Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities, an independent expert body operating under the umbrella of the UN Commission on Human Rights. A draft resolution has been adopted requesting the Secretary-General of the United Nations to invite the Government of Sri Lanka to submit any information on the recent communal violence, including its efforts to investigate the incidents and to promote communal harmony, and to submit any information received from the Sri Lankan Government to the Commission on Human Rights at its 40th session in February/March 1984. The resolution also recommended to the Commission that it should examine the situation in Sri Lanka in the light of all available information. The Australian Government would not consider it appropriate to raise the communal situation in Sri Lanka at other multilateral meetings.

(7) It would not be appropriate for the Australian Government to reconsider its commitment to development assistance in Sri Lanka. Any move in this direction would fall most heavily upon those whom it is most intended to assist, namely the poor of both communities. Nor is this Government aware of any moves of this nature by any other international aid donors.

Military training offered to Sri Lanka by Australia has in the past two years been restricted to attendance by one officer of the Sri Lankan armed services to the Joint Services Staff College, Canberra, and a divers' course offered by the Royal Australian Navy. There is no intention to reconsider this assistance.
